The Dieterle silver stain (choice B) is used to identify Legionella pneumophila, which is an agent of atypical pneumonia of the elderly but would be more likely in a smoker or immunosuppressed patient. Legionella would respond to erythromycin, but this patient is not immunocompromised. The Quellung reaction (choice C) is a technique used to identify the capsular serotype of Streptococcus pneumoniae. This bacterium is the most common cause of adult typical pneumonia and would not cause the interstitial presentation described here. Requirement for cysteine (choice D) is a characteristic of four genera of bacteria: Francisella, Legionella, Brucella, and Pasteurella. Although Francisella, Legionella, and Brucella are facultative intracellular pathogens that could cause atypical pneumonia, they would not be expected in this patient. Francisella is acquired from ticks or from handling infected reservoir animals. Brucella is acquired from contaminated dairy products or contact with animals. Legionella is a disease of elderly smokers who are immunosuppressed. Pasteurella is found in the mouths of many animals and is transmitted most commonly from cat bites. Requirement for factors X and V (choice E) is characteristic of Haemophilus. Haemophilus is an extracellular bacterium that causes otitis media, epiglottitis, pharyngitis and meningitis in unvaccinated children who are between 3 months and 2 years of age. It would not be expected in the present patient's age group.

question: A 35-year-old man who lives in the central U.S. develops fever chest pain, and dry cough. Chest x-rays show opacities, consistent with calcified masses. The results of a PPD skin test are negative. A CT-guided biopsy of one of the calcifying masses is most likely to show which of the following?
options: A. 2-to-5-μm yeast with a thin cell wall but no true capsule
B. 4-to-10-μm yeast with a broad, slimy capsule
D. 20-to-50-μm nonbudding spherule filled with endospores
E. Hyphae branching dichotomously at acute angles
explanation: The correct answer is A. A variety of fungi can produce acute or chronic lung disease like that described in this case history. They are distinguished by geographic incidence and examination of the sputum or biopsy. Histoplasma capsulatum which causes histoplasmosis, is observed most frequently in the Ohio, Mississippi, and Missouri river valleys of the United States (Central U.S.). The organism is a small (2-to-5-μm) intracellular yeast which, despite the name, has no true capsule. Calcifying lesions forming in the lungs are very suggestive of fungal infection. Blastomyces dermatitidis could cause similar presentation in this area, but it would be found in the sputum as a broad-based budding yeast, and that option is not available within the choices. Choice B describes Cryptococcus which is the most common cause of fungal meningitis in immunosuppressed patients notably those with AIDS or hematopoietic disorders. Choice C describes Paracoccidioides which can cause pulmonary disease in patients from South and Central America. Choice D describes Coccidioides, which can cause skin lesions or pulmonary disease in the desert southwest and far west of the United States (San Joaquin Valley fever). Choice E describes Aspergillus an opportunistic fungus that can invade cavitary lesions in the lung and cause aspergilloma, or fungus ball.

question: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of fever, joint and muscle pain, photophobia, and malaise. He says that he felt well until 4 days ago, but now has a headache and has been vomiting. His temperature is 40.0°C (104.0°F). Physical examination shows no rash, ulceration, or petechiae Laboratory studies show an absolute leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and increased serum transaminases. A peripheral blood smear shows granulocytes that contain berry-like clusters of intracellular organisms. The vector for the causative agent of his illness is the same as that for which of the following organisms?
explanation: The correct answer is A. This patient has granulocytic ehrlichiosis, caused by Ehrlichia phagocytophila. This intracellular bacterium is transmitted by the Ixodes tick, which also transmits Borrelia burgdorferi and Babesia microti. The disease presents similarly to Rocky Mountain spotted fever but does not have a rash. The pathognomonic feature in this case history is the presence of morulae (berry-like clusters of organisms) inside the patient's granulocytes. Francisella tularensis (choice B) can be transmitted in a number of different ways, but when an arthropod is implicated, it is the Dermacentor tick. This is the same tick that transmits Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Tularemia is an ulceroglandular disease with fever, ulcer at the bite site, and lymph node enlargement. Plasmodium vivax (choice C) is transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito. Mosquitoes are responsible for transmission of most of the encephalitis viruses, all species of malaria parasites, dengue yellow fever, and filariasis. This patient clearly does not have encephalitis, and malaria, dengue, yellow fever, and filariasis would not be expected in a 16-year-old boy in the continental United States. Rickettsia rickettsii (choice D) is the agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever and is transmitted by the Dermacentor tick. Rocky Mountain spotted fever has a characteristic rash that begins on the ankles and wrists progressing toward the trunk. The Weil-Felix test, which is a nonspecific test for antibodies that agglutinate Proteus organisms, would be positive. This tick also transmits Francisella tularensis but the symptoms of this patient are not consistent with either tularemia (an ulceroglandular disease) or Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Rickettsia tsutsugamushi (choice E) is the agent of scrub typhus. It is transmitted by mites in the genus Leptotrombidium. Rickettsialpox (Rickettsia akari) is also transmitted in this fashion, but both of these diseases are rare in the United States and would be characterized by rash and Weil-Felix test positivity.

question: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a seizure. His mother says that he developed a fever, a severe prefrontal headache, and an altered sense of smell ten days after swimming in a lake near his camp. Physical examination shows a profuse green discharge from the nose. Examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows 100 neutrophils, 50 lymphocytes, 30 mg/dL glucose, and 60 mg/dL protein. He dies two days after admission despite aggressive therapy Which of the following is most likely to be found on microscopic examination of the central nervous system at autopsy?
options: D. Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusion bodies
E. Ribbon-like hyphae branching at 90-degree angles
explanation: The correct answer is C. This child has acquired primary amebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri. This organism is a free-living ameba that is found in warm freshwater lakes. During the act of diving into such lakes, changes in pressure can force the organism through the cribriform plate and result in the production of necrotic lesions spreading from the olfactory lobes. The form of the organism that is found in human tissue is a flagellated trophozoite. Gram-negative, encapsulated diplococci (choice A) describes Neisseria meningitidis. This is a common cause of meningitis in young adults, but the case history would have to describe the presence of petechial hemorrhages from endotoxin toxicity. N. meningitidis overproduces outer membrane fragments and thus produces very early signs of endotoxin shock compared to other gram-negative organisms. Gram-positive catalase-negative diplococci (choice B) describes Streptococcus pneumoniae. Although this is the most common cause of typical pneumonia, meningitis and sinusitis in the United States, it is not associated with swimming or diving, and the CSF would have shown extremely high numbers of neutrophils, low glucose, and high protein. Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusion bodies (choice D) describes cells infected with herpes simplex virus. This is the most common cause of viral encephalitis in the United States. It is not associated with swimming or diving. Although the CSF cell, protein, and glucose values could have indicated a viral etiology, herpes simplex encephalitis is also associated with a high opening pressure and the presence of many red blood cells. Encephalitis is also generally associated with confusion or change in mental status. Ribbon-like hyphae branching at 90-degree angles (choice E) describes the zygomycophyta: bread mold fungi in the genera Rhizopus, Absidia, and Mucor. These agents can cause fatal rhinocerebral infections in ketoacidotic diabetics and adults with cancer. The symptoms would be quite similar to those described in this case history, but these are opportunistic pathogens that do not cause disease in otherwise healthy individuals. Urease-positive, encapsulated yeasts (choice F) describes Cryptococcus neoformans. This monomorphic fungus is the principal cause of meningitis in patients with Hodgkin disease or AIDS.

question: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a sudden high fever, severe dyspnea, and malaise. One hour later, he develops progressive respiratory distress and supplemental oxygen is provided. He has a history of intravenous drug abuse, His CD4 cell count is 73/uL. Which of the following tests will be most helpful in confirming the identity of the most likely causal agent of his fever and respiratory symptoms?
explanation: The correct answer is B. The most common atypical pneumonia in AIDS is caused by the atypical fungus Pneumocystis jiroveci (formerly carinii). Patients with Pneumocystis pneumonia have great difficulty producing sputum, so bronchial lavage or transmural biopsy are generally required. The sample is then submitted to the direct fluorescent antibody test or stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain to visualize the organisms. The direct fluorescent antibody test is a technique to demonstrate the presence of antigen from a pathogen in a patient. Antigen-detecting tests will remain useful throughout the life of an AIDS patient because they do not depend on detection of the patient's immune response to the pathogen (which may be absent at the end of AIDS). When stained with methenamine silver, Pneumocystis cysts have a characteristic cup or boat shape; the individual cells are difficult to demonstrate without electron microscopy. CD4 cell count (choice A) is used to measure the progression of infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Since the virus infects and destroys these cells, the number remaining in the circulation becomes a good predictor of the progression of disease. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (choice C) is used as the screening test to diagnose HIV infection. It is a serologic test (i.e., identifies antibodies against the virus) and once the patient progresses into full-blown AIDS, antibody levels other than IgM will decline, so in general, serologic tests in late HIV infection tend to be less useful than tests that detect antigens from a pathogen. Polymerase chain reaction (choice D) is used to detect the viral load of the HIV virus in infected patients and infants. Western blot (choice E) is the confirmatory serologic test that is used in the diagnosis of HIV infection.

question: A 28-year-old woman from Mexico develops an indurated, erythematous nodule that is 12 mm in diameter after receiving a PPD tuberculin test. Which of the following is the bacterial feature most important in stimulating this response?
explanation: The correct answer is D. This woman has developed a positive tuberculin skin test indicating exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The molecule injected into the skin of the forearm to elicit this response is a purified protein derivative (PPD), which is composed of tuberculin (an outer surface protein) and mycolic acids of the organism. This is an example of a type IV hypersensitivity reaction requiring sensitized TH1 cells. Only proteins can evoke such responses, since T cells are only capable of recognizing peptides presented to them in the context of an MHC molecule. The cell wall (choice A) of mycobacteria contains a thinner-than-normal layer of peptidoglycan and mycolic acids, which are long-chain fatty acids. However, this material is not proteinaceous and therefore does not stimulate the TH1 cells necessary for the formation of the delayed-type hypersensitivity response. The cytoplasmic membrane (choice B) of mycobacteria is a phospholipid bilayer that is similar to the inner membranes of all other prokaryotes and does not contribute to the specific skin test for tuberculosis. Flagella (choice C) are not present on M. tuberculosis because the organism is not motile. M. tuberculosis does not possess a periplasmic space (choice E) because it is an organism that is taxonomically related to the gram-positives. Only gram-negative bacteria possess a periplasmic space.

question: A 35-year-old man develops hemiparesis, homonymous hemianopia, and cognitive deterioration. An MRI of the brain shows widespread areas of abnormal T2 signal in the white matter. An electroencephalogram shows diffuse slowing over both cerebral hemispheres. Examination of tissue obtained on biopsy of the brain shows demyelination with abnormal giant oligodendrocytes, some of which contain eosinophilic inclusions. This patient's condition occurs most commonly in association with which of the following diseases?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The condition is progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is a rapidly progressive demyelinating disorder in which the JC virus (a polyomavirus) infects oligodendroglial cells in the brain. The eosinophilic inclusions represent accumulations of JC virus. PML occurs in about 1% of AIDS patients, and is the AIDS-defining illness in half of the patients who develop the condition. Symptoms include aphasia, hemiparesis, cortical blindness, ataxia, and conjugate gaze abnormalities. The condition can progress to quadriparesis and coma. There is no effective treatment for this disorder. Shingles and postinfectious encephalitis can follow chickenpox (choice B) but varicella is not specifically associated with demyelination. Measles (choice C) can cause an encephalitis and, in some cases, subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) may follow previous measles infection. These disorders would affect not only white matter but gray matter as well. Also, SSPE usually occurs before the age of 18. Multiple sclerosis (choice D) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease characterized by demyelination. The immunologic basis of the pathology appears to be that TH1 lymphocytes reactive against myelin stimulate macrophages to destroy the myelin. It is an example of a type IV hypersensitivity response. Women are affected twice as often as men. The disease tends to have a relapsing and remitting course and may involve visual impairment, cranial nerve signs, ataxia, nystagmus, and internuclear ophthalmoplegia. Spinal cord lesions give rise to motor and sensory difficulties of the trunk and limbs, and spasticity and loss of control of bladder function. Rabies (choice E) produces eosinophilic inclusions (Negri bodies) in the brain but these are found in the gray matter. Signs of rabies would include excessive salivation, hallucinations, and hydrophobia. Syphilis (choice F) can cause meningitis, encephalitis, and spinal cord damage, but the disease process would not be limited to the white matter. Tuberculosis (choice G) can cause a granulomatous meningitis, typically affecting the base of the brain.

question: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of redness and a yellowish discharge from her left eye over the past 2 days. She has had minimal crusting upon awakening in the morning but has not had eye pain or previous trauma. Physical examination shows diffuse conjunctival hyperemia and a mucoid discharge. The pupils are reactive to light, but there is mild photophobia of the affected eye. Gram stain of the exudate shows pleomorphic, gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following is necessary to culture the most likely causal organism on a blood agar plate?
options: A. Antibiotics to inhibit normal flora
E. Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar
explanation: The correct answer is E. The patient is suffering from conjunctivitis caused by Haemophilus, a fastidious organism requiring factors V (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) and X (hematin), which must be released from whole-blood preparations to be accessible to the organism. This can be done by gentle heating, which lyses the red blood cells, or by co-culture with Staphylococcus aureus, which is beta-hemolytic and lyses the red blood cells to provide the factors Haemophilus needs for growth. This is called the satellite phenomenon. Antibiotics (choice A) would not be necessary since, with proper culture techniques, no normal flora should be available to confuse the diagnosis of conjunctivitis. Antibiotics and antifungals are added to chocolate agar to create Thayer-Martin medium to prevent the growth of normal flora when culturing from the genital tract. Cold temperature (choice B) would not be necessary because Haemophilus grows at normal body temperature. Listeria is the genus commonly mentioned for which a cold temperature is necessary. Cholesterol (choice C) is necessary for the growth of Mycoplasma but not Haemophilus. Low oxygen tension (choice D) is necessary for the growth of the microaerophiles (such as Campylobacter, Helicobacter, and Borrelia), but is not a condition for growth of Haemophilus.

question: A 67-year-old woman in a skilled nursing facility develops flulike symptoms. Several days later, she develops a high fever dyspnea, a productive cough, and mental status changes. An x-ray of the chest shows a cavitary lesion in her left lung Examination of a sputum sample will most likely show which of the following?
options: B. A gram-positive, catalase-negative, alpha-hemolytic diplococcus
C. A gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive coccus
E. A yeast that forms pseudohyphae
explanation: The correct answer is C. This woman has developed a pulmonary abscess, as evidenced by the chest radiograph. Of the organisms listed, Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely cause of bacterial pneumonia complicated by abscess formation. Bacteria that commonly produce pneumonia that develops in the context of influenza include Staph. aureus, Haemophilus influenzae and Streptococcus pneumoniae. Of these, Staph. aureus is most destructive to lung tissue and likely to cause cavitary lesions. Staph. aureus is a gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive coccus. A gram-negative, oxidase-negative bacillus (choice A) describes Klebsiella pneumoniae. This bacterium would be a cause of pneumonia in alcoholic or diabetic patients, or in those suffering from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. A gram-positive catalase-negative alpha-hemolytic diplococcus (choice B) describes Strep. pneumoniae. This agent causes a necrotizing abscessing pneumonia with appearance similar to that of Staph. aureus, but it rarely causes cavitary lesions. A silver-staining cyst (choice D) describes Pneumocystis jiroveci. This agent is associated with atypical pneumonia in the immunocompromised or in premature infants. A yeast that forms pseudohyphae (choice E) describes Candida albicans. Candida is an opportunistic pathogen in the immunocompromised, but would not be expected to be associated with postviral pneumonia.

question: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of an itchy, vesicular rash on his face and trunk Physical examination demonstrates a mixture of lesions, with macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions. The mother says that the lesions seem to be occurring in crops. The virus that causes this boy's condition also causes which of the following disorders?
explanation: The correct answer is D. This is varicella (chickenpox), which is the primary form of infection by the herpes zoster (varicella-zoster) virus. Recurrence due to virus harbored in neurons tends to be dermatomal in distribution and is called shingles. Fever, malaise, headache, and myalgia may also be present, particularly in the prodromal phase. Tzanck smear of the base of a vesicle may demonstrate multinucleated giant cells. Immunocompromised patients can be treated with acyclovir to prevent dissemination. Chickenpox may be complicated by secondary bacterial infection, pneumonia, systemic spread (immunosuppressed patients), neurologic involvement (rare), Reye syndrome (rare), and/or hemolytic anemia (rare). Genital vesicles and ulcers (choice A) are associated with herpes simplex type 2. Infectious mononucleosis (choice B) is usually caused by Epstein-Barr virus. Orchitis (choice C) can complicate mumps infection. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (choice E) is a rare complication of measles infection.

question: An 18-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fever, chills, and sore throat. Physical examination shows marked pharyngeal hyperemia, tonsillar exudates, cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. Treatment with ampicillin is begun. Two weeks later, he returns to the physician because of a generalized maculopapular rash. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
options: D. Lateral x-ray of the neck
explanation: The correct answer is C. This patient most likely has infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The clinical features include sore throat, headache, fever, malaise, lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis and tonsillitis, hepatosplenomegaly, periorbital edema, rash, and a palatal enanthem. The diagnosis is made by heterophile antibody testing, EBV antibody titers, and lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. Treatment includes rest, fluids, and analgesics. Treatment with penicillin derivatives (ampicillin) leads to a maculopapular rash. Chest x-ray (choice A) is useful for a respiratory or cardiac process. Infectious mononucleosis cannot be diagnosed by any radiographic study. ELISA (choice B) would be a useful screening test for a variety of infections, including human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). A lateral x-ray of the neck (choice D) is useful in acute epiglottitis; it would show epiglottic swelling. The symptoms of epiglottitis include extreme sore throat, drooling, and difficulty swallowing. A rapid antigen test (choice E) is used to diagnose streptococcal pharyngitis. Streptococcal pharyngitis is characterized by fever, sore throat, tonsillar exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy. A scarlatiniform rash may follow the pharyngitis. The rash, a diffuse erythema that later desquamates, is caused by an erythrotoxin. Antibodies to the varicella virus (choice F) can be detected by immunofluorescence. The symptoms of varicella include a vesicular rash (in various stages of evolution), fever, and malaise. The treatment is bathing soaks and antipruritic topical medication. Treatment with aspirin has been associated with Reye syndrome and should therefore be avoided.

question: A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a fever, nausea, diarrhea, and a rash. Her last menstrual period began 3 days ago. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 90/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a diffuse erythematous rash with areas of desquamation over the hands and feet. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
options: A. Gram-negative, oxidase-negative, nonfermenting, nonmotile, non-H₂S-producing bacillus
explanation: The correct answer is C. This patient has toxic shock syndrome (TSS), a multisystem syndrome caused by a toxin (TSST-1) formed by certain strains of Staphylococcus aureus. TSS usually affects several organ systems (gastrointestinal, renal, hepatic, hematopoietic, musculoskeletal, pulmonary) and can result in death. TSS has historically been associated with the use of tampons in young women, but can also occur in other patient populations. Fever, hypotension, diarrhea, and diffuse rash with desquamation of the hands and feet are common symptoms. Management of shock, renal failure, and adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) are a priority if these conditions are present, in addition to appropriate antibacterial treatment. S. aureus is a gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive coccus. A gram-negative, oxidase-negative non-lactose fermenting, nonmotile, non-H₂S-producing bacillus (choice A) describes the genus Shigella, which causes dysentery, characterized by fever, abdominal cramps, and bloody diarrhea. A gram-positive anaerobic rod (choice B) describes Clostridium perfringens, which causes gas gangrene with necrosis of soft tissues, usually after a traumatic wound. It is also a cause of food poisoning. Gram-positive, catalase-positive, novobiocin-sensitive coccus (choice D) describes Staph. epidermidis, which is part of the normal skin flora but is notorious for causing infections of intravenous lines and prosthetic heart valves. A single-stranded diploid RNA virus (choice E) describes the retroviruses. Although HIV-1 can cause many diverse findings and should never be immediately ruled out, the findings in the present patient are most specific for TSS.

question: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of fever, myalgias, and cough He owns an automobile repair shop and recently cleaned his garage, which was infested with mice. He is tachypneic and must use accessory respiratory muscles to breathe. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The correct answer is C. Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome, first reported in 1993, consists of fever, myalgia, and rapid development of respiratory failure leading to death. The initial cases were mostly among Navajo Indians, however, cases have been documented in many U.S. states and in Canada. It is most common in the U.S. Four Corners states: New Mexico, Arizona, Colorado, and Utah. The causative agent is a hantavirus belonging to the family Bunyaviridae. The virus has also been called the Sin Nombre (Spanish for 'without a name') virus. Infection is thought to be through inhalation of aerosolized secretions from the common deer mouse. The disease typically begins with a nonspecific prodrome (fever, generalized myalgia, and gastrointestinal disturbances) followed 4 to 5 days later by respiratory symptoms (cough, dyspnea, and tachypnea). This progresses rapidly to an adult respiratory distress syndrome and, in many cases, death. California encephalitis (choice A) is caused by an arbovirus transmitted by infected mosquitoes. Most cases are in children younger than 10 years of age. Signs and symptoms include fever, headache, photophobia, nausea, and vomiting. Myalgias and arthralgias are typically present. Seizure activity is most frequently observed in infants and young children. Most cases are in the midwestern United States. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (choice B) is a Herpesvirus that produces a variety of infections. Primary CMV infection is usually asymptomatic in immunocompetent patients, but can cause a heterophile-negative mononucleosis syndrome. Perinatal infections can occur in utero, intrapartum, or postpartum, and can produce congenital malformations. CMV can be transmitted by leukocytes in blood transfusions. In patients with AIDS or other immunosuppressive states, CMV can produce severe disease, including retinitis, pneumonia, encephalitis, adrenalitis, and gastrointestinal tract ulcerations. Plague (choice D) is caused by Yersinia pestis. It is endemic in the desert southwest of the United States, but plague normally begins with an extremely high fever, conjunctivitis, and septicemia. If it is acquired by fleabite, then buboes (hemorrhagic lymph nodes) will be found; if it is acquired in the pneumonic form, then cough will be observed. Poliovirus (choice E) is a member of the Picornavirus family. It remains epidemic in parts of Asia and Africa even though the wild type has been eliminated from the western hemisphere. The virus affects cranial nerve nuclei and anterior horn motor neurons of the spinal cord, producing a flaccid paralysis that is usually asymmetric. Vaccine-related polio can occur with the live virus vaccine. Rabies (choice F) is a Rhabdovirus that produces encephalitis and/or myelitis. It should be considered in persons who have recently traveled outside of the United States. The most common sources of exposure are dogs, cats, skunks, foxes, raccoons (in Florida and Connecticut), wolves, and bats. The infection is acquired from the bite of a rabid animal or by inhalation. Rabies also has been reported to occur in patients after corneal transplantation. The virus spreads along peripheral nerves to the central nervous system. Symptoms include hallucinations, hydrophobia and copious salivation. Tularemia (choice G) is caused by Francisella tularensis, a gram-negative, cysteine-requiring facultative intracellular bacillus. The disease is most common in Arkansas and Missouri, and is acquired by handling, ingesting, or inhaling material from infected reservoir animals such as deer, rabbits and small rodents. It may also be transmitted by ticks from one of the reservoir animals to humans. Tularemia is generally characterized by disseminated granulomatous lesions, and would not be expected to cause acute respiratory distress syndrome.

question: A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of a headache and a high fever. He recently returned from a 2-week trip to Europe where he went diving in several natural pools. A diagnosis of meningoencephalitis localized to the base of his brain is made. A photomicrograph of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is shown. Through which of the following structures did the causal organism most likely gain access to the brain?
explanation: The correct answer is B. The rare but life-threatening meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri apparently ensues when the organism enters the body through the nasal mucosa and crosses the cribriform plate to enter the brain via the olfactory nerves. It has been speculated that changes in pressure created during diving predispose to this infection. The cavernous sinus (choice A) is the site of entry of the zygomycophyta (Rhizopus, Mucor or Absidia) into the brain in diabetic ketoacidotic patients or adults with cancer. The lacrimal bone (choice C) of the medial aspect of the orbit does not appear to be involved in amebic infection. The mouth and its associated bones, including the mandible (choice D), do not appear to be routes of infection for this organism. The nasal bones (choice E) located on the superior surface of the nose, do not appear to be a route of infection for this organism. The zygomatic bone (choice F) which forms the cheekbone, does not appear to be a route of infection for this organism.

question: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of malaise, loss of appetite, nausea, and jaundice. Laboratory studies show a serum alanine transaminase (ALT) of 3,200 U/L. Serology for hepatitis viruses is performed and shows the presence of HBsAg and HBc IgM antibody Antibody tests for HBsAb and HAV are negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these results?
options: B. A dual infection of HBV and HAV
D. Immunity to hepatitis B virus
explanation: The correct answer is A. The presence of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) along with hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM Ab), and the absence of hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb), indicate the early stages of an acute infection with hepatitis B virus (HBV). A dual infection of HBV and hepatitis A virus (HAV) (choice B) is not plausible since the IgM anti-HAV serology is negative. Chronic HBV infection (choice C) is unlikely because the patient has HBc IgM Ab, which is characteristic of an acute infection rather than a chronic infection. Immunity to HBV (choice D) is not plausible due to the presence of HBsAg and HBc IgM Ab and the lack of HBsAb. Past hepatitis A infection (choice E) would be manifested by the presence of IgG antibodies against HAV.

question: A 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a fever of 40°C (104°F) Physical examination shows conjunctival petechiae, bruising in the right antecubital fossa, and a murmur is heard on auscultation of the chest along the left fourth intercostal space. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple patchy infiltrates in both lung fields An echocardiogram shows damage to the tricuspid valve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The correct answer is A. This patient has acute infective endocarditis. The most common cause of acute bacterial endocarditis is Staphylococcus aureus. This type of endocarditis is typically acquired by illicit intravenous drug use, which can introduce skin organisms into the venous system that then attack the tricuspid valve. Staph. aureus accounts for between 60 and 90% of cases of endocarditis in intravenous drug users. Damage to the tricuspid valve is common. The endocarditis associated with congenital heart disease (choice B) typically involves left-sided valves (mitral or aortic) and is more often subacute, caused by viridans streptococci.

question: During an investigational study. a group of experimental animals is inoculated with bovine serum albumin (BSA) three times, 7 days apart. over a 3-week period. The last injection of BSA is mixed with keyhole limpet hemocyanin (KLH). Seven days after the last injection, animal sera are analyzed for the presence of antibodies to BSA and KLH by radial immunodiffusion. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be present in elevated titers?
options: B. IgG against BSA and IgM against KLH
C. IgG against BSA and KLH
D. IgG and IgM against BSA
F. IgM against BSA and IgG against KLH
explanation: The correct answer is B. Three weeks and three injections after the beginning of the experiment, the animals will have undergone a full primary immune response fo the BSA, along with isotype-switching of those antibodies from IgM to IgG. The response to KLH at 7 days after its first injection will be a primary immune response, with anti-KLH IgM predominating. IgM is always the first antibody produced in response to any antigen, and IgG is the most common secondary immune response antibody unless a mucosal surface is involved, in which case IgA might predominate in the secondary and all subsequent responses. IgG against BSA (choice A) will certainly be present in these animals due to the multiple repeated inoculations over a 3-week period, but the animals will also be making a primary immune response (IgM) to the first injection of KLH. IgG against BSA and KLH (choice C) is not correct, since 7 days after the first injection of KLH a primary immune response will just be beginning. It is not possible for the isotype switch of anti-KLH antibodies to have occurred at this time. However, IgG against BSA will be found. IgG and IgM against BSA (choice D) is a possible but incomplete answer. There should be low-level production of IgM against BSA in these animals. but since affinity maturation improves the binding strength of populations of antibodies during the burst of clonal proliferation and subsequent natural selection. it is unlikely that these antibodies will have high titers in the serum compared with those of the high-affinity IgG molecules. Furthermore, this answer does not acknowledge that a primary response against KLH would be happening in these animals at the same time. IgM against BSA (choice E) is not correct because after 3 weeks and three inoculations, the animals should have finished their primary immune response (IgM) and be well into their secondary response (IgG). IgM against BSA and IgG against KLH (choice F) is not correct and is the opposite of what would be expected. IgM is the primary immune response antibody and IgG is the secondary immune response antibody. BSA in these animals should be a secondary response (even a tertiary response) and KLH should be a primary response.

question: A 2-day-old newborn with dysmorphic facies develops a seizure. Laboratory studies of serum show glucose of 90 mg/dL, sodium of 140 mEg/L. potassium of 4.2 mEq/L, and calcium of 3.9 mg/dL. Over the next several months, the boy is admitted to the hospital twice for Candida infections and once for a viral exanthem. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The correct answer is E. DiGeorge syndrome, or velocardiofacial syndrome is due fo malformation of epithelial elements of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches, leading to thymic aplasia or severe hypoplasia and sometimes absence of the parathyroids. Clinically, the condition is classified as a selective T-cell deficiency, but varying degrees of deficiency of antibody production may also be seen. Affected infants are susceptible to fungal and viral infections, and may exhibit tetany due to severe hypocalcemia. Congenital rubella syndrome (choice A) is associated with patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, microcephaly. cataracts, and deafness. Cytomegalovirus in utero infection (choice B) is associated with hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytic purpura, and damage to the central nervous system and retina. Trisomy 13 (choice C) , or Patau syndrome, is associated with microphthalmia, microcephaly, polydactyly, cardiac defects, renal defects, umbilical hernia, and rocker-bottom feet. Trisomy 18 (choice D) , or Edwards syndrome, is associated with mental retardation, low-set ears, micrognathia. short neck. overlapping fingers, heart defects, kidney defects, limited hip abduction, and rocker-bottom feet.

question: A 60-year-old man with a history of alcoholism is brought to the emergency department after being found behind the neighborhood bar at 4 AM. in freezing weather. He is lethargic and has shaking chills. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 12/min and labored, and blood pressure is 108/62 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor and cold extremities. and diffuse rales are heard on auscultation of the chest. His sputum is blood-tinged and contains numerous gram-positive, alpha-hemolytic cocci. Treatment with penicillin is begun and his condition improves over the next few days. Which of the following immune effector mechanisms is most important in completely clearing this infection?
explanation: The correct answer is E. The patient has typical pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae - One of the most efficient mechanisms for eliminating extracellular pathogenic bacteria is by opsonization and phagocytosis by phagocytes. The IgG and IgM antibodies produced in response to the organism react with the capsular structure, stimulating the activation of the classical pathway of the complement system. This pathway produces large amounts of C3b that coat the organism, enhancing the speed and efficiency of phagocytosis. ADCC (antibody-dependent cell cytotoxic cells) (choice A) are cells that find altered self cells that have been coated with antibody, and kill them. NK cells do not destroy antibody-coated bacteria, only altered self cells that are coated with antibody. Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (choice B) destroy host cells that have antigen epitopes presented in association with class | major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. An example would be a virus-epitope from a virus-infected cell presented by class | molecules on the surface of the cell. LAK cells (choice C) are natural killer (NK) cells that have been activated by IL-2. They are considered to be superactivated NK cells. NK cells kill altered self cells such as tumor cells or virus-infected cells. NK cells (choice D) are cells of the innate immune system that destroy virus-infected cells or tumor cells. This does not involve antibody and it does not involve extracellular pathogens.

question: A 56-year-old woman is diagnosed with metastatic melanoma. Treatment is begun with an in vitro culture of peripheral leukocytes in the presence of TH1 cytokines, followed by reinfusion into the circulation. After 2 years of remission, the patient returns to the physician for a follow-up examination. A CT scan of the chest shows renewed tumor growth in both lungs. Treatment with the previous therapy is repeated. however, it has no effect on tumor size. Which of the following has most likely been lost from the surface of the tumor cells?
options: E. HLA DP, DQ, and DR
explanation: The correct answer is D. Tumor-specific killer cells could describe either cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) or natural killer (NK) cells. Of the two, only the CTLs would lose their activity if a surface molecule was lost, namely major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class | antigens. NK cells would actually be stimulated by the loss of MHC class |, so they could not be the cells to which the question refers. Tumor antigens may be present in the groove of the class | MHC molecule of transformed cells. These are presented to cytotoxic CD8+ T cells, which recognize the MHC class I/peptide complex on the cell surface and kill the tumor cell. Loss of this molecule would therefore prevent the tumor cell from being killed. The MHC class | molecule is described as a two-chain structure, with one of the chains (beta-2 microglobulin) holding the other chain (alpha chain) in its needed configuration on the cell surface. In the human, class | MHC molecules are HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C. The T-cell signal transduction molecule, or CD3 (choice A) is a marker on all T cells. It is not involved in antigen recognition. This molecule would not be on the surface of tumor cells unless the malignant cells themselves were T lymphocytes. The co-receptor for MHC class II molecules, or CD4 (choice B) , would not be on the surface of this tumor cell. but it would be on the surface of a helper T lymphocyte. The co-receptor for MHC class | molecules, or CD8 (choice C) would not be on the surface of this tumor cell, but it would be on the surface of a cytotoxic T lymphocyte. HLA DP, DQ, and DR are the MHC class II molecules in humans (choice E). These are not involved in killing of tumor cell targets. They present peptide fragments (derived from intracellular killing of extracellular organisms by macrophages) to CD4+ (helper) T lymphocytes.

question: During an investigational study, blood from a healthy volunteer is analyzed by flow cytometry. The relative proportion of all cells bearing surface immunoglobulin in the circulation is evaluated. Which of the following cell surface markers should be used to identify the B cells in this blood sample?
explanation: The correct answer is D. The best markers for identification of B cells are CD19, CD20, and CD21. The CD21 molecule is a receptor for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The CD3 marker (choice A) is present on all T cells. This is the marker that is used to identify total T cell count in a blood sample. CD3 is the signal transduction molecule on T cells. The CD4 marker (choice B) is used to identify T-helper (TH) cells. These are the cells that recognize exogenous peptides presented on major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II molecules by macrophages. CD4+ TH cells are also involved in cell-mediated delayed hypersensitivity, production of cytokines for stimulation of antibody production by B cells, and stimulation of macrophages. The CD8 marker (choice C) is used to identify cytotoxic T cells. These are the cells that recognize viral epitopes attached to the MHC class | molecules of a virus-infected cell. The CD56 marker (choice E) is used to identify natural Killer (NK) cells. These cells are important in innate host defense, specializing in killing virus-infected cells and tumor cells by secreting granzymes and perforins. IgM (choice F) is present on mature naive B lymphocytes along with IgD, but would not be present on any memory cells. Therefore, to receive an idea of the proportion of all immunoglobulin-bearing cells in the circulation, IgM determination would not be the best choice.

question: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe skin lesions as a result of exposure to poison ivy. He says that he has experienced this numerous times in the past. One year later, he participates in a clinical immunologic study. A flow cytometric measurement of T cells shows values within the normal range. An increased serum concentration of which of the following cytokines is most likely to decrease the likelihood of a contact dermatitis in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is E. IL-10 is produced by T-helper 2 (TH2) cells and inhibits T-helper 1 (TH1) cells. Since the cytokines from TH1 cells stimulate cell-mediated immunity and delayed hypersensitivity, an increased level of IL-10 would decrease the likelihood of contact dermatitis, which is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. Other cytokines from TH2 cells stimulate B cells to produce antibody. Gamma-interferon (choice A) from TH1 cells inhibits TH2 cells. It also activates natural killer (NK) cells and activates macrophages. This cytokine would make a contact dermatitis worse, not better. IL-2 (choice B) stimulates the TH1 subset, CD8 T cytotoxic cells, and activates NK cells. It causes cloning of the cells of cell-mediated immunity, and thus would make a contact dermatitis worse. IL-5 (choice C) is secreted by TH2 cells and promotes B-cell proliferation, IgA synthesis in the submucosa, and eosinophil production in the bone marrow. It does not have a direct effect on TH1 function. IL-8 (choice D) is produced by macrophages and is chemotactic for neutrophils. This cytokine is most important in stimulating an inflammatory reaction and in attraction of neutrophils to the site.

question: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a large, painful boil on his left knee. He has a history of repeated infections with Candida, Staphylococcus. and Klebsiella since the age of 14 months. Flow cytometry of peripheral blood leukocytes reveals a decreased neutrophil oxidative index. Cultures of the fluid from the boil grow Staphylococcus aureus . Which of the following intracellular defense mechanisms is most likely absent in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is E. This child has chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which is a genetic defect in one or more of the subunits of NADPH oxidase. Activation of this membrane-bound oxidase is the critical first step in the generation of toxic oxygen radicals within the phagolysosome. One of the products of this reaction, hydrogen peroxide, serves as the substrate for the second most important killing mechanism: myeloperoxidase acting to produce toxic halide radicals. Patients with CGD are prone to persistent infections with catalase-positive bacteria and fungi, because these organisms destroy the hydrogen peroxide that they produce metabolically, so neither of the oxygen-dependent mechanisms can function in intracellular killing during these infections. Defensins (choice A) are part of the oxygen-independent mechanisms of phagocytic killing. These make up the largest number of different antimicrobial mechanisms used by phagocytes, but there are no known disease states that result from such deficiencies. Hydrogen peroxide (choice B) is the substrate for the myeloperoxidase enzyme system. It is produced inside the cell by the activation of NADPH oxidase, but it is also produced by aerobic microorganisms as a byproduct of their metabolism. Hypochlorite (choice C) is a toxic product arising in the myeloperoxidase arm of the intracellular killing pathway when myeloperoxidase acts on hydrogen peroxide to produce toxic halide radicals. Myeloperoxidase (choice D) is an enzyme present in neutrophils that acts on hydrogen peroxide to produce toxic halide radicals such as hypochlorite.

question: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an oral ulcer. She also has fatigue, myalgia. and joint pain. Laboratory studies show leukopenia and a high titer of antinuclear antibody. Urinalysis shows proteinuria. Serum analysis by an indirect fluorescent antibody test shows a speckled staining pattern due to anti-Sm. Which of the following is most likely to additionally be present in this patient?
options: B. Antibodies to the glomerular basement membrane
D. complement-mediated lysis of blood vessels in the face
explanation: The correct answer is D. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a prototype connective-tissue disease. The diagnosis requires that four out of 11 possible criteria be met: malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, arthritis, serositis, renal disorder, neurologic disorder, hematologic disorder, immunologic disorder, and antinuclear antibody (ANA). This patient also has anti-Sm, which is pathognomonic for SLE but is found in only 30% of the affected patients. Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are present in 95 to 100% of SLE cases; anti-double stranded DNA is found in 70% of cases. The vasculitis and rash of SLE are associated with immune complex deposition in the small-diameter blood vessels, followed by complement-mediated lysis. Antibodies to centromeres (choice A) are found in 90% of patients with limited scleroderma or CREST (calcinosis, Raynaud syndrome, esophageal dysmotility, scleroderma, telangiectasias). They would be found in less than 5% of patients with SLE. Antibodies to the glomerular basement membrane (choice B) are found in Goodpasture syndrome. This causes the linear disposition of immunoglobulin, and often C3, along the glomerular basement membrane. It results in glomerulonephritis, pulmonary hemorrhage, and occasionally idiopathic pulmonary hemosiderosis. Antibodies to SS-A ribonucleoproteins (choice C) are found in Sjogren syndrome, which is characterized by keratoconjunctivitis sicca and xerostomia. The secondary form of this disease may be associated with rheumatoid arthritis, SLE, polymyositis, scleroderma vasculitis, mixed connective tissue disease, or thyroiditis. Antibodies to core proteins of small nuclear ribonucleoprotein particles (Smith antigen) are found in 20 to 30% of SLE patients, and antibodies against SS-A ribonucleoproteins are found in 30 to 50% of patients with SLE. Epstein-Barr virus infection (choice E) has been suggested as being linked to the development of chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS). This condition, which is of unknown etiology, involves severe mental and physical exhaustion that is not relieved by rest and may be worsened by even trivial exertion. The symptoms must be present for at least 6 months and must be idiopathic. Other signs that are not included in all diagnostic criteria may be found, including muscle weakness, cognitive dysfunction, hypersensitivity, orthostatic intolerance, digestive disturbances, depression, poor immune response, and cardiac and respiratory problems.

question: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of relapsing and remitting neurologic symptoms including paresthesias visual symptoms, and mild motor symptoms for the past 3 years. An MRI of the brain is shown. An increased concentration of which the following is most likely to be important in the pathogenesis of the lesions shown in the MRI?
explanation: The correct answer is C. The symptoms and MRI shown are typical of multiple sclerosis, which is a demyelinating disease of autoimmune pathology. Multiple sclerosis is characterized microscopically by plaques with a central loss of oligodendrocytes and myelin but with relative preservation of axons. The plagues are surrounded by a peripheral rim of lymphocytes and increased astrocytes. The disease appears to be initiated by CD4+ TH1 lymphocytes that react against self myelin antigens and secrete cytokines such as interferon-gamma to activate macrophages. The activated macrophages are responsible for the demyelination. The disease is therefore classified as an example of a type IV hypersensitivity disease. Immunoglobulin G (choice A) may be present near multiple sclerosis plagues but its role in demyelination is unclear. IgG may be involved in type II and type III hypersensitivities, where antibodies bind to either fixed (type II) or circulating (type III) antigens to activate complement and start inflammation. In myasthenia gravis, for example, antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor in the neuromuscular junction cause abnormal function of the motor end plate and eventual inflammatory destruction of the area. Immunoglobulin M (choice B) could be found near multiple sclerosis plagues but it is not believed to play a role in the disease. IgM production is a cause of some type III hypersensitivities, such as rheumatoid arthritis, where circulating complexes of IgM against one’s own IgG (rheumatoid factor) begin to block the small-diameter blood vessels and activate complement, ultimately resulting in inflammatory damage. Interleukin-10 (choice D) is a product of TH2 lymphocytes that inhibits the cell-mediated immune response. It is unlikely to be produced near the location of an active TH1 response such as a multiple sclerosis plague. Interleukin-10 could be produced in type II or type III hypersensitivities when antibody production is stimulated, but is not likely to be produced in a type IV hypersensitivity, which is due to activation of TH1 cells. Transforming growth factor-beta (choice E) is a product of TH2 cells that encourages B-cell isotype-switching, and is not likely to be produced near the plagues of multiple sclerosis. This cytokine could potentially be produced in cases of hypersensitivities involving antibodies (types I, II, and III) but would not be present in cell-mediated hypersensitivities such as this one.

question: During infection with HIV, which of the following best describes how CDE+ cells that are generated against the virus distinguish between an infected antigen-presenting cell (APC) and a normal one?
options: A. Infected APCs have viral peptides in class | MHC molecules
B. Infected APCs have viral peptides in class || MHC molecules
C. Normal APCs have normal peptides in class || MHC molecules
D. Normal APCs have viral peptides in class | MHC molecules
E. Normal APCs have viral peptides in class || MHC molecules
explanation: The correct answer is A. Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ cells) recognize the target they intend to kill by binding their T-cell receptor to the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class | molecule of the target cell. Cells infected with intracellular pathogens will have peptides in the groove of MHC class | on their surface, reflecting the fact that abnormal proteins are being produced internally. If an antigen-presenting cell (APC) has ingested a cell that has died of virus infection, the viral peptides will be presented in the context of the class II MHC molecule, and this will serve as the stimulatory signal for T-helper (TH) cells to begin producing stimulatory cytokines. Thus, APCs will bear viral peptides in the context of class II MHC, whereas the infected target cell can be identified by finding viral peptides in the groove of the class | MHC. If there were not separate mechanisms for MHC molecules involved in cell-cell cooperation versus cytotoxic killing, CD8+ cells would kill the APCs necessary for 'turning on' the TH response. Infected APCs having viral peptides in class II MHC molecules (choice B) is not correct. If APCs were both infected and acting as antigen presenters, they could have viral peptides in the context of both classes of MHC molecules, but the cytotoxic T lymphocyte (CTL) identifies its target via class I/peptide combinations. Normal APCs having normal peptides in class II MHC molecules (choice C) is not correct. Uninfected APCs will have the groove of class II MHC molecules loaded with peptides from materials they have digested previously. Materials presented in the class II groove are not targets for cytotoxic killing by T cells. Normal APCs having viral peptides in class | MHC molecules (choice D) is not correct. Only infected APCs will have viral peptides in the class | MHC groove. Normal APCs having viral peptides in class II MHC molecules (choice E) is true, but this will not serve as the signal for CTL targeting. Any uninfected APC that has digested a virus-infected cell may express viral peptides in the class II molecule, but this serves as the stimulus for TH cells, not CTLs, to become activated.

question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a severe reaction to a bee sting. His right hand and arm are very swollen and itchy. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
explanation: The correct answer is C. This child is suffering from the results of mast cell degranulation in response to histamine. Histamine, heparin, and eosinophil-chemotactic factor-A are found in preformed mast cell granules. These granules are released in response to physical injury, heat, cold, type | hypersensitivity reactions, C3a and C5a anaphylatoxins, proteins released from leukocytes, substance P, and melitin found in bee venom. In the present case, the direct degranulation of mast cells by melitin and subsequent release of histamine is the most direct cause of the boy's symptoms. Histamine is the principal mediator of the immediate transient phase of increased permeability of venules in acute inflammation, an effect mediated by H1 histamine receptors. Anaphylatoxins (choice A), another name for the complement components C3a and C5a, are substances produced in areas of acute inflammation that cause mast cell degranulation. Although they would contribute to these symptoms, they are not likely to be the most direct cause in the present case. Eosinophil chemotactic factor-A (choice B) is actually multiple substances that are preformed in mast cells and would be released in the area of this bee sting. They are not the most direct cause of this boy's symptoms. The attraction of eosinophils into areas of mast cell degranulation is important in cases in which the pathogen is a helminth, since eosinophils contain major basic protein, which is damaging to the cuticles of most helminths. Interleukin (IL)-4 (choice D) is produced by TH2 cells and is involved in causing isotype-switching in B lymphocytes to the production of IgE. Although IgE is an important cause of mast cell degranulation in type | hypersensitivities, it would be produced in the sensitization phase of a type | hypersensitivity, not in the actual symptomatic phase. IL-8 (choice E) is a product of macrophages and can cause mast cell degranulation, but it is not likely to be the most direct cause in this case.

question: A 28-year-old man is brought into court for nonpayment of child support. His ex-wife states that he is the father of her child, although he denies it. The court orders genetic tests, including one for genetic immunoglobulin identification of the mother, father, and child. Which of the following immunoglobulin markers is likely to be most useful in this paternity case?
explanation: The correct answer is A. Allotypes are genetically inherited markers (amino acid sequence differences) that occur within the constant domains of both heavy and light chains of immunoglobulin molecules. They reflect the paternity of the individual, and are similar in concept to the ABO blood group alloantigens: they do not affect the function of the cell that bears them, but simply reflect patterns of inheritance. These are distinctive markers that, when present, can be helpful in paternity cases. If this man had these markers and the child had the same markers, then this would be presumptive evidence that the man is the child's biologic father. Other genetic tests would also performed in this case, because if the mother and father happened to have the same markers, then the findings could be nonconclusive. Idiotypes (choice B) are the antigen-recognition portions of the immunoglobulin molecule that are unique for specific antigens to which we have been exposed. Since every antibody molecule has a different idiotype (antigenic specificity) unless it has been made by a clone of cells, these would not be useful in determining paternity. The isotypes (choice C) are the five major classes of immunoglobulin: IgG, IgA, IgM, IgD, and IgE. They are distinct from one another based on amino acid sequences in the constant domains of both heavy and light chains. Isotypes would not be helpful for a paternity case. Subisotypes (choice D) are subclasses within the isotypes of antibodies. IgG has four subisotypes and IgA has two subisotypes. They are distinguished on the basis of amino acid sequences in the constant domains of heavy chains and would not be useful in determining paternity.

question: A 54-year-old Hispanic man comes to the physician because of skin lesions. Physical examination shows several disfiguring lesions on the face. and there is loss of cutaneous sensation for light touch, pain, and temperature. Histologic examination of the lesions shows multinucleated giant cells. Which of the following is most likely to be found on the surface of these cells?
explanation: The correct answer is D. The disease in question is leprosy, or Hansen disease. Mycobacterium leprae has a predilection for the skin and cutaneous nerves, thereby producing the symptoms of depigmentation and anesthetic cutaneous lesions. This loss of peripheral nerve function leads to many of the disfiguring features of the disease: because the patients do not have normal pain sensation, they sustain repeated injuries. In addition, the organism attacks cartilage and causes granuloma formation in the skin, leading to some of the facial damage. The multinucleated giant cells that form in leprosy are modified macrophages or epithelioid cells. They possess CD14, the endotoxin receptor on their cell surface as well as CD16, the Fc receptor for the Fc tail of immunoglobulin G. CD3 (choice A) is the signal transduction complex molecule in T lymphocytes. Although T cells would be found in the granulomatous lesions of tuberculoid leprosy, these are not the cells that become multinucleated giant cells in these areas. CD4 (choice B) is the specific marker on the surface of T-helper lymphocytes. It would not be found on the multinucleated giant cells found in leprosy. CD8 (choice C) is the specific marker on the surface of cytotoxic T lymphocytes. These are not the cells that fuse together in the lesions of leprosy. CD20 (choice E) is part of the signal transduction complex in B lymphocytes. It would not be found on the surface of modified macrophages. CD56 (choice F) is one of two markers used to identify natural killer (NK) cells in tissues. The other marker on NK cells is CD16, the Fc receptor, by which NK cells carry out antibody-dependent, cell-mediated cytotoxicity. NK cells do not fuse together to form multinucleated giant cells in leprosy.

question: A newborn who is born at 39 weeks' gestation is delivered by a woman whose family has a history of birth defects. Chromosomal analysis of fetal cells fails to show any abnormalities. Immediately at birth, cells are extracted from the umbilical cord and sent for flow cytometric analysis. The analysis shows a population of cells that are both CD4+ and CD8+. These cells are most likely to be which of the following?
explanation: The correct answer is C. CD4 and CD8 are both markers for T cells, and mature T cells express one or the other but not both. However, some of the immature T cells in the thymus (which can 'leak' into the baby's blood in small numbers) coexpress these markers before the cells have 'committed' to being either helper T (TH) or cytotoxic T cells. In adults, significant numbers of cells coexpressing CD4 and CD8 usually implies the existence of a non-Hodgkin lymphoma with a cell population similar to immature T cells. Normally, T-cell precursors entering the thymus are double-positive for CD4 and CD8. During thymic selection, cells that recognize major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II become CD4-positive only and differentiate into TH lymphocytes, whereas cells that recognize MHC class | become CD8-positive only and differentiate into cytotoxic T lymphocytes. Helper T cells (choice A) are CD4+ and CD8-. Suppressor T cells (choice E) are CD4- and CD8+. Immature B cells (choice B) and plasma cells (choice D) are both CD4- and CD8-, since these are T-cell markers.

question: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a sore throat, cough, and nasal congestion. His mother says that he has suffered from recurrent bacterial infections since he was 6 months old. Laboratory and genetic studies show that this patient has an inherited defect in one of the genes encoding a component of NADPH oxidase. A defect of which of the following processes is most likely responsible for the deficient leukocyte defense against microbes in this patient?
options: E. Transfer of lysosomal enzymes to phagosomes
explanation: The correct answer is C. Phagocytosis is followed by rapid activation of oxygen-dependent enzymatic reactions referred to as the oxidative burst, which leads to generation of reactive oxygen radicals capable of killing bacteria. NADPH oxidase plays a fundamental role in the oxidative burst. NADPH oxidase is a multiprotein complex that oxidizes NADPH, producing superoxide anions (·O2−) from molecular oxygen. Superoxide anions then convert to H2O2 by spontaneous dismutation. Hydrogen peroxide serves as the substrate for myeloperoxidase, which then acts to produce toxic halide radicals. This child has chronic granulomatous disease, a group of congenital disorders characterized by defective bacterial killing and chronic predisposition to infections with catalase-positive microbes. Patients with CGD are prone to persistent infections with catalase-positive bacteria and fungi, because these organisms destroy the hydrogen peroxide that they produce metabolically, so neither of the oxygen-dependent mechanisms can function in intracellular killing during these infections. Other conditions due to defective leukocyte functions include genetic deficiencies in leukocyte adhesion molecules (leukocyte adhesion deficiencies 1 and 2; LAD1 and LAD2), which impair leukocyte adhesion and transmigration (choice A), leading to recurrent infections and defective wound healing. LAD1 is due to genetic alterations in the beta chain of the integrin. LAD2 is due to absence of sialyl-Lewis X, a carbohydrate that binds selectins expressed on activated endothelium. Chemotaxis (choice B) is impaired in a number of acquired conditions, including diabetes mellitus, malignancy, thermal injury, and sepsis. Myeloperoxidase (MPO) deficiency is a genetic condition characterized by absence of MPO and deficient production of HOCI (choice D). Myeloperoxidase converts H2O2 to HOCI in the presence of Cl−. HOCI is one of the most powerful bactericidal agents, killing bacteria by halogenation and oxidation of macromolecules. Patients with MPO deficiency tend not to be symptomatic unless they have a simultaneous inability to generate NADPH oxidase. Chediak-Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by a deficiency in the transfer of lysosomal enzymes into phagosomes (choice E). This defect also affects melanocytes, nerve cells, and platelets, resulting in a peculiar constellation of clinical features, i.e., susceptibility to infections, albinism, nerve deficits, and a bleeding diathesis.

question: A 56-year-old homeless man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious on the street. One hour after arrival, he dies despite appropriate lifesaving measures. An autopsy shows small, scattered nodules within the apex of the right lung. Histologic examination shows these nodules to be composed of collections of large epithelioid macrophages and multinucleated giant cells, surrounded by lymphocytes and fibroblasts. Caseating necrosis is seen in some of these lesions. and acid-fast bacilli are seen with appropriate staining. Which of the following mediators is most likely responsible for the development of epithelioid macrophages and multinucleated giant cells in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The patient had tuberculosis, and the lesions described here are granulomas, more specifically, they are caseating granulomas due to mycobacterial infection. Granulomatous inflammation is a specialized, immune-mediated form of chronic inflammation resulting from complex interactions between the cells involved in cell-mediated immunity, including TH1 lymphocytes and macrophages. The ultimate effect is the development of activated macrophages, which acquire an epithelial-like appearance (epithelioid macrophages) and may fuse to form multinucleated giant cells. This process begins with the uptake of foreign antigens by macrophages, which process and present them to helper T lymphocytes. T lymphocytes activate macrophages through interferon (IFN)-gamma and they become epithelioid and multinucleated giant cells. Epithelioid macrophages secrete interleukin-1 (choice B) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha (choice E), which increase leukocyte recruitment locally and mediate the systemic acute-phase responses (e.g., fever, malaise). Macrophages release a large number of inflammatory mediators that are responsible for tissue damage, necrosis of parenchymal cells, and subsequent reparative fibrosis. However, the question asks which mediator causes the production of epithelioid macrophages, not which cytokines epithelioid macrophages produce. Interleukin-2 (choice C) is a product of TH cells, which stimulate cell proliferation. Macrophages are end-cells that are incapable of proliferation, thus they would not be affected by IL-2 production. Macrophages also produce nitric oxide (NO) (choice D), which plays an important role in microbial killing but may also result in tissue damage through generation of NO-related free radicals. Again, the question asks which mediator causes the production of epithelioid macrophages, not which products epithelioid macrophages produce.

question: A 24-year-old man is found to be HIV-positive after a sexual encounter with a prostitute. He states that he did not have any symptoms during the period immediately after the encounter. During the asymptomatic phase of this infection, the virus is found in association with which of the following?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Follicular dendritic cells in the germinal centers of lymph nodes are important reservoirs of HIV. Although some follicular dendritic cells are infected with HIV, most viral particles are found on the surface of their dendritic processes. Follicular dendritic cells have receptors to the Fc portion of immunoglobulins that serve to trap HIV virions coated with anti-HIV antibodies. These coated HIV particles retain the ability to infect CD4+ T cells as they traverse the dendritic cells. B lymphocytes (choice A) have a surface marker (CD21 protein, a complement receptor) to which an Epstein-Barr envelope glycoprotein can bind. The virus associates with the host DNA, producing a latent infection. These cells may undergo polyclonal activation and proliferation, resulting in lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 primarily affects the mouth and lips, causing 'cold sores'. It resides in the trigeminal ganglion and remains latent until reactivated. HSV type 2 primarily infects the genitals. Both types can infect the ganglion cells (choice C) in the CNS, causing a fatal encephalitis. Oligodendrocytes (choice D) are centrally affected by two viruses: JC virus (a polyomavirus) and measles virus. JC virus causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). Measles virus produces a persistent, nonproductive infection of the CNS, leading to subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE). Peripheral nerves (choice E) are affected by HIV virus in the AIDS-associated distal sensory polyneuropathy. This disease is characterized by subacute onset of proximal muscle weakness, sometimes with pain, and elevated levels of creatine kinase. The muscles and nerves are infiltrated with mononuclear cells, including HIV-positive macrophages.

question: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of a pruritic, linear, vesicular rash on her leg. The rash developed 2 days after she returned from a hiking trip. She says that it began as a swollen. erythematous streak that developed into extremely itchy blisters and that she has experienced similar episodes in the past. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the development of this rash in this patient?
options: A. Antigen-antibody complexes formed in the circulation and deposited in the tissue
B. Cytotoxic antibodies against cell surface antigens
D. Release of histamine from mast cells
E. Release of interferon-gamma from activated TH1 cells
explanation: The correct answer is E. This woman most likely has been exposed to poison ivy, which caused a contact, type IV cell-mediated sensitivity response to urishiol, an oil found in poison ivy. Contact with this oil leads to a reaction that appears as a linear, streak-like rash in sensitized individuals. Redness, swelling, and pruritic blisters occur at the sites of contact. Sensitivity usually develops after the first contact with poison ivy, and the reaction described typically occurs after subsequent exposures. Antigenic activation of TH1 lymphocytes causes the production of interferon-gamma, which stimulates macrophages and cytotoxic T lymphocytes to destroy the oil-coated cells. This reaction does not require the formation of antibodies. Antigen-antibody complexes formed in the circulation and deposited in the tissue (choice A) underlie type III hypersensitivity reactions. Diseases mediated by this type of hypersensitivity include systemic lupus erythematosus and poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. Cytotoxic antibodies against cell surface antigens (choice B) produce type II hypersensitivity reactions. Diseases mediated by this type of hypersensitivity include autoimmune hemolytic anemia, pemphigoid, pemphigus, and Goodpasture disease. IgE antibody-mediated basophil degranulation (choice C) and the release of histamine from mast cells (choice D) are the mechanisms responsible for type | immediate hypersensitivity reactions. IgE antibodies are formed in response to exposure to a specific antigen. Re-exposure to that antigen results in the cross-linking of the IgE molecules on the surface of mast cells and basophils, and subsequent degranulation to release mediators that cause the classic manifestations of type | hypersensitivity reactions. Examples are hives, hay fever, and anaphylactic reactions.

question: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent infections. He has a history of infections with Streptococcus pneumoniae , Klebsiella pneumoniae , and Pseudomonas aeruginosa that have occurred over the past 6 months. Laboratory studies show total immunoglobulin levels greater than 900 mg/dL and decreased C3 levels. To which of the following does this patient have an increased susceptibility?
explanation: The correct answer is D. Individuals with C3 deficiency have an increased susceptibility to immune complex diseases (type III hypersensitivity). The most important functions of C3 are removing immune complexes from the bloodstream and enhancing opsonization. Type III hypersensitivity reactions result from immune complexes of self or foreign antigens bound to an antibody; these will activate complement, leading to tissue damage. Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions include rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. Human immunodeficiency virus-1 (choice A), which is the cause of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), is an intracellular pathogen that depends on the activation of TH1 cells and their cytokines for a protective immune response. A patient with C3 deficiency would not be expected to be any more susceptible to an intracellular pathogen such as this one than the population at large would be. Measles (choice B) is caused by rubeola virus, which is an intracellular pathogen and would not be affected by deficiencies in complement. Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare (choice C) is an intracellular bacterium that infects phagocytic cells. It is controlled by a cell-mediated response, not a complement-mediated response. Type IV hypersensitivity (choice E) is a disease that depends on the action of TH1 cells, macrophages, and cytotoxic T lymphocytes. It does not depend on the presence of antibody and complement.

question: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a sore and inflamed left foot after stepping on a nail. During the early stages of infection, leukocytes leave the circulation to enter the damaged tissues following a concentration gradient. Which of the following molecules are most important in this process?
options: B. IL-1 and tumor necrosis factor
explanation: The correct answer is A. The most important chemotactic factors for neutrophils are the complement factor C5a and the interleukin IL-8. The cytokines IL-1 and TNF (choice B) are products of activated macrophages and endothelial cells, among others. They have multiple, often similar actions, including stimulation of production of many acute-phase reactants, stimulations of fibroblasts, and stimulation of endothelial expression of adhesion molecules. Leukotrienes LTC4 and LTD4 (choice C) cause increased vascular permeability. Prostaglandins PGI2 and PGD2 (choice D) mediate vasodilation and pain. Thromboxane and Platelet activating factor (choice E) promote vasoconstriction and platelet aggregation.

question: An 18-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a severe headache and a high fever. The patient is incoherent. Physical examination shows nuchal rigidity. Examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows gram-negative diplococci. A review of the patient's records shows that he has had five previous episodes of infection with this pathogen, the earliest being at age 6 years. Which of the following is most likely impaired in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is B. A wide variety of defects related to complement can occur and can produce immunodeficiency. The pattern of recurrent Neisseria (gram-negative diplococcus) infections described here is typical of deficiency of complement factors C6, C7, or C8. Other complement deficiencies produce the following patterns: Deficiency of C1q produces a combined immunodeficiency with a systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)-like syndrome. Deficiency of C1rs, C1s, C4, or C2 produces an SLE-like syndrome and glomerulonephritis. Deficiencies of C3 or C3b produce a tendency to pyogenic infections. No disease has yet been associated with C9 deficiency. B-cell deficiencies (choice A) occur in a number of conditions and tend, in general, to be associated with an increased susceptibility to extracellular organisms. Eosinophil deficiency (choice C) is not a usual cause of immunodeficiency, but it would impair the normal protective response against parasites. Neutrophil abnormalities (choice D) are associated with increased susceptibility to extracellular microorganisms.
