T-cell deficiencies (choice E) may present as severe combined immunodeficiencies or with infections with opportunistic organisms such as Candida, Pneumocystis, or Cytomegalovirus.

question: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of headaches, nausea. and vomiting for the past week. He has a history of dilated cardiomyopathy and underwent a heart transplant 1 year ago. An MRI scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is most likely deficient in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is E. This man, immunosuppressed to prevent rejection of his transplanted heart, has developed cerebral toxoplasmosis as evidenced by the multiple ring-enhancing lesions seen on MRI. This is a common occurrence in the immunocompromised, since Toxoplasma gondii is so common worldwide. It is estimated that up to 70% of the population of the United States is seropositive, so reactivation of cysts held in latency by a normal immune response becomes commonplace as the immune response declines. Toxoplasma is an intracellular protozoan parasite in the human. Cats act as the definitive host of the parasite and shed infectious forms in their feces. Intracellular pathogens are best controlled by cell-mediated immune responses. These responses are orchestrated by T helper-1 (TH1) cells. The effector mechanisms include cytotoxic T lymphocytes, natural killer cells, macrophages and cells capable of mounting antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC). Complement (choice A) is a set of serum proteins that act to opsonize or lyse microbes in a cascading fashion to culminate in the production of a membrane attack complex that will lyse whatever particle has started the cascade. Complement acts primarily against extracellular agents, as it is not active against intracellular microbes. Immunoglobulin A (choice B) is the immunoglobulin found on the mucosal surfaces. Although Toxoplasma organisms are ingested across a mucosal surface, within the human, they exist as intracellular cysts. Intracellular organisms are not affected by the presence of IgA. IgE (choice C) is an immunoglobulin that can mediate ADCC against parasites, but it is elicited against helminth parasites and not intracellular protozoa such as Toxoplasma. IgG (choice D) is the most abundant antibody in the serum, but antibodies do not play a role in protection against intracellular organisms. TH2 cells (choice F) are important in humoral immunity, but do not usually play important roles against intracellular pathogens.

question: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a skin abscess. Cultures of the discharge from the abscess grow Staphylococcus aureus . The patient's mother says that over the past year, the girl has had several similar abscesses as well as two episodes of aspergillosis. Which of the following best explains this patient's repeated infections?
explanation: The correct answer is B. A history of recurrent infection with Staphylococcus aureus and Aspergillus sp. suggests a diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), which is caused by a deficiency of NADPH oxidase inside phagocytic cells. In the absence of NADPH oxidase, phagocytes cannot generate toxic oxygen metabolites in the phagolysosome, and patients become susceptible to catalase-positive infections, particularly those caused by S aureus, Aspergillus sp., Nocardia, Salmonella, and Candida. The reason these patients have difficulties with catalase-positive microbes is that catalase production will destroy any hydrogen peroxide created during the metabolism of aerobic bacteria. Hydrogen peroxide is the substrate for myeloperoxidase (the second oxygen-dependent intracellular killing mechanism). Catalase-mediated destruction of hydrogen peroxide in a CGD patient will therefore eliminate the function of both oxygen-dependent mechanisms. In about 2/3 of patients the inheritance is X-linked and so the disease usually affects males, but the remainder of cases are autosomal recessive and can occur in females. Defective chemotactic responses (choice A) are seen in diseases such as alcoholism and diabetes mellitus. Defective chemotaxis would lead to increased susceptibility to a broad range of pathogens, and not just the catalase-positive ones listed in this case. Deficiency of C5 (choice C), a complement component, would make patients prone to infection by gram-negative bacteria, especially Neisseria species. IgA deficiency (choice D) represents the most common primary immunodeficiency and would present with an increased predisposition to autoimmune diseases, infections, and atopy. Thymic hypoplasia (choice E) is caused by defective development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches, leading to decreased T-cell levels and making patients more prone to viral and fungal infections. Patients may also exhibit hypocalcemia and other signs of parathyroid insufficiency.

question: A 39-year-old man develops scrotal inflammation, itching, localized scrotal swelling, and tenderness of his inguinal lymph nodes 4 months after returning from a trip to Africa. A blood smear is positive for microfilariae. Which of the following immune mechanisms does the body use against the most likely causal organism?
options: A. Antibodies binding to cells or tissues and causing death of the cells or tissues
B. Antibodies binding to cells or tissues and changing the function of the tissue
C. IgE-mediated degranulation of mast cells and basophils
D. Immune complex deposition in tissues
E. T cell-mediated activation of macrophages
explanation: The correct answer is C. This patient is infected with a filarial parasite such as Wuchereria or Brugia. Filarial parasites have a complex life cycle, beginning with transmission by mosquitoes or other arthropods. The adult worms elicit an inflammatory reaction in the lymphatics, eventually leading to lymphatic obstruction and edema. Microfilariae produced by the adults circulate in the bloodstream until they are ingested by the arthropod vector and develop over 1 to 2 weeks into new infective larvae. The body reacts to tissue parasites, such as filarial worms, by coating them with a thin layer of IgE molecules, which triggers eosinophil-mediated cytotoxicity and the release of vasoactive and spasmogenic substances from mast cells and basophils (local anaphylaxis, a form of type | hypersensitivity). Antibodies binding to cells or tissues and causing death of the cells or tissues (choice A) is a cytotoxic type II hypersensitivity reaction. Transfusion reactions due to mismatched blood are an example. Antibodies binding to cells or tissues and changing the function of the tissue (choice B) is a type II non-cytotoxic hypersensitivity reaction. Graves disease and myasthenia gravis are examples. Immune complex deposition in tissues (choice D) is an example of a type III hypersensitivity. It usually takes the form of vasculitis secondary to deposition of circulating antigen-antibody complexes. The Arthus reaction is a specific variant of these reactions in which local vasculitis leads to tissue injury and necrosis, often in the skin. T cell activation of macrophages (choice E) is a delayed type IV hypersensitivity reaction. The reaction is common with facultative intracellular pathogens such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Listeria monocytogenes.

question: A 24-year-old woman who is a veterinary student comes to the physician because of itching. burning eyes, and sinus irritation. An intradermal test for response to allergens is performed and shows moderate hypersensitivity to cat and dog dander. The physician explains that desensitization therapy can potentially help control these symptoms. In this type of therapy. which of the following will most likely prevent the allergen from reacting with a specific IgE molecule present on mast cell membranes?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Blocking antibody is generally an IgG antibody against the allergen. It is induced in the allergic patient by administering small amounts of allergen over a period of time. When the person is again exposed to the allergen, the IgG reacts with the allergen before it can reach the IgE-coated mast cell. Antihistamines (choice A) would block histamine receptors but would not react with the allergen before it could reach the IgE-coated mast cell. Cromolyn sodium (choice C) is a drug that stabilizes mast cell membranes, thus inhibiting degranulation, but would have no effect on allergen binding to IgE on mast cells. Epinephrine (choice D) is the mainstay of therapy in severe cases of immediate hypersensitivity (anaphylaxis). It increases intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP), thus decreasing mast cell degranulation, and causes smooth-muscle dilation in the airways. Epinephrine would have no effect on the binding of the allergen to IgE on mast cells. cAMP is degraded in cells by the enzyme phosphodiesterase. Theophylline (choice E) inhibits this enzyme, thereby increasing mast cell cAMP levels and making degranulation less likely without affecting the binding of the allergen to IgE on mast cells.

question: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of itching on his arms and face. Physical examination shows well circumscribed wheals with raised. erythematous borders and blanched centers. Which of the following forms of hypersensitivity is this patient most likely exhibiting?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Urticaria (hives), which this patient has, is a good example of a local anaphylactic reaction, which is classified as a type | hypersensitivity reaction. Type | hypersensitivity reactions involve preformed IgE antibody bound to mast cells or basophils, which then release vasoactive and spasmogenic substances when they react with the allergen. Antibody-dependent, cell-mediated cytotoxicity (choice A) occurs when antibodies bound to the Fc receptors of various cells (monocytes, macrophages, natural killer cells, neutrophils, and eosinophils) target cells, tissues, or pathogens for destruction. It is not involved in the production of urticaria. Type II hypersensitivity (choice C) is caused by autoantibodies against cells or tissues. When these antibodies activate complement or promote phagocytosis, the tissue is damaged. Type III hypersensitivity (choice D) is caused by immune complex deposition in the small diameter blood vessels and the subsequent activation of complement and destruction of the vasculature. The tuberculin (PPD) reaction, used to test for tuberculosis exposure, is an example of delayed-type, or type IV, hypersensitivity (choice E). This response involves TH1 cells and the effector cells of cell-mediated immunity and requires 48 to 72 hours after a second and subsequent exposure to elicit maximum expression.

question: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty swallowing, calcifying subcutaneous lesions. and diminished circulation to the hands. Physical examination shows markedly thickened, shiny skin on the fingers and hands. Which of the following autoantibodies is most likely to be present in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The symptoms described in the question are classic for CREST syndrome. This condition is an example of localized scleroderma with slow progression to life-threatening complications. CREST syndrome is the combination of calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia. Anticentromere antibodies are reported in a high percentage of patients who have CREST syndrome, but only in a small percentage of pure scleroderma patients. Centromeres are the portion of the chromosome where spindle fibers attach during cell division. Antihistone antibody (choice B) is a marker for drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Drugs that can induce systemic lupus erythematosus are hydralazine, isoniazid, and procainamide. Anti-SS-A (choice C) is a marker for Sjogren syndrome, which is characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. Anti-SS-B (choice D) is an autoantibody directed against ribonucleoproteins and is a marker for Sjogren syndrome. Rheumatoid factor (RF) (choice E) is generally an IgM autoantibody directed against the Fc portion of IgG. RF is found in 80% of patients who have rheumatoid arthritis and may also be found in low titers in patients who have chronic infections, other autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus and Sjogren syndrome, or chronic pulmonary, hepatic, or renal diseases.

question: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of hemoptysis. Urinalysis shows microhematuria and red blood cell casts. A needle biopsy specimen of the kidney, examined with an indirect fluorescent antibody test. shows linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane. Which of the following antibodies is most likely present in this patient's serum?
explanation: The correct answer is E. This patient is suffering from Goodpasture syndrome, which results from autoantibodies to type IV collagen. This results in antibodies binding to the basement membranes in the kidney and lungs, resulting in nephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage. This is an example of a type II cytotoxic hypersensitivity reaction. Anti-double stranded DNA (choice A), Anti-Sm, and ANA could be used as markers for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). ANA markers are the most sensitive markers for SLE, whereas anti-double stranded DNA and anti-Sm are more specific markers for SLE. Anti-double stranded DNA levels correlate with disease activity and kidney involvement in some patients who have SLE. Lupus is a type III (immune complex) hypersensitivity that may cause vascular damage from complement-mediated lysis anywhere there are small diameter blood vessels. SLE is more common in females than males and would be likely to have the additional manifestations of rash and arthritis. Antiphospholipid antibodies (choice B) are associated with clinical symptoms such as deep venous thrombosis, arterial occlusive events, and repetitive fetal loss. Anti-IgG Fc (choice C), also known as rheumatoid factor) is a marker for rheumatoid arthritis. Anti-smooth muscle antibodies (choice D) are seen in patients who have autoimmune hepatitis.

question: A 67-year-old woman with a history of ocular melanoma comes to the physician because of abdominal pain. Physical examination shows mild tenderness in the right upper abdominal quadrant. A CT scan of the abdomen shows multiple metastatic hepatic nodules. The patient had previously been treated with aggressive radiation and chemotherapy. Therapy is now begun using an in vitro treatment of her peripheral blood leukocytes. Which of the following cytokines will have the most beneficial anti-cancer effect in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Interleukin (IL)-2, which is produced by T-helper (TH) cells, causes activation and cloning of many categories of lymphocytes and has been used to treat various types of cancer. In this case, it would be expected to increase numbers of cytotoxic T lymphocytes and natural Killer cells, both of which may have benefit in the battle against malignant cells. IL-1 (choice A) is endogenous pyrogen. It is a product of activated macrophages and causes fever by affecting the hypothalamic temperature set-point. It would not cause a beneficial effect on cytotoxic cells if used in an in vitro culture. IL-3 (choice C) is a cytokine that enhances the production of myeloid cells in the bone marrow. It would not cause a beneficial effect on cytotoxic cells if used in an in vitro culture. IL-4 (choice D) is a product of TH2 cells that stimulates isotype-switching to IgE in B lymphocytes. It would not cause a beneficial effect on cytotoxic cells if used in an in vitro culture. IL-5 (choice E) is a product of TH2 cells that stimulates isotype-switching to IgA in B lymphocytes. It would not cause a beneficial effect on cytotoxic cells if used in an in vitro culture. IL-6 (choice F) is a second endogenous pyrogen. It is a product of activated macrophages, and plays a role in the production of the acute phase response of systemic inflammation.

question: A 70-year-old man who is a resident in a nursing home develops a fever of 39°C (102.2°F) and shortness of breath. He also has a cough productive of brown-sireaked sputum. Gram stain of sputum shows gram-positive diplococci. The patient's chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following cells will likely be most numerous in the abnormal-appearing area of this patient's lung?
explanation: The correct answer is D. This man has the symptoms of a 'typical' pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. The chest x-ray shows consolidation of the right lower lobe. Typical pneumonia is characterized by high fever, lobar consolidation, and productive sputum. These symptoms are a result of the primary responding immune cell, the neutrophil, which enters the area, releases pyrogenic products (fever), causes innocent bystander damage to the lung (sputum), and creates abscesses (lobar consolidation). Most agents causing typical pneumonia are extracellular organisms, which possess molecules that are chemotactic for neutrophils (f-Met peptides, peptidoglycan, teichoic acids). B lymphocytes (choice A) are most frequently found in the secondary lymphoid organs (lymph nodes and spleen). They are not primarily associated with the pathology of typical pneumonia, although antibodies and complement will eventually assist in neutrophil phagocytosis of the causal organism. Eosinophils (choice B) predominate in lesions that are either parasitic or allergic in nature. Since neither of these is the case here, they would not be expected to predominate in these lesions. Macrophages (choice C) are called into areas of infection by the cytokines produced by T lymphocytes. Macrophages and T lymphocytes are responsible for the pathology in atypical pneumonias but not in the pathology of typical pneumonia, which usually does not persist long enough for the neutrophil population to be replaced by macrophages. T lymphocytes (choice E) are stimulated by presentation of antigens on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. They are thus primarily stimulated by intracellular pathogens, whose antigens are presented in the groove of the MHC class II molecule of various phagocytic cells. This reaction is responsible for the production of alveolar septa swollen with mononuclear cells, which is the primary manifestation of an atypical pneumonia.

question: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever. chills, sweating. headache, and body aches. She states that she recently returned from a trip to Malaysia and that the symptoms have occurred every other day. despite acetaminophen and over-the-counter flu medications. Treatment with chloroquine is begun. Which of the following immune cell types is most likely able to clear the causal organism in the erythrocytic stage?
explanation: The correct answer is B. The patient has malaria, which is caused by four species of intraerythrocytic protozoa belonging to the genus Plasmodium. The erythrocytic stage of malaria would have to be cleared by natural killer (NK) cells due to the lack of MHC molecules on red blood cells (RBCs). The most important protective mechanism in malarial infections is antibody, complement, opsonization and lysis in the spleen, but if a cell-mediated mechanism were to be effective, it would have to be the NK cell, which targets altered cells that do not express MHC class | molecules. Neutrophils (choice A) are cells that cause abscess formation against extracellular microbes. They would not be useful against pathogens with intraerythrocytic locations. Tc cells (choice C) are cytotoxic T lymphocytes that recognize MHC class I on cells infected with intracellular pathogens. They depend on recognition of MHC class I molecules on infected cells, and therefore are unable to recognize erythrocytes, which lack these molecules. TH1 cells (choice D) help promote cell-mediated immune responses that are important in the protection from intracellular pathogens. TH1 cells produce the cytokines that stimulate cytotoxic T lymphocytes, NK cells, macrophages, and the cells of antibody-mediated cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC). TH1 cells are not themselves responsible for clearing intracellular pathogens, however, and the question asks which cell would be able to clear the infection. TH2 cells (choice E) help promote the production of antibodies by B cells. TH2 cells themselves do not clear intracellular infections, although antibodies, complement, opsonization and phagocytosis play an important role in removal of infected erythrocytes from the spleen in malaria.

question: A study is conducted fo evaluate the effect of cytokine administration on the progression of multi-drug resistant tuberculosis in HIV-positive patients. A variety of cytokines produced by recombinant DNA are aerosolized and administered twice daily to a group of 20 individuals. Treatment progress is monitored by chest x-ray and sputum culture. Which of the following cytokines is likely to have the most beneficial effect on macrophage intracellular killing of the mycobacteria?
explanation: The correct answer is C. Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an intracellular pathogen that lives inside macrophages. The protective immune response to this organism depends on the stimulation of more efficient intracellular killing in phagocytic cells by the cytokines of T helper-1 (TH1) cells. Interferon (IFN)-gamma is a product of TH1 cells that acts on macrophages to enhance their microbicidal activities. IFN-alpha (choice A) is a product of leukocytes that inhibits viral replication. It is unlikely to have an effect on an intracellular bacterial infection. IFN-beta (choice B) is a product of fibroblasts that inhibits viral replication. It is unlikely to have an effect on an intracellular bacterial infection. Interleukin (IL)-2 (choice D) is a product of TH1 cells that causes proliferation (cloning) of other lymphocytes. Because the macrophage is an end cell, incapable of further replication, it would not be affected by IL-2 administration. Tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha (choice E), a product of macrophages and natural killer (NK) cells, is cytotoxic for tumor cells, induces cytokine production, and causes the cachexia of chronic inflammation. It is unlikely to have a beneficial result on a bacterial infection of macrophages.

question: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and night sweats. Physical examination shows generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies show: Leukocyte count 13,5300/mm³, Hemaglobin 12.5 g/dL, Hematocrit 38%, Platelet count 120,000/mm³. A peripheral blood smear shows numerous smudge cells. Which of the following marker(s) is/are most likely present on the abnormal cells?
explanation: The correct answer is E. This patient most likely has chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), which usually occurs in people over 50 years of age. The symptoms (which may or may not be present) and the physical findings are classic for this disorder. The peripheral smear usually shows an increased number of small, round lymphocytes, with occasional 'smudge cells' (fragile cells disrupted in the process of making a smear). The neoplastic cells have an immunophenotype somewhat like B cells, with IgM, or IgM and IgD, on their surfaces. In addition, both the tumor cells and normal B cells have CD19 and CD20 markers that aid in their identification on flow cytometry. In CLL, the tumor cells may additionally have CD5, a T-cell marker present on a small minority of normal B cells. The CD3 (choice A) marker is present on all T cells. The CD8 (choice B) marker is present on cytotoxic T lymphocytes. The CD14 (choice C) marker is used to identify macrophages. The CD16 and CD56 (choice D) markers are present on natural killer (NK) cells.

question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a skin rash and epistaxis. A review of his records shows that he has had several severe sinopulmonary infections and that his maternal uncle died of bleeding complications following a cholecystectomy. Which of the following additional findings are most likely to be seen in this patient?
options: C. Elevated platelet count and high serum IgG. IgA. and IgE levels
D. Low platelet count and low serum IgG levels
E. Low platelet count and low serum IgM levels
explanation: The correct answer is E. This clinical scenario is typical for Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. This is a X-linked recessive disorder presenting with the triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. Serum IgM levels are low, IgG levels are nearly normal, and IgA, and IgE levels are increased. Patients have a defective response to polysaccharide antigens, which is due to a cytoskeletal defect in T cells that inhibits their binding to B cells. A CD4/CD8 ratio of 1.5:1 (choice A) is the pattern seen in AIDS due to selective tropism of the CD4+ T-helper cell population. Cerebellar ataxia (choice B) is part of the ataxia-telangiectasia syndrome. The ataxia develops between age 2 and 5 years. The defect is associated with a DNA repair enzyme deficiency. Elevated platelet count and increased serum levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE (choice C) are not associated with a particular syndrome. Polyclonal gammopathies result in an increase in immunoglobulin of more than one class. This benign alteration is frequently seen in viral or bacterial infections. Thrombocythemia may be associated with a myeloproliferative syndrome or with a secondary reactive process. Low platelet count and low serum IgG (choice D) are not associated with any particular disorder.

question: An 18-year-old man who underwent a tonsilloadenoidectomy 2 days ago is brought to the emergency department because of a high fever, hypotension, and a diffuse desquamating erythematous rash over the palms of his hands. Which of the following TH1-produced cytokines is most likely to be increased in this patient's serum?
explanation: The correct answer is A. This patient is suffering from toxic shock syndrome, which resulted from growth of Staphylococcus aureus in the surgical packing associated with his tonsilloadenoidectomy. S aureus produces an exotoxin, TSST-1, which acts as a superantigen, crosslinking the T-cell receptors and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II antigens of unrelated T lymphocytes and macrophages (in the absence of antigen recognition), causing their polyclonal stimulation and the production of dangerous amounts of their cytokines. The cytokines that are overproduced during superantigen pathogenesis are interleukin (IL)-1, IL-6, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha (from macrophages), and IL-2 and interferon (IFN)-gamma (from TH1 lymphocytes). IL-1 (choice B) is a product of activated macrophages, not TH1 cells, and would be elevated in toxic shock syndrome. This cytokine is also known as endogenous pyrogen and plays a major role in the development of the fever in these cases. IL-4 (choice C) is a product of TH2 lymphocytes that stimulates the differentiation of B lymphocytes in the humoral immune response. It would not be produced in large amounts in superantigen pathogenesis. IL-5 (choice D) is a product of activated macrophages and TH2 lymphocytes and would be elevated in toxic shock syndrome. This cytokine is a second pyrogen and also mediates the acute phase response. TNF-alpha (choice E) is a product of activated macrophages, not TH1 cells, and would be elevated in toxic shock syndrome. This cytokine is pyrogenic and plays a role in cancer cachexia.

question: During an investigational study. a specific antibody to complement component C3b is developed. Intravenous administration of the antibody prevents the biologic effects of C3b. Which of the following immunologic functions is most likely to be inhibited by the administration of this antibody to a patient?
explanation: The correct answer is C. C3b acts as an opsonin, along with IgG, to facilitate phagocytosis. It is also critically involved in the removal of immune complexes from the blood. Phagocytes have Fc receptors (CD16), which allow them to clear immune complexes from the serum, and immune complexes also activate the complement cascade. C3b is generated in excess during the activation of the classical complement cascade. Antibody formation (choice A) would not be affected by an antibody to C3b. Antibodies are formed by B cells in the bone marrow and secreted by plasma cells in the periphery. C3b has nothing to do with this process. Natural killer (NK) cell function (choice B) is increased by TH1 cytokines, but would not be affected by C3b. Tc-cell activation (choice D) occurs via stimulation with TH1 cytokines, but not C3b. TH-cell activation (choice E) occurs via macrophage presentation of MHC class II molecules loaded with foreign peptides, followed by stimulation with interleukins 1 and 6 and tumor necrosis factor-alpha. It is not altered by C3b.

question: A 42-year-old man who recently emigrated from Nigeria is brought to the emergency department because of weight loss, night sweats. sputum production, and occasional hemoptysis for the past few months. A protein injected into the skin of the forearm shows a 15-mm indurated swelling 48 hours later. Which of the following immune effector mechanisms has most likely occurred?
options: D. TH1 cells have attracted macrophages
E. TH2 cells have activated B cells
explanation: The correct answer is D. The tuberculin skin test is a delayed-type hypersensitivity test. This type IV hypersensitivity is a cell-mediated immune response involving CD4 T helper-1 (TH1) lymphocytes activating and attracting macrophages into the area. The most important cytokine stimulating this response is interferon-gamma, produced by TH1 cells to activate macrophages. This individual is tuberculin test-positive, and should now have cultures and a chest x-ray to confirm an active case of TB. An Arthus reaction (choice A) has not occurred. The Arthus reaction is an example of a type III (immune complex) hypersensitivity involving antibody, antigen, and complement activation. Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a facultative intracellular pathogen, and therefore requires cell-mediated, not antibody-mediated, immunity. Mast cell degranulation (choice B) has not occurred. Mast cells are involved in type | hypersensitivities, along with IgE. Antibodies are not involved in the etiology of type IV hypersensitivity. Neutrophil diapedesis (choice C) has not occurred. Although neutrophils are always the first responders to any injury, by 48 hours they would no longer be the predominant cell in this area. It is not the case that TH2 cells have activated B cells (choice E) because TH2 cells and B cells are involved in the production of the humoral immune response, and the tuberculin response is the classic demonstration of the function of the cell-mediated arm of the immune response.

question: A 15-year-old boy who recently immigrated from Africa is brought to the physician by his parents because of a fever and weight loss. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and generalized lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 12.2 g/dL, hematocrit of 35%. and platelets of 125,000/mm³. A peripheral blood smear shows amastigotes in monocytes. Which of the following cytokines is most important in containing this infection?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The finding of amastigotes inside monocytes and macrophages in the circulation, lymph nodes, spleen, and bone marrow suggests a diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis. Leishmania donovani is a protozoan parasite that survives inside macrophages. Therefore, the most effective immune response is cell-mediated, with stimulation of macrophage-killing mechanisms. The most important cytokines to stimulate macrophage microbicidal activity are those produced by TH1 cells, especially interferon (IFN)-gamma. Interleukin (IL)-2 (choice B) is a product of TH1 cells that causes the proliferation (cloning) of other lymphocytes. Because the macrophage is an end cell, incapable of further replication, it would not be affected by IL-2 administration. IL-4 (choice C) is a product of TH2 cells that causes the differentiation of B lymphocytes. It acts antagonistically to TH1 cells, which would mediate the protective response needed in this patient. IL-10 (choice D) is a product of TH2 cells that causes the differentiation of B lymphocytes. It inhibits TH1 cells, which would assist in the protective response needed in this patient. Tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha (choice E) is a product of macrophages and natural killer (NK) cells that is cytotoxic for tumor cells, induces cytokine production, and causes the cachexia of chronic inflammation. It is unlikely to have a beneficial result on the microbicidal activity of macrophages.

question: A 5-year-old child is brought to a physician for the evaluation of a potential genetic deficiency. The parents say that she has had numerous infections and has failed to make a protective immune response after vaccination with the DTaP or MMR vaccines. Flow cytometry of a blood sample shows normal numbers of CD19+, CD16+, and CD8+ cells but a near-total absence of CD4+ cells. Which of the following molecules is most likely absent from this patient's cells?
explanation: The correct answer is E. This child has major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II deficiency, which causes a defect in the development of CD4+ cells in the thymus. Because there is no MHC class II, helper cells cannot be selected. However, cytotoxic cells (CD8+), which recognize MHC class | molecules, are normally produced. This condition is also known as type II bare lymphocyte syndrome, and because helper T cells are required for virtually all immune responses, it will affect the patient's ability to respond to both extra- and intracellular pathogens. The gamma-delta T-cell receptor (choice A) is present on a small proportion of T cells that do not undergo thymic selection. Their function in the body is not known, but they would not be affected by the absence of the class II MHC. Intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (choice B), found on the surface of antigen-presenting cells (APCs) in the body, reacts with LFA-1 on T cells for the purpose of cell-to-cell adhesion. Its absence would not affect the development of cells in the thymus. The killer inhibitory receptor (choice C) is one of two receptors found on the surface of natural killer (NK) cells. It inhibits the killing of an attached cell if it is bound to MHC class |. Because this child has normal levels of CD16+ (NK) cells, it is unlikely she has a deficiency of this receptor. MHC class | (choice D) is the molecule that presents peptides that have been produced intracellularly to CD8+ cytotoxic cells. If this molecule had been absent, the patient would have exhibited susceptibility to intracellular pathogens, and not both intra- and extracellular pathogens as described in this case.

question: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a yeast infection of the diaper area that does not respond fo therapy. A review of his records shows that he has had multiple acute pyogenic infections. A leukocyte differential count shows: 70 neutrophils. 20 lymphocytes. and 10 monocytes. Circulating lymphocytes are all CD-19 positive. Which of the following is the most common cause of this patient's condition?
options: D. Inability to produce MHC-II molecules
E. Nonsense mutation of rag genes
explanation: The correct answer is C. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is associated with deficiencies in both B and T cells due to a defect in differentiation of an early stem cell. Over 50% of cases are caused by a gene defect on the X chromosome, resulting in a defective gamma-chain of receptors for IL-2, IL-4, IL-7, IL-9, IL-11, IL-15 and IL-21. Because of defective signaling from the IL-7 receptor, there is profound decrease in T cell numbers. B cell numbers may be near normal, but antibody synthesis is impaired in the absence of T helper cells. NK cell activity may also be diminished because of the absence of the IL-15 receptor. Adenosine deaminase deficiency (choice A) is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by a deficiency of adenosine deaminase, which results in accumulation of metabolites that are toxic to both B and T stem cells in the bone marrow. Children with severe infections usually die within the first 2 years of life unless they receive bone marrow transplants. This deficiency produces a SCID, but it is much more rare than deficiencies of IL-2 receptors. A defective CD40L molecule (choice B) causes hyper-IgM syndrome. This makes it impossible for B lymphocytes to receive the signal to switch isotypes, and they are therefore 'stuck' making IgM alone. It is not classified as a SCID. Inability to produce major histocompatibility complex (MHC)II (choice D) causes bare lymphocyte syndrome, which causes patients to be unable to produce CD4 cells. It results in a type of SCID since T-helper (TH) cells are necessary for the function of all immune responses, but is much less common than SCID due to IL-2 receptor deficiency. Nonsense mutation of rag genes (choice E) results in a SCID, because without the ability to perform VDJ recombinations, lymphocytes cannot express surface receptors for antigen, and in that case, lymphocyte precursors are induced to undergo apoptosis in the bone marrow. Recombination activating genes (rag genes) are responsible for the VDJ rearrangements that allow lymphocytes to create the idiotype of their antigen receptors. These are extremely rare conditions.

question: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of dyspnea. tachycardia, and diaphoresis following a bee sting. Which of the following is the first immunoglobulin produced in response to this antigen?
explanation: The correct answer is E. The first immunoglobulin produced in response to any immunogen is always IgM. This is because of the sequential transcription of the DNA coding for the immunoglobulin isotype genes. The first constant domain that is encoded downstream in the DNA from the idiotype coding is that for IgM and then IgD. These two isotypes are produced and expressed concomitantly. It is not possible for any other immunoglobulin to be made first. The symptoms that this patient is having are the result of a type | hypersensitivity reaction, but in these reactions the IgE antibody is preformed and already bound to mast cell receptors. IgE is not made during the hypersensitivity reaction itself. IgA (choice A), IgE (choice C) and IgG (choice D) can only be produced as a secondary response, i.e., one that follows the primary IgM response. The DNA coding for the IgD (choice B) heavy chain follows that of IgM in the lymphocyte germ-line DNA. Mature, naive B lymphocytes express both IgM and IgD on their surfaces because of alternative RNA splicing, but the complete IgM molecule is always produced first.

question: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a feeling that she has "sand in her eyes" and difficulty swallowing foods such as crackers and toast. Examination of tissue obtained on biopsy of an enlarged salivary gland shows lymphocytic infiltration. Which of the following tests will most likely yield positive results in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is E. This patient has Sjogren syndrome, which is an autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of exocrine glands resulting in dry mouth (xerostomia) and dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca). Patients have an increased risk of malignant lymphoma. Autoantibodies produced include anti-Ro (SS-A), anti-La (SSB), antinuclear antibodies, and rheumatoid factor. Anticentromere antibodies (choice A) are a very specific marker for CREST syndrome. Anti-Smith antibody and anti-double stranded DNA antibody (choice B) are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies (choice C) are seen in Goodpasture syndrome. Anti-Scl-70 antibodies (choice D) are seen in patients with scleroderma.

question: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of several "boils" on his arm. His mother states that on several previous occasions the boy has had similar lesions that were treated successfully with antibiotics. He does not have a history of eczema or childhood illnesses such as measles or chickenpox and he is up-to-date on all immunizations. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count, and normal immunoglobulin levels. B- and T-cell counts. and complement levels. The nitroblue tetrazolium test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The correct answer is C. The fact that the boy has had several different infections with pyogenic bacteria requiring antibiotics suggests an inability of phagocytes to kill bacteria. The nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT) for reactive oxygen intermediates was negative, indicating that the boy suffers from chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). CGD is most often due to a defect in NADPH oxidase, which is necessary for leukocyte hydrogen peroxide production. It leads to an inability to kill bacteria and fungi that are catalase-positive. A cytoskeletal defect (choice A) is the underlying lesion in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, which causes a triad of symptoms including eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immunodeficiency. A defect of IL-2 receptors (choice B) is the most common cause of severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID). Patients with SCIDs have an inability to mount any immune response, and are therefore susceptible to infections of all types. A patient with SCID would not have the normal immunoglobulin levels and T- and B-cell counts given here. A defect of tyrosine kinase (choice D) is the cause of Bruton agammaglobulinemia. It would cause a blockage of maturation of B lymphocytes, so B-cell numbers in the blood would be depressed and serum immunoglobulin levels would be minimal. These patients are susceptible to extracellular pathogens but have normal abilities to mount delayed-hypersensitivity reactions and responses to intracellular pathogens. Thymic aplasia (choice E) is observed in DiGeorge syndrome as an embryonic failure of formation of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. In such a case, there would be depressed numbers of T cells in the peripheral blood. This is referred to as velocardiofacial syndrome to reflect the fact that such individuals have hypocalcemic tetany (due to malformed parathyroids), malformation of the mouth and face (cleft palate and vertical elongation of the mouth), and cardiac abnormalities (persistent truncus arteriosus).

question: A multigravid 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of concern about her pregnancy. A review of her records shows that she is Rh-negative and her husband is Rh-positive. Both of her children are also Rh-negative. She has had two spontaneous abortions; she carried a third pregnancy to term but the child was diagnosed with erythroblastosis fetalis and died at birth. Which of the following tests will most likely show the presence of circulating anti-Rh antibody in this patient?
options: A. Direct Coombs test to measure IgG anti-Rh antibody
B. Direct Coombs test to measure IgM anti-Rh antibody
C. Indirect Coombs test to measure IgG anti-Rh antibody
D. Indirect Coombs test to measure IgM anti-Rh antibody
E. Ouchterlony test to measure precipitating IgG anti-Rh antibody
explanation: The correct answer is C. The indirect Coombs test is the test of choice to detect the presence of IgG anti-Rh antibody circulating in the mother's blood. Serum is collected from the mother and mixed with Rh-positive red blood cells. If the mother is making the antibody, it will bind to the Rh-positive cells, and when Coombs serum (anti-human IgG) is then added, the erythrocytes will then agglutinate. The direct Coombs test (choice A) is used to diagnose a child at risk for development of hemolytic disease of the newborn. A sample of the child's blood is mixed with Coombs serum (anti-human IgG) and if there is agglutination, it means that the child's erythrocytes have already been coated by maternal anti-Rh antibodies. These antibodies are IgG antibodies that can cross the placenta, and not IgM antibodies (choice B) that would not be able to cause this problem. An indirect Coombs test to measure IgM anti-Rh antibody (choice D) is not available, and would not be useful, since IgM does not cross the placenta and would therefore not cause hemolytic disease of the newborn. An assay for the presence of IgM against erythrocyte antigens would be an agglutination reaction, and not a Coombs test, which requires finding antibodies that have already coated erythrocytes. The Ouchterlony test (choice E), or double-diffusion reaction, is basically used to determine if two antigens are identical, non-identical, or related. It is not the direct Coombs test for hemolytic disease of the newborn (the object is to find the presence of maternal antibodies, not antigens, on the child or in the mother).

question: A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of oliguria and hematuria. He has also had nasal congestion, epistaxis, occasional cough, and hemoptysis. Physical examination shows mucosal ulceration and nasal septal perforation, but no polyps are seen. Laboratory studies show a serum BUN level of 22 mg/dL and creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL. Lung biopsy shows necrosis, vasculitis, and granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following serum markers is most likely to be present in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is D. This patient has Wegener granulomatosis, which is characterized by renal involvement, severe upper respiratory tract symptoms, and pulmonary involvement. Other organ systems may also be involved. The renal syndrome is a crescentic, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis leading to renal failure. The upper respiratory tract findings include sinus pain and drainage, and purulent or bloody nasal discharge with or without nasal ulcerations. Nasal septal perforation may follow. Pulmonary involvement may be clinically silent, with only infiltrates present on x-ray, or it may present as cough and hemoptysis. ANCA stands for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, and c-ANCA refers to antibody that localizes staining to the cytoplasm of neutrophils. The most common target antigen is proteinase 3 (PR-3). c-ANCA is a marker for Wegener granulomatosis, present in a high percentage of patients. Anticentromere antibody (choice A) is associated with approximately 90% of patients who have CREST syndrome (calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal motility syndrome, sclerodactyly, telangiectasia), which is also called limited systemic sclerosis. Anti-Ro (choice B) is also called anti-SS-A and is associated with Sjogren syndrome (70-95%). Anti-SS-B (choice C) is associated with Sjogren syndrome (60-90%). p-ANCA (choice E) refers to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies that localize in a perinuclear fashion. These are usually directed against myeloperoxidase in the cell. p-ANCA antibodies can sometimes be seen in Wegener granulomatosis, but are more characteristic of Churg-Strauss syndrome, a medium to small vessel vasculitis associated with asthma and eosinophilia. It causes eosinophil-rich inflammation involving the respiratory tract and necrotizing vasculitis affecting medium to small sized vessels.

question: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever and cough productive of reddish-brown sputum. She had a splenectomy 1 year ago. A chest x-ray shows consolidation of the right lower lobe. Blood cultures grow α-hemolytic. gram-positive diplococci. Immunity to the most likely causal organism is based on which of the following?
explanation: The correct answer is B. This patient has pneumococcal pneumonia, which must be considered in any patient with chills, fever, chest pain, and cough productive of purulent, rust-colored sputum. Streptococcus pneumoniae is an α-hemolytic, gram-positive coccus that grows in short chains. It can easily be distinguished from other α-hemolytic streptococci because it is exquisitely sensitive to bile and bile-like compounds, such as Optochin. It is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia and the most common cause of community-acquired meningitis in adults older than 30 years. The only recognized virulence factor of S. pneumoniae is its carbohydrate capsule (which contains acidic polysaccharides). Antibody to a specific capsule type is necessary to overcome infection. More than 80 capsule types have been recognized. The 23 types that most commonly cause disease are contained in a vaccine that is recommended for high-risk groups, including the elderly and those undergoing splenectomy. Increased susceptibility is also found in patients with Hodgkin disease, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, and myeloma. The vaccine should still be given to patients with these conditions, but it is less protective because of diminished patient ability to mount an antibody response. The alternative complement pathway (choice A) is important in clearing Neisseria infections. Individuals with deficiencies in C5 through C8 are at increased risk of disease from Neisseria. Neutrophils (choice C) will be found in the sputum of patients with pneumococcal pneumonia, but they do not provide immunity. They are attracted to the area by N-formyl methionine peptides found in the bacteria, but have difficulty engulfing the organism due to the antiphagocytic nature of the capsule. T cells and NK cells (choices D and E) are predominantly used for the clearance of intracellular pathogens, and pneumococcal pneumonia is an extracellular pathogen.

question: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician for a pre-employment physical examination. She says that as a child she experienced two episodes of fever, headache, and sore joints following severe sore throats. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following sequelae of her childhood illness is most likely to develop in this patient as she grows older?
explanation: The correct answer is C. After an initial attack of rheumatic fever, an affected individual is at increased risk for developing recurrent rheumatic disease after each pharyngeal infection by beta-hemolytic streptococci. Any one of the manifestations of rheumatic disease can recur, but will usually resolve. The damage to the heart valves caused by rheumatic fever can lead to fibrous scarring and deformity, producing valvular dysfunction (particularly mitral stenosis) that may lead to heart failure in late adulthood. This is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction in which tissue-specific autoantibodies cause damage to host tissues. The inflammatory response associated with type II hypersensitivities is usually localized rather than systemic. The arthritis (choice A) produced by rheumatic fever is transitory and resolves after the attack has run its course. There are no long-term complications of the arthritis. Fibrinous pericarditis (choice B), like almost any fibrinous inflammatory response, is an acute process. Although the patient may develop some scarring of the pericardium, this is generally not sufficient to produce long-lasting consequences. Myocardial involvement (choice D) by rheumatic fever is typically seen as Aschoff bodies, collections of fibrinoid necrosis, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and histiocytes within the myocardium. When the event resolves, the Aschoff bodies will be replaced by discrete fibrous scars. No appreciable myocardial dysfunction ensues. Sydenham chorea, the neurologic manifestation of rheumatic fever, leaves no lasting neurologic effects (choice E).

question: A 33-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a deep puncture wound in her right hand. A shard of glass is removed from the patient's hand, and the wound is appropriately cleaned and treated at the time of the accident. Twelve hours later, the wound becomes inflamed and swollen despite appropriate therapy. Which of the following molecules plays an important role in producing chemotaxis of white blood cells into this area?
explanation: The correct answer is B. In active inflammation, the complement system has been activated and C5a is being produced. C5a is a strong chemoattractant to neutrophils and other phagocytic cells. Other chemotactic factors for neutrophils include IL-8, fibrinopeptides, leukotriene B4, and formyl methionyl peptides from bacteria. C3b (choice A) acts as an opsonin for microorganisms. When the organism is coated with C3b, it is more easily phagocytized. C3b is formed via the classical and alternative complement pathways, but it is not chemotactic for neutrophils. IgM (choice C) is the large antibody produced in the primary immune response. It is not chemotactic for neutrophils. IL-2 (choice D) is a growth-promoting interleukin that stimulates the proliferation of natural killer cells, and T-cytotoxic cells, and T-helper lymphocytes, but it is not chemotactic for neutrophils. Lysozyme (choice E) is a natural antibacterial present in tears, mucus, vaginal secretions, and other body fluids. It is active against the peptidoglycan of bacterial cell walls, splitting the backbone structure of the peptidoglycan (N-acetylglucosamine and N-acetyl muramic acid polymers). It is not chemotactic for neutrophils.

question: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of sore throat, rhinorrhea. fever, and productive cough. A review of his records shows that this is the seventh time over the last 6 months that the child has been brought to the emergency department because of an illness. Prior visits have been because of infections involving the skin, ear, and respiratory tract. Laboratory studies show extremely low levels of serum IgG and an absence of CD19+ cells. Which of the following genes is likely mutated or deficient in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Bruton x-linked agammaglobulinemia is the only one of the humoral immune deficiencies in which there are no peripheral B cells (no CD19+ cells). The mutation is in the Bruton tyrosine kinase gene (Btk) that is required for pre-B cells to develop to immature B cells in the bone marrow. Adenosine deaminase deficiency (choice A) is the deficiency in one form of severe combined immunodeficiency disease. CD18 (choice C) is deficient in leukocyte adhesion deficiency, leading to failure of diapedesis, in which leukocytes are unable to extravasate to an area of inflammation due to lack of the common beta chain of integrin molecules. CD40L (choice D) is missing in hyper-IgM syndrome, in which IgM-producing B cells cannot receive the signal to isotype-switch to production of IgA, IgG, and IgE. The actual deficiency is in TH cells that are deficient in expression of CD40L. NADPH oxidase (choice E) is the enzyme that is deficient in chronic granulomatous disease, which will then result in an inability to generate toxic oxygen metabolites inside phagocytic cells. This would cause increased susceptibility to catalase-positive organisms, but would not result in diminished numbers of circulating B lymphocytes or reduced immunoglobulin levels.

question: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of frequent upper respiratory tract infections. His mother says that he was delivered at 39 weeks' gestation and that the pregnancy was uneventful. A review of his records shows that he is up-to-date on all his immunizations. He has had three hospitalizations in the past year for pneumonia. Laboratory studies will most likely show a deficiency of which of the following immunoglobulins in this patient?
options: C. An immunoglobulin that binds to mast cells
D. An immunoglobulin that is an antigen receptor on mature naive B lymphocytes
E. An immunoglobulin that mediates antibody-dependent, cell-mediated cytotoxicity
explanation: The correct answer is A. Selective IgA deficiency (<5 mg/dL) is the most common of all the primary immunodeficiency diseases. The incidence reported in the United States has ranged from 1:250 to 1:1,000. Recurrent bacterial and viral infections of the respiratory tract can be attributed to a lack of secretory IgA (sIgA), the predominant immunoglobulin of the mucosal immune system. IgA is a dimer held together by a single J chain, and a secretory component is added by mucosal cells as it is transported into the lumen of the organ system. Children typically do not begin to develop severe signs of this deficiency until their second year of life because maternally acquired IgG (across the placenta) and IgA (in breast milk) protect the child for the first year of life. A pentameric immunoglobulin (choice B) describes serum IgM. This is the most important immunoglobulin of the primary immune response, but it is not important in protection against mucosal surface pathogens. An immunoglobulin that binds to mast cells (choice C) describes IgE. It is involved in the mediation of type | hypersensitivity responses and anti-parasite responses. An immunoglobulin that is an antigen receptor on mature naive B lymphocytes (choice D) describes IgD. Its only known function is as an antigen receptor on the surface of mature naive B lymphocytes. An immunoglobulin that mediates antibody-dependent, cell-mediated cytotoxicity (choice E) describes IgG. The binding of the Fc region of IgG molecules to natural killer cells, neutrophils, and macrophages can cause destruction of cells targeted by the antibody.

question: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of fever of recent onset and pain and swelling of his knees and ankles. He had an upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago, for which he received acetaminophen. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min. and blood pressure is 115/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows erythematous skin macules with a clear center, arthritis, and small subcutaneous nodules on the dorsal aspect of the arms. A systolic murmur in the mid-precordial area is heard on auscultation of the chest. Which of the following is the most likely immunopathogenetic mechanism responsible for this condition?
explanation: The correct answer is B. The clinical manifestations fulfill the diagnostic criteria for rheumatic disease, a condition characterized by pancarditis (endocarditis, myocarditis, and pericarditis), arthritis, subcutaneous nodules, chorea, and erythema marginatum. A history of pharyngitis, otitis, or other streptococcal infections preceding the onset of the disease by 2-3 weeks is usually elicited. The triggering etiologic agent is group A Streptococcus, which incites production of antistreptococcal antibodies that cross-react with antigens of heart, skin, and nervous tissues. The antibodies bind fixed antigens and trigger an acute inflammatory response that eventually resolves with permanent scarring. This type of hypersensitivity response, in which autoantibodies bind antigens on cells or tissues, is classified as type II. Other examples of type II hypersensitivity-mediated diseases include Graves disease (the autoantibodies stimulate hormone production by binding thyroid-stimulating hormone [TSH] receptors) and myasthenia gravis (the autoantibodies interfere with cholinergic neuromuscular transmission by binding nicotinic receptors). Type | hypersensitivity (choice A) is mediated by IgE. Antigens bind IgE on the surface of mast cells and trigger the release of inflammatory mediators such as histamine and heparin, and then activation of the arachidonic acid cascade causes production of prostaglandins and leukotrienes. Asthma and urticaria are classic examples of this immune mechanism. Type III hypersensitivity (choice C) is mediated by soluble immune complexes, i.e., antigen-antibody complexes. Diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, and various types of vasculitis are due to this mechanism. Type IV hypersensitivity (choice D) is mediated by T lymphocytes and often results in formation of granulomas. Granulomatous inflammation caused by Mycobacteria is an example of a type IV cell-mediated reaction.

question: A 47-year-old man with a history of polycystic kidney disease is awaiting a renal transplant. A living donor is found who matches the patient at A, B, and DR loci. Which of the following best describes this type of transplant?
explanation: The correct answer is A. A transplant between two members of the same species who are not genetically identical is an allogeneic graft. This is the most commonly performed graft in today's medicine. An autograft (choice B) is a graft from one location to another on the same individual. This is the only type of graft that will not experience rejection, even without immunosuppressive drugs. This type of transplantation is performed in coronary bypass surgery and in skin grafting following burns. Isografts and syngeneic grafts (choices C and D) are grafts between monozygotic twins. Typically, this procedure in the human is called an isograft; in other species it is called a syngeneic graft. Even monozygotic twins have genetic distinctions that arise during gestation and development, so some level of immunosuppression is still required following this form of engraftment. A xenograft (choice E) is a transplant between members of different species. Pig heart valves are often used in humans in this way.

question: A 33-year-old woman develops a painful, swollen right knee. Culture of the joint fluid aspirate grows organisms on chocolate agar but not on blood agar The most likely causal organism has which of the following properties?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The causal organism is Neisseria gonorrhoeae which is a sexually transmitted gram-negative coccus. It is estimated that N. gonorrhoeae may express over 1 million variants of pili, resulting in the virtual absence of immunity to reinfection with this agent The pili of this organism also are protective against phagocytosis and mediate attachment to the mucosal surfaces. The organism is the most common cause of septic arthritis in otherwise healthy, sexually active adults The treatment is usually with ceftriaxone. The Chlamydiae are intracellular organisms that cannot make ATP (choice C) and do not usually cause septic arthritis. Having both hyphae and spores (choice B) would be true of Candida, which usually causes arthritis as a rare complication of systemic candidiasis in immunocompromised patients. Mycoplasma do not have true cell walls (choice D) and do not usually cause septic arthritis. Syphilis is caused by a spirochete that is visible only with darkfield microscopy (choice E) or direct fluorescent antibody. Secondary syphilis can (uncommonly) cause an acute arthritis, but syphilis is rare in an otherwise healthy adult.

question: A 10-year-old boy develops an abscess on his left knee. Examination of the exudate shows neutrophils containing mixed bacterial flora. Which of the following is the most important virulence factor for bacterial survival within the phagolysosome?
explanation: The correct answer is A. Abscesses are commonly produced by catalase-positive organisms. Catalase is an enzyme that converts hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen. Hydrogen peroxide is one of the toxic oxygen compounds generated by the action of NADPH oxidase in phagocytes and it acts as the substrate for myeloperoxidase. Producing catalase, therefore, allows bacteria to survive longer intracellularly. Catalase-positive organisms include the staphylococci, Pseudomonas, Candida, Aspergillus, and the Enterobacteriaceae. Hemolysins (choice B) refers to a variety of enzymes that act to degrade hemoglobin. These would not have a role inside the phagolysosome. Hyaluronidase (choice C) is a spreading factor produced by Streptococcus pyogenes that degrades hyaluronic acid and promotes the movement of the organism through the extracellular matrix. It would not inactivate any of the intracellular killing mechanisms of phagocytes. Streptokinase (choice D) is a fibrinolytic compound produced by Streptococcus pyogenes. It would not contribute to survival within the phagolysosome. Tetanospasmin (choice E) is a neurotoxin produced by Clostridium tetani. It inhibits the inhibitory mediators glycine and GABA, and promotes the rigid paralysis of tetanus. It would not contribute to survival within the phagolysosome.

question: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of sore throat and a fever. Physical examination shows pharyngeal erythema with a tonsillar abscess. Culture of oropharyngeal secretions on sheep's blood agar grows colonies of gram-positive cocci that are surrounded by a zone of complete hemolysis. Another culture of the secretions on mannitol salt agar grows well and causes the medium to turn yellow. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is C. The description of the agent is consistent with a staphylococcal organism (catalase-positive, gram-positive cocci that grow on mannitol salt agar). The organism is most likely Staphylococcus aureus since it was able to ferment mannitol (as evidenced by the color change in the mannitol salt agar after incubation) and was beta-hemolytic. Other characteristics of this organism are coagulase production and excretion of DNAse from colonies. Staphylococcal organisms are also notorious for formation of abscesses; this patient has an abscess in the tonsillar region. The diphtheria bacilli Corynebacterium diphtheriae (choice A) are gram-positive, pleomorphic rods that are arranged in palisades. They are non-hemolytic and will not grow on mannitol salt agar. These organisms produce a whitish-gray pseudomembrane on the pharynx or the larynx; constitutional symptoms from toxemia are the major features of diphtheria. Epiglottitis is the most common disease of the upper respiratory tract produced by Haemophilus influenzae (choice B) a gram-negative, encapsulated rod. It is also a common cause of otitis media in children and may cause bronchitis, bronchiolitis, and pneumonia in adults. Streptococcus pyogenes (choice D) is a beta-hemolytic gram-positive coccus that grows in chains, as opposed to the random, grapelike clusters of the staphylococci. Streptococcus pyogenes is the most common cause of pharyngitis, which is usually manifested by severe sore throat, fever, a beefy-red pharynx and a tonsillar exudate. Streptococcus salivarius (choice E) is a gram-positive coccus that is usually alpha-hemolytic. It is normal flora of the oral cavity and is sometimes implicated in subacute bacterial endocarditis, but is not associated with tonsillar abscesses.

question: A 58-year-old man with a history of colorectal cancer has had fatigue weight loss, and myalgias for several weeks. He has a temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows punctate hemorrhages under the fingernails and a murmur is heard on auscultation of the chest Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the development of these symptoms in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Streptococcus bovis is a group D Streptococcus. There is a significant association between S. bovis bacteremia and endocarditis with carcinoma of the colon and other colonic diseases. Every patient with S. bovis bacteremia should undergo gastrointestinal and cardiac evaluation. Up to 50% of patients with S. bovis bacteremia are reported to have underlying colonic malignancies. In another study, 25-50% of cases of S. bovis bacteremia were associated with endocarditis, especially in patients with preexisting valvular lesions. The group D Streptococci are distinguished by having a cell wall carbohydrate composed of glycerol teichoic acid. S. agalactiae (choice A) is a group B Streptococcus that is the number-one cause of neonatal meningitis and septicemia in the United States. S. mutans and S. sanguis (choices C and F) are viridans streptococci, which are normal flora of the oral mucosa. While they are associated with bacterial endocarditis, it is usually associated with invasive dental work and a preexisting heart valve defect. S. pneumoniae (choice D) which is a non-groupable Streptococcus (it does not have a C cell wall carbohydrate), is the most common cause of typical pneumonia in the United States. S. pyogenes (choice E) is a group A Streptococcus and is associated with pharyngitis, poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, rheumatic fever, and scarlet fever.

question: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a several month history of chronic fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats. Laboratory studies show that he is HIV-positive by ELISA and Western blot. His CD4 cell count is 525/mm³. He declines anti-retroviral therapy. Which of the following sets of findings is most likely at his next visit?
options: A. Virus, p24, RNA Increasing | CD4+ Decreasing | Anti-p24 Decreasing | Anti-env Increasing slightly
B. Virus, p24, RNA Increasing | CD4+ Decreasing | Anti-p24 Increasing | Anti-env Decreasing slightly
C. Virus, p24, RNA Increasing | CD4+ No change | Anti-p24 Increasing | Anti-env Decreasing slightly
D. Virus, p24, RNA Decreasing | CD4+ Normal | Anti-p24 No change | Anti-env No change
E. Virus, p24, RNA Undetectable | CD4+ Normal | Anti-p24 Decreasing | Anti-env Increasing
explanation: The correct answer is A. Since the patient's CD4 cell count is 525/mm³, he will soon enter the early symptomatic period during which there is generalized decline in immune function, without the presence of an AIDS-defining condition. As the number of CD4-positive cells declines further, his ability to produce any isotype of antibody other than IgM will decline, and thus antibodies to the capsid antigen (p24) will decline. Since these antibodies are the ones that keep virions out of the circulation, there will now be an increase in viral load in the patient, measured by RT-PCR for viral RNA, and virions will be found in the blood. Antibodies against the envelope glycoproteins are generally IgM, which does not require a primary immune response. The IgM anti-env antibody can be made in the absence of TH cells. Increasing p24 virus, and RNA, decreasing CD4 cells, increasing p24 antibodies, and decreasing env antibodies (choice B) is not correct, because as CD4-positive cells decline, there is decreasing ability for isotype switching, and p24 antibodies will decline because they are IgG in isotype. Envelope antibodies will remain stable or increase slightly, not decrease. Increasing p24, virus, and RNA, stable CD4 cells, increasing p24 antibodies, and decreasing env antibodies (choice C) is not correct because in untreated cases CD4 counts will decline consistently until death. Decreasing p24, virus, and RNA, normal CD4 cells, no change in p24 antibodies, and no change in env antibodies (choice D) is not correct because untreated cases do not self-resolve, and decreasing amounts of virus constituents in the blood would indicate that the patient's condition is improving. Undetectable p24, virus, and RNA, normal CD4 cells, decreasing p24 antibodies, and increasing env antibodies (choice E) is not correct, because, again, it suggests that the patient has resolved his infection by removing all the virus constituents from the blood. This does not happen in the absence of anti-retroviral therapy.

question: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of dysmenorrhea and lower abdominal tenderness. A pelvic examination shows adnexal tenderness and a mucopurulent discharge without blood Examination of cervical cells shows intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies when stained with Giemsa stain. Which of the following properties is characteristic of the most likely causal organism?
options: A. It has sterols in its membrane
B. It lacks a cell wall
C. Its cell membrane contains ergosterol
D. Its cell wall contains mycolic acids
E. It uses an elementary body to infect cells
explanation: The correct answer is E. This young woman is infected with Chlamydia trachomatis the most common bacterial sexually transmitted disease in the United States. This genus of organisms is unusual in that they do not make ATP and are thus obligate intracellular parasites, and they possess a cell wall in which muramic acid is missing from the peptidoglycan. Chlamydia species utilize an elementary body to infect host cells and a reticulate body to replicate within host cells. It has sterols in its membrane (choice A) is a statement that describes the mycoplasmas. These are the only prokaryotes that totally lack a cell wall, but instead have sterols in their membranes. It lacks a cell wall (choice B) is also a statement that describes the mycoplasmas. These prokaryotes are devoid of a cell wall but have sterols in their membranes. Its cell membrane contains ergosterol (choice C) is a statement that describes the fungi. The ergosterol molecule is unique to fungi and is the target molecule for nystatin and the imidazoles. A cell wall containing mycolic acids (choice D) describes the genus Mycobacterium. Mycolic acids are long-chain fatty acids that give this group its resistance to environmental stresses and its acid-fast staining characteristics.

question: A 28-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician because of recurrent growth of a whitish film on his tongue and buccal mucosa. There is no evidence of esophageal involvement. A scraping of the lesion is placed in a test tube containing animal serum and the results of this evaluation are shown in the photomicrograph. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug of choice for this patient's illness?
options: A. It blocks ergosterol synthesis by inhibiting squalene epoxidase
B. It inhibits the CYP450—dependent enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase
C. It inhibits the synthesis of beta-glucan
D. It interferes with mitotic spindle function
E. It interferes with thymidylate synthetase and DNA synthesis
explanation: The correct answer is B. This is a case of oral thrush, an overgrowth of the oral cavity with Candida albicans which is a normal flora organism that commonly causes problems in immunosuppressed patients. The image shown is that of the germ-tube test, the formation of pseudohyphae in animal serum, which is considered a definitive diagnostic for the organism. In HIV-infected individuals, oral and/or pharyngeal candidiasis infections are generally treated with clotrimazole troches or fluconazole oral tablets. Fluconazole acts as an inhibitor of the fungal cytochrome P-450 dependent enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase. In a fungus, lanosterol 14-α-demethylase functions to convert lanosterol to ergosterol. This is responsible for the fungistatic effect of the “conazole” antifungals. Terbinafine blocks ergosterol synthesis (choice A). This agent is primarily used to treat dermatophytic infections, particularly tinea unguium. The echinocandins, such as caspofungin, inhibit the synthesis of beta-glucan (choice C). These agents are indicated for invasive candidiasis, not simple oral thrush. Caspofungin can also be used in the treatment of oral/esophageal candidiasis, however this agent would be used only for simple oral candidiasis when therapy with fluconazole alone does not effectively treat the patients oropharyngeal candidiasis. Griseofulvin interferes with mitotic spindle function (choice D). This agent is primarily used orally against dermatophytes, as it concentrates in the stratum corneum. Flucytosine interferes with thymidylate synthetase (choice E). This agent is used in the treatment of cryptococcosis. It is contraindicated in HIV patients, as it may cause bone marrow suppression in those patients.

question: A medical virology laboratory coinfects cells in a tissue culture flask with influenza A (H3N2) and influenza A (H1N1). The flask is incubated for 48 hours and the progeny viruses are analyzed. Four distinct variants of influenza A are isolated: H3N2, H1N1, H3N1, and H1N2 Which of the following viral attributes most likely made the production of H3N1 and H1N2 variants possible?
explanation: The correct answer is D. Influenza A is well known for its ability to undergo genetic shift or reassortment of the pieces of its segmented genome. Because the genome of this RNA virus occurs in eight separate segments, random rearrangements can occur when two related viruses infect a single cell. The packaging of the progeny viruses can then become drastically changed, and pandemics can result in the population due to the sudden appearance of new antigenic types. There have been four major pandemics of influenza since 1933. Genetic shift can occur only in viruses with segmented genomes (separate pieces of RNA that can be exchanged in the progeny). There are four families of viruses with segmented genomes: Reovirus, Orthomyxovirus, Bunyavirus, and Arenavirus. Complementation (choice A) is the process by which two related viruses that have gene defects can “complement” each other when coinfecting a cell, and thereby produce progeny by the sharing of gene products. A variation of this process happens in the case of the delta agent infecting cells coinfected with the hepatitis B virus. The genome of the delta agent is defective in its ability to capture an envelope itself, but when it exists in the same cell as the hepatitis B virus, it can use the hepatitis B envelope-capturing gene to surround itself with an envelope and complete its lifecycle. High mutational rate (choice B) refers to minor antigenic changes based on random mutations, and is a potential cause of genetic drift in virus infections. Although genetic drift due to mutational change can happen in virtually any reproducing organism, it is most common in RNA viruses. It is best described as a mechanism for causing antigenic drift in the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Phenotypic mixing (choice C) is the process by which two related viruses coexisting in a single cell can create a generation of progeny with components of both viruses making up their capsids. The genomes are not altered, but the capsid consists of components of both parental viruses. Syncytia formation (choice E) is the property of forming multinucleated giant cells during viral infection. Fusing one infected cell to the uninfected cell next door allows some viruses to move within the host without being exposed to immunologic products outside the cell. Syncytia formation is a common mechanism of immunologic evasion in the Herpesvirus family, in measles, mumps, and in respiratory syncytial virus infections.

question: A 73-year-old woman with a history of diabetes comes to the physician because of left ear pain and drainage of pus from the ear canal. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness over the left mastoid bone. The most likely causal organism is also responsible for causing which of the following?
explanation: The correct answer is A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa causes malignant otitis externa which is a severe necrotizing infection of the external ear canal. Infection tends to spread to the mastoid bone, temporal bone, sigmoid sinus, base of the skull, meninges, and brain. Patients at increased risk include the elderly, people with diabetes, and the immunocompromised. Pseudomonas is also associated with many other clinical syndromes, including infection following traumatic wounds to the feet in persons wearing sneakers or rubber-soled shoes (since the organism can be cultured from the shoes), burn infections, and pneumonia in cystic fibrosis patients.
