question: A 54-year-old man who is a farmer in rural Pennsylvania comes to the physician because of a chronic cough. A chest x-ray shows a mass lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy. Examination of tissue obtained on biopsy of the mass shows multiple tiny oval forms within macrophages. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The correct answer is C. Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus that grows as a mold in the wild but as a tiny yeast inside macrophages in humans. The disease is typically asymptomatic or mild enough to go undetected, but when symptomatic it presents with cough, fever and malaise. It is commonly seen in geographic areas surrounding the central riverbeds of the United States. The primary and secondary treatments of choice for uncomplicated histoplasmosis are itraconazole and fluconazole, respectively. More serious cases are treated with amphotericin B. Blastomycosis (choice A) is characterized by a larger, round, budding yeast form, seen free in the tissues. Coccidioidomycosis (choice B) is seen mainly in the desert parts of the southwestern United States. In the lungs, spherules containing endospores are seen. Paracoccidioidomycosis (choice D) is endemic in Latin America, especially in Brazil. The infected cells show a typical 'pilot's wheel' appearance due to multiple yeasts sprouting out of a single parent cell. Sporotrichosis (choice E) most often produces a localized cutaneous infection, following inoculation occurring in association with minor skin trauma during gardening.

question: A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of multiple blister-like lesions on the glans of the penis. He has had 2 episodes of similar symptoms during the past 2 years. Physical examination shows tender, 3-to-4-mm vesicles on the shaft of the penis with no crusting, drainage, or bleeding There is also mild bilateral inguinal adenopathy Which of the following best describes the most likely causal agent?
options: A. The agent becomes latent in B cells
B. The agent becomes latent in mononuclear cells
C. The agent becomes latent in the dorsal root ganglia
D. The agent becomes latent in the sacral ganglia
E. The agent becomes latent in trigeminal ganglia
explanation: The correct answer is D. This is a classic example of an infection with herpes simplex virus (HSV, probably type 2). This agent causes lytic infections in mucoepithelial cells. It then moves by retrograde transport into neurons of the sacral ganglia, where it lies dormant during the asymptomatic phase of the disease. The Tzanck smear is a diagnostic test involving the touching of a microscope slide to a vesicular lesion. Multinucleated giant cells will be lifted off onto the slide and can be stained and identified as having a herpesvirus origin. B cells (choice A) are the site of latency for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Mononuclear cells (choice B) are the site of latency for cytomegalovirus (CMV). The dorsal root ganglia (choice C) are the sites of latency for varicella zoster virus (VZV), the causative agent of chickenpox and shingles. Since the present lesions are on the genitalia, the virus would move into latency in the sacral ganglia, not the trigeminal ganglia (choice E). HSV introduced into the oral mucosa becomes latent in the trigeminal ganglia.

question: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of crampy abdominal pain, nausea, and mild diarrhea for the past 2 weeks. Her mother states that the girl vomited a 10-cm (4-inch) long cylindrical white worm 24 hours ago. Which of the following best describes the most likely route of infection in this patient?
options: B. Ingestion of cysts in contaminated water
C. Ingestion of eggs from an infected pet
D. Ingestion of eggs from human feces
explanation: The correct answer is D. This is a case of Ascaris lumbricoides infection, the only helminth infection caused by a cylindrical white worm of this remarkably large size. It is acquired directly with no intermediate host, from fecal contamination from other human beings, and the stage of the life cycle that is transmitted is the egg. Autoinfection (choice A) is a rare occurrence in helminthic infections, possible only with Strongyloides stercoralis (the threadworm), Enterobius vermicularis (the pinworm), and Taenia solium (the pork tapeworm). Ingestion of cysts in contaminated water (choice B) is the normal mechanism of infection used by intestinal protozoa. There are no helminthic infections in the United States that are transmitted via cysts in water. Ingestion of eggs from an infected pet (choice C) occurs in visceral larva migrans when the ascarids of dogs and cats infect the human, an aberrant host. It would never result in the introduction of an adult worm into the vomitus, as described here. Mosquito transmission of larvae (choice E) is a means of transmission of the filarial nematodes, none of which are found in the United States and none of which would be found in vomitus. Skin penetration of larvae (choice F) is the mechanism of infection used by hookworms, threadworms, and schistosomes. None of these helminths would fit the description of the worm that was recovered in this case, since none of these is larger than 1 cm in length.

question: A 16-year-old girl who is an exchange student from Panama is brought to the emergency department by her host family because of a high-grade fever and delirium She has had 2 episodes of similar symptoms during the past 2 years. A peripheral blood smear shows Schüffner dots in enlarged erythrocytes containing oval bodies. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is E. The description of Schüffner dots tells us this patient is infected with Plasmodium vivax or ovale malaria. Schüffner dots are morphologic changes that occur in infected host erythrocytes, are visible by light microscopy in Romanovsky-stained blood smears, and appear as multiple brick-red dots. Both P. vivax and P. ovale (choice D) are capable of causing relapse following recovery from the primary infection. Both organisms leave dormant forms in the liver, called hypnozoites. Of these two, however, only P. vivax occurs in the western hemisphere. P. falciparum and P. malariae (choices B and C) do not possess these dormant forms and thus are incapable of causing relapses, but if drug treatment of the erythrocytic stages is inadequate the symptoms can 'recrudesce' due to renewed multiplication in the bloodstream. Relapses and recrudescences look the same symptomatically, because once parasites begin multiplying again in the bloodstream, the cyclic fevers return. Babesia microti (choice A) causes malaria-like symptoms and is transmitted by the same tick that spreads Lyme disease. It does not occur in Panama.

question: A 23-year-old man develops dehydration, and profuse, watery diarrhea 3 weeks after arriving in Mexico. He continues to have diarrhea despite not eating. Qualitative analysis of stool shows few leukocytes, trace mucus, and no blood. The causal agent produces a toxin with a mechanism of action that is closest to the mechanism of action of which of the following?
options: A. Alpha toxin of Staphylococcus aureus
C. Exotoxin A of Pseudomonas aeruginosa
D. Labile toxin of Escherichia coli
explanation: The correct answer is D. This is cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae. The voluminous 'rice-water' stools described in the question result from the action of the cholera enterotoxin. Cholera enterotoxin acts by activating adenylate cyclase by ADP ribosylation of a GTP-binding protein in small intestinal crypt cells, turning on massive secretion of isotonic fluid. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli produce a toxin very similar to cholera toxin, the heat-labile toxin. The alpha toxin of Staphylococcus aureus (choice A) is a pore-forming toxin that punches holes in cellular membranes. Diphtheria toxin (choice B) acts by ribosylating eukaryotic elongation factor-2 and thereby inhibiting eukaryotic protein synthesis. Its binding component targets heart, nerve, and epithelial cells. Exotoxin A of Pseudomonas aeruginosa (choice C) acts very similarly to the diphtheria toxin, inhibiting elongation factor-2, but targeting liver cells. Pertussis toxin (choice E) causes edema by ADP-ribosylating Gi, the inhibitory subunit of G protein, thus increasing cyclic AMP. Verotoxin (choice F) is produced by enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli and acts in a mechanism similar to that of the Shiga toxin, shutting down eukaryotic protein synthesis by clipping the 60S ribosomal subunit.

question: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a severe headache and a fever She has a history of hydrocephalus and underwent a revision of a ventricular-peritoneal shunt 1 month ago. Gram stain of the shunt exudate shows gram-positive cocci that are catalase-positive and coagulase-negative. Which of the following is the most important pathogenic property of the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The most common cause of infections involving catheters and prosthetic devices is Staphylococcus epidermidis. Materials left in the body for prolonged periods of time are almost always coated with Teflon™, which is so slippery that most organisms cannot adhere and cause infections there. S. epidermidis is capable of initiating infection even on Teflon-coated surfaces because it produces a biofilm that alters the surface tension of liquids around itself. Endotoxin production (choice B) is not an attribute of S. epidermidis. Endotoxin, or lipopolysaccharide is a component of the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria. S. epidermidis is a gram-positive organism. Intracellular habitat (choice C) is not an attribute of S. epidermidis. Staphylococci are extracellular bacteria. Novobiocin resistance (choice D) is exhibited by S. saprophyticus but not S. epidermidis, and it is a diagnostic aid, not a pathogenicity factor. Superantigen action (choice E) is expressed by the exotoxins of Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes, but it does not contribute to the pathogenesis of S. epidermidis.

question: A 3-year-old boy who attends a large daycare facility suddenly develops a fever vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. When he is brought to the emergency department three days later, he has more than 10 bowel movements per day, and mucus, blood and pus are seen in the stool. He has developed weight loss and severe dehydration. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is C. The child has shigellosis (bacillary dysentery), which is an acute infection of the bowel that can be caused by a variety of Shigella organisms, including S. flexneri, S. sonnei (the most common isolate in the United States), S. boydii, and S. dysenteriae. The organism is spread via the fecal-oral route by contaminated food or inanimate objects; spread in contaminated water is unusual. Epidemics commonly occur in crowded populations with poor sanitation. Mini-epidemics have occurred in the daycare setting. The presentation given here is typical; adults may have a slower presentation. Diagnosis is important because untreated children may die (of dehydration and circulatory collapse) in the first 12 days. Fluid replacement is the most critical aspect of therapy and may require IV fluids in severe cases. The condition resolves spontaneously; use of antibiotics (TMP-SMX) may shorten duration. Bacillus anthracis (choice A) causes anthrax, which can produce skin infection and pneumonia. Salmonella enterica subspecies typhi (choice B) causes typhoid fever, which differs from shigellosis because it is an enteric fever with more prominent systemic symptoms. Vibrio cholerae (choice D) causes cholera, with characteristic 'rice-water stool' diarrhea. Yersinia pestis (choice E) causes plague, with prominent lymph node and lung involvement.

question: A 17-year-old girl develops the skin lesion shown after being badly burned in an automobile accident. Culture of the lesions grows an organism with a blue-green pigment and a fruity odor. Which of the following best describes the most likely causal organism?
options: A. A gram-negative, oxidase-positive, aerobic rod
B. A gram-positive, aerobic, spore-forming rod
C. A gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming rod
explanation: The correct answer is A. This is a case of ecthyma gangrenosum, the hallmark lesion of Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection. It is a common nosocomial infection in patients with cystic fibrosis, neutropenia, or severe burns. P. aeruginosa is a gram-negative rod that is oxidase-positive, aerobic (a nonfermenter), and catalase-positive. It is a prodigious producer of a capsule (slime layer) and is also distinguished by its production of a blue-green pigment and a grapelike odor. Bacillus is a gram-positive aerobic, spore-forming rod (choice B). Superficially, the skin lesion of anthrax (the anthrax eschar) might resemble the lesion caused by Pseudomonas but would not be a common finding in burn patients and indeed is quite rare in the United States. Clostridium is an anaerobic, spore-forming, gram-positive rod (choice C). Clostridium would not be a common pathogen in burn patients and would not cause such a lesion. A gram-positive, coagulase-negative coccus (choice D) could be Staphylococcus epidermidis, Staph. saprophyticus or any of the members of the genus Streptococcus. None of these agents would be likely to produce a lesion such as the one shown. Staph. epidermidis is a member of the normal skin flora and is best known for its ability to colonize intravenous catheters and the endocardium via its production of a biofilm. Staph. saprophyticus is best known as an agent of urinary tract infection in young, sexually active women, and the streptococci cause a wide variety of diseases, such as pharyngitis, meningitis, cellulitis, and endocarditis. Staph. aureus is a gram-positive coagulase-positive coccus (choice E). It is a member of the normal skin flora and causes abscesses, furuncles and boils, but not the lesion shown in the image here.

question: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a fever, sore throat, and rash. Physical examination shows swollen, bright-red tonsils, enlarged anterior cervical lymph nodes, and a diffuse, erythematous, symmetrical rash that has a slightly rough, sandpaper-like texture. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the skin rash?
explanation: The correct answer is E. The rash described is that of scarlet fever, which can be a complication of streptococcal sore throat (as in this question) or streptococcal wound infection. In past centuries, scarlet fever was a major childhood disease that often caused death, but it has become much less common (possibly as a result of early antibiotic therapy) and is now only a rare cause of death. The fever and rash in this disease are due to the pyrogenic exotoxin, which is phage-encoded. The alpha toxins (choice A) of Staphylococcus aureus and Clostridium perfringens are cytolysins. The alpha toxin of S. aureus is a pore former, and that of C. perfringens is a lecithinase. Endotoxin (choice B) is found in gram-negative organisms. Endotoxin directly activates macrophages to overproduce IL-1, IL-6 and TNF-α, and causes gram-negative shock. Hyaluronic acid capsule and M protein (choices C and D) are both found in Streptococcus pyogenes, but are not responsible for the fever and rash seen in the present case. The hyaluronic acid capsule is non-immunogenic and makes it difficult for the immune system to recognize the infection. M protein is an anti-phagocytic surface protein.

question: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of diffuse muscle weakness and palpitations. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 137/62 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mydriasis. Which of the following agents is the most likely cause of the findings seen in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Botulism is caused by a protein toxin produced by the gram-positive, spore-forming, obligate anaerobe Clostridium botulinum. Botulinum toxin type A is also available commercially as the compound OnabotulinumtoxinA. Botulinum toxin selectively cleaves the docking proteins for acetylcholine (ACh) exocytosis. As a result, there is decreased ACh transmission in all parasympathetic neuroeffector junctions and decreased sympathetic cholinergic transmission in sweat glands and neuromuscular junctions. Mydriasis is a result of decreased ACh activity on muscarinic receptors in parasympathetic neuroeffector junctions. Skeletal muscle weakness results from decreased ACh stimulation of nicotinic receptors in neuromuscular junctions. Skeletal muscle weakness is the differentiating feature between anticholinergic agents (i.e., atropine) and botulinum toxin. Serious adverse effects of botulinum toxin type A include respiratory compromise, development or worsening of acute angle-closure glaucoma, brachial plexopathy, dysphonia, muscle weakness, and anticholinergic side effects. Atropine (choice A), a muscarinic receptor antagonist, causes tachycardia, mydriasis, and elevated body temperature but does not cause muscle weakness. Ephedrine (choice C) is an indirect sympathomimetic and causes tachycardia, mydriasis, and possibly elevated body temperature from increased metabolic rate. It would not cause diffuse muscle weakness, however. Phenelzine (choice D), an MAO inhibitor, would also enhance the sympathetic system but with no effects on skeletal muscle. Succinylcholine (choice E), a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, causes muscle weakness but none of the other symptoms.

question: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a rash. His mother says the rash began with several small vesicles on his calves and ankles. The child lives in the suburbs and often plays outside in shorts. Physical examination shows no abnormalities except for golden-brown and crusted lesions with an erythematous base, that are in various stages of healing Which of the following laboratory tests is most appropriate to identify the genus of causal organism of this disease?
explanation: The correct answer is B. This is likely a case of Streptococcus pyogenes impetigo, based on the description of golden-crusted lesions. The other major cause of impetigo is Staphylococcus aureus and these two genera are distinguished on the basis of the catalase test. Staphylococcus is catalase-positive and Streptococcus is catalase-negative. The CAMP test (choice A) is the test used to distinguish the group B streptococci from other streptococci. It would not be useful here. The ELEK test (choice C) is the immunodiffusion test used to identify toxin-producing strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Gram stain (choice D) would not be useful, as both of the most common agents of impetigo are gram-positive cocci. The oxidase test (choice E) is the test used to identify Neisseria, Pseudomonas, and Vibrio and distinguish them from members of the family Enterobacteriaceae; it would not be useful here.

question: Several children and adults who recently fled a detention camp come to the emergency department because of a sore throat and low-grade fever. Physical examination of the buccal and nasal mucosa shows an adherent membrane. Gram stain of the oral secretions from most of the patients shows gram-positive rods. The toxins produced by the causal organism most likely interfere with which of the following?
explanation: The correct answer is E. Although now rare in the United States due to vaccination programs, diphtheria is a serious disease with fatality rates between 5 and 10% in adults. The disease is an upper respiratory tract infection characterized by sore throat, low-grade fever, and an adherent pseudomembrane on the tonsil, pharynx, and/or nose. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, a facultatively anaerobic gram-positive bacterium. Diphtheria toxin inactivates eukaryotic elongation factor-2 (eEF-2) in eukaryotic cells via ADP-ribosylation. The inactivation of eEF-2 inhibits cell protein synthesis in eukaryotic cells. This directly affects translation elongation. Corynebacterium diphtheriae toxin primarily targets the heart, nerves, and epithelium. Transcription initiation (choice A) and elongation (choice B) may be affected by drugs that target RNA polymerase, such as rifampin. These drugs are mainly used for mycobacteria. Transcription termination (choice C) is usually determined by chromatin structure, such as pin-loops. It is not generally easily targeted for inhibition by toxins or drugs. Translation initiation (choice D) may be affected by certain antimicrobials such as aminoglycosides. Translation termination (choice F) is not generally a target of toxins.

question: A 2-year-old boy is diagnosed with urinary tract obstruction and undergoes surgical correction. An indwelling urinary catheter is in place and two days later, the patient develops a urinary tract infection. Cultures of the urine grow non-lactose fermenting, oxidase-positive, gram-negative rods. The most likely causal organism also causes which of the following illnesses?
options: E. Staghorn calculi in the urinary tract
explanation: The correct answer is B. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative rod that produces blue-green pigments. It can easily be distinguished from the family Enterobacteriaceae because Pseudomonas is oxidase-positive. It is an opportunistic pathogen that has an increased chance of causing urinary tract infections (UTIs) in patients who have indwelling catheters or who are on antibiotics. Pseudomonas is an agent of hot-tub folliculitis in normal patients using contaminated spas, and causes infections in burn patients and pneumonia in patients with cystic fibrosis. Esophagitis in AIDS patients (choice A) can be caused by Candida albicans. This is a yeast that can cause urinary tract infections in poorly controlled diabetics because glucose in the urine enhances its growth. Neonatal septicemia (choice C) is most frequently caused by Streptococcus agalactiae, Escherichia coli or Listeria monocytogenes. Of these, S. agalactiae is a gram-positive coccus and L. monocytogenes is a gram-positive rod; and although E. coli is a gram-negative rod, it is oxidase-negative and lactose-fermenting. E. coli is the most common cause of UTI overall. Pneumonia in AIDS patients (choice D) is caused by a variety of organisms, including Histoplasma capsulatum, Coccidioides immitis, Blastomyces dermatitidis and Pneumocystis jiroveci. None of these is a gram-negative bacillus. Staghorn calculi in the urinary tract (choice E) are formed during infections with urease-positive organisms such as Proteus and Ureaplasma. Proteus is a gram-negative rod but is oxidase-negative, and Ureaplasma is a cell wall-less prokaryote related to Mycoplasma that would not stain at all with Gram stain.

question: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intense, burning pain upon urination. Treatment with ampicillin is begun. One week later, she returns to the physician because of fever and flank pain. Her temperature is 40.0°C (104.0°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 90/30 mm Hg Blood cultures grow gram-negative, lactose-fermenting bacilli. Which of the following virulence factors is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
explanation: The correct answer is C. Septic shock is a feared, potentially fatal complication of systemic infection with a wide variety of gram-negative organisms. The primary toxic agent is the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in the gram-negative bacterial cell wall. Further, it has been established that the most toxic part of the LPS is lipid A. The pathophysiologic effects of LPS are related to triggering the release of potent cytokines (interleukin [IL]-1, IL-6, and tumor necrosis factor) from macrophages and activation of coagulation cascades. Common core polysaccharide (choice A) is a portion of the LPS that is the same in all gram-negative bacteria. The polysaccharide component of LPS is the immunogenic component. It is not the most important factor in pathogenesis. Lecithinase (choice B) is an enzyme produced by Clostridium perfringens that damages cell membranes. O-specific polysaccharide (choice D) is a portion of the LPS that induces specific immunity. Peptidoglycan (choice E) is found in both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, and can be indirectly linked to LPS.

question: A 30-year-old man who has a history of HIV infection and intravenous drug use has been treated with HAART therapy over the past 4 years. The infection has not responded to several combinations of treatment. Laboratory studies show a progressively declining CD4 count. Over the next several days, he develops diarrhea and a fever An acid-fast stain of the stool reveals thick-walled oval structures that are 4-6 microns in diameter Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
explanation: The correct answer is B. This patient became symptomatic with prolonged diarrhea, which is common in AIDS patients. All of the agents on the list are common causes of diarrhea in AIDS, but the only one that would produce acid-fast oocysts of this size in the stool is Cryptosporidium. Adenovirus (choice A) is a viral cause of diarrhea in AIDS. Viruses are minute in size compared to bacteria and eukaryotes, and would not be visible by standard microscopy of the stool. Listeria (choice C) is a gram-positive bacterium. Most bacteria measure less than 2 microns in size. Mycobacterium avium complex (choice D) commonly presents in AIDS patients with diarrhea, fever, and wasting. Although the organism is acid-fast, it is a bacterium that is intracellular, and as such its size is much smaller than that of a eukaryote. Salmonella (choice E) is a common cause of diarrhea in AIDS, but it is a gram-negative, oxidase-negative bacterium that would be about 2 μm in diameter.

question: A newborn who is born at 38 weeks' gestation is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit because of respiratory distress One day later she develops a fever and persistent dyspnea and cough. Examination of sputum shows numerous neutrophils and gram-negative rods that grow pink colonies on MacConkey agar, Which of the following is the most important pathogenic feature of the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is D. This child has neonatal infection with Escherichia coli. The most important pathogenic attribute of the strains that cause neonatal disease is the K1 capsule that prevents phagocytosis. Most of the strains that cause this have the K1 serotype. E. coli is the most common gram-negative rod that infects children from maternal contamination as they pass through the birth canal. Beta hemolysis (choice A) is an attribute of some strains of urotropic E. coli but is not a major factor in the pathogenesis of E. coli neonatal disease. Biofilm production (choice B) is an attribute of Staphylococcus epidermidis, Streptococcus mutans and enteroaggregative E. coli, but is not believed to be involved in the pathogenesis of E. coli neonatal disease. Exotoxin production (choice C) is involved in enterotoxigenic E. coli and enterohemorrhagic E. coli pathogenesis, but is not believed to be involved in the pathogenesis of E. coli neonatal disease. Motility (choice E) is an important pathogenic mechanism among the agents of urinary tract infection because it gives them the ability to enter the bladder against the flow of urine. It is not believed to be important in the pathogenesis of neonatal disease caused by E. coli.

question: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a fever and severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain A diagnosis of appendicitis is made and a laparotomy is performed. The appendix is found to be normal but the mesenteric lymph nodes are markedly enlarged and contain focal areas of microabscesses. A specimen from the patient's abdomen is streaked for isolation and shows gram-negative rods that grow at 22°C (71.6°F). By which of the following means was the pathogen most likely acquired?
explanation: The correct answer is C. This child has pseudoappendicitis, and Yersinia enterocolitica is the pathogen that produces this clinical syndrome. Yersinia is transmitted to patients via the oral route, most commonly from contaminated milk, and occasionally, from blood transfusion. Y. enterocolitica is associated with cooler climates since it grows well at less than body temperature. Arthropod vectors (choice A) are not involved in transmission of Y. enterocolitica. Arthropods such as ticks transmit tularemia, Rocky Mountain spotted fever and Lyme disease. Insects such as mosquitoes transmit viral encephalitides and malaria. Contaminated ground beef (choice B) is involved in the transmission of enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC), but is not a common source of infection with Y. enterocolitica. Dog bite (choice D) is not involved in the transmission of Y. enterocolitica. Dogs may transmit rabies, Capnocytophaga or Pasteurella. Endogenous transmission (choice E) is important in the formation of intestinal abscesses by anaerobic normal flora organisms, but is not believed to be involved with Y. enterocolitica transmission.

question: A 12-year-old boy has a productive cough characterized by large volumes of foul-smelling sputum. He has a history of pancreatic insufficiency and steatorrhea. Cultures of the sputum grow colorless, oxidase-positive colonies with a fruity aroma on blood agar Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of the exotoxin produced by the causal organism?
options: A. Activation of macrophages to produce proinflammatory cytokines
C. Block release of GABA and glycine
explanation: The correct answer is E. This boy is displaying the characteristic symptoms of cystic fibrosis with bronchiectasis (accounting for the foul-smelling sputum) and pancreatic insufficiency producing steatorrhea. However, the question directly relates to the infectious agent causing the pneumonia, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, an oxidase-positive bacterium with a fruity aroma. Pseudomonas produces blue-green pigments that act as siderophores when grown in an iron-limited environment, but are often colorless on blood agar. P. aeruginosa is a strictly aerobic, gram-negative rod that produces an exotoxin (exotoxin A) that ADP-ribosylates, and therefore inhibits, eukaryotic elongation factor-2 (eEF-2), which is a G protein involved in the eukaryotic translation of proteins. Activation of macrophages to produce proinflammatory cytokines (choice A) is the mechanism by which lipopolysaccharide (LPS) causes damage. This is an endotoxin and is not to be confused with an exotoxin. Blocking release of acetylcholine (choice B) is specific for Clostridium botulinum which produces a neurotoxin that causes a flaccid paralysis. Blocking release of GABA and glycine (choice C) is specific for Clostridium tetani which produces a neurotoxin that causes a spastic paralysis. Increasing levels of cAMP (choice D) refers to the toxins of enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC), Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis and Bacillus anthracis. These exotoxins each increase cellular fluid loss, leading to the causation of edema or diarrhea.

question: A 23-year-old woman who is a veterinary student comes to the physician because of fatigue and malaise. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F) Physical examination shows pronounced cervical lymphadenopathy Laboratory studies show moderate lymphocytosis She is 3 months pregnant with her first child Transmission of the infection to the fetus is most likely to result in which of the following sequelae?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Toxoplasma gondii is capable of crossing the placenta and causing harmful fetal infection only during an acute maternal infection. During this period, rapidly dividing forms called tachyzoites can be spread via the bloodstream and thus cross the placenta. As soon as the maternal immune response is initiated, parasitemia ceases and the parasite can no longer enter the fetus. In a patient such as this one, occupational exposure to cats (the definitive host of the parasite) might be assumed. In the general U.S. population, however, it is more common to acquire the infection from poorly cooked pork. When the organism infects the mother in the first trimester of pregnancy there is little risk of fetal infection, but infections that do occur often involve serious damage to the central nervous system, e.g. necrotizing encephalitis, or disseminated disease. When the organism infects the mother in later trimesters the fetus has a greater likelihood of infection, but most of those infections will be asymptomatic. Hydrops fetalis (choice A) is a common consequence of fetal infection with the B19 virus, which infects immature erythrocytes. It may occur following in utero infection with Toxoplasma but it is not the most common sequela. Patent ductus arteriosus (choice C) and pulmonary stenosis (choice D) are aspects of congenital rubella syndrome, caused when rubella virus crosses the placenta. Retinochoroiditis (choice E) is a consequence of infection of second- and third-trimester fetuses with Toxoplasma gondii. It may also occur 20 to 30 years after birth in children born with asymptomatic Toxoplasma infections.

question: A 1-week-old newborn has irritability, fever and is developing stupor. A lumbar puncture is performed and examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows large numbers of neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely causal agent?
options: B. Double-stranded DNA virus with nuclear membrane envelope
explanation: The correct answer is F. The clinical presentation and lumbar puncture suggests meningitis. The presence of numerous neutrophils in the cerebrospinal fluid suggests a bacterial pathogen. The most common cause of neonatal meningitis is Streptococcus agalactiae, which is a gram-positive coccus. Acid-fast bacillus (choice A) describes a bacterium in the genus Mycobacterium. These bacteria are not causes of neonatal meningitis. Double-stranded DNA virus with nuclear membrane envelope (choice B) describes a virus in the herpesvirus family. Herpesviruses may cause encephalitis in newborns but would not be a likely cause of meningitis in this age group. A gram-negative bacillus (choice C) describes Escherichia coli among many others. E. coli is the second most common cause of neonatal meningitis. Gram-negative diplococcus (choice D) describes the genera Neisseria, Moraxella and Veillonella. Of these, Neisseria meningitidis causes meningitis, but usually in adolescents and young adults. It would not be the most common cause of a neonatal presentation such as this one. Gram-positive bacillus (choice E) describes Listeria monocytogenes among others. Listeria is the third most common cause of neonatal meningitis in the United States.

question: A 43-year-old man with a history of polysubstance abuse and psychosis is involuntarily admitted to the hospital because of persistent bloody diarrhea for the past 1 week Qualitative analysis of stool shows spherical, quadrinucleate, thin-walled cysts measuring 10-20 μm in diameter. Infection with which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
explanation: The correct answer is C. Entamoeba histolytica may produce asymptomatic infection or more severe disease characterized by mucosal ulcerations and submucosal spread causing abdominal distress and bloody stools. Stools may show either trophozoite forms or the typical spherical cysts. E. histolytica cysts characteristically are spherical in shape, are 10-20 μm in diameter and have granular cytoplasm containing up to four nuclei. Cryptosporidium parvum (choice A) infections occur in the immunocompromised population and may cause severe diarrhea. The organism presents as minute (2-5 μm) intracellular spheres or arc-shaped merozoites under normal mucosa, and can be difficult to see by light microscopy. Cysts in the stool are too small (4-5 μm) to be confused with Entamoeba. Dientamoeba fragilis (choice B) is an intestinal ameba that also may produce an infectious diarrhea. It does not have a cyst form, and only the trophozoite forms are seen in stools. Giardia lamblia (choice D) is a flagellate protozoan that infects the stomach and small intestine when contaminated water is ingested. Diagnosis is usually made by examining duodenal contents; however, the stools may contain the oval or elliptical cysts, which are thick-walled and measure 8-14 μm in diameter. Spherical cysts are not seen in Giardia infection, and giardial diarrheas are not bloody. Isospora belli (choice E) produces self-limited intestinal infections, mostly in the tropics, in which fever and diarrhea may last weeks to months. The stool-borne cysts are much larger than Entamoeba (30 by 15 μm), are asymmetrical, and are typically almond-shaped.

question: A 27-year-old man develops a fever of 38.9°C (102°F) Physical examination shows bilateral parotid gland swelling and orchitis Antibodies against the most likely causal agent are ineffective due to which of the following properties?
explanation: The correct answer is D. The disease is mumps, caused by a paramyxovirus. In children, mumps causes a transient inflammation of the parotid glands, and less commonly, of the testes, pancreas, or central nervous system. Mumps tends to be a more severe disease in adults than in children. Mumps in adults involves the testes (causing orchitis) and pancreas with some frequency. The paramyxoviruses are negative-sense RNA viruses that spread from cell to cell by syncytia formation. This protects them from exposure to substances that exist extracellularly (such as antibodies) and makes cell-mediated immunity an absolutely essential event for recovery and cure. This is why the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine must be live-attenuated, to stimulate strong cell-mediated immunity. Multiple serotypes (choice A) of medical importance do not exist in mumps virus. The vaccine contains a single serotype. A negative-sense genome (choice B) is possessed by the Paramyxoviridae, but this attribute is not associated with the lack of efficacy of antibodies. The negative-sense genome causes these viruses to require a virion-associated polymerase for infectivity. It is true that the mumps virus is spread by respiratory droplets (choice C) - but this attribute does not have a relationship to making antibodies ineffective in cure. Many viruses that are spread by respiratory droplets can be prevented by an adequate IgA or IgG antibody response. Viral hemagglutinin (choice E) in the case of mumps virus exists in a complex with the neuraminidase molecule and thus is not found alone on the surface of the virion. The hemagglutinin-neuraminidase complex is responsible for the attachment to cells via sialic acid residues and the release from the cell following the clipping off of sialic acid residues. Many viruses that have hemagglutinin-neuraminidase complexes on the surface of their membrane can be neutralized by antibodies, so this attribute does not contribute to the need for a cell-mediated immune response.

question: A strain of bacteria that is resistant to ampicillin is placed in a culture containing a lytic bacteriophage. The viral life cycle is allowed fo proceed to completion, and the cultures are centrifuged to pellet the cells and cellular debris. The cell-free supernatant liquid is subjected to a limiting dilution and added to new cultures of the same strain of bacteria that are not ampicillin-resistant. Out of 100 bacterial cultures subsequently tested, two cultures showed ampicillin resistance but failed to show viral cytolysis. Which of the following processes of DNA transfer most likely occurred in these two cultures?
explanation: The correct answer is B. The mechanism involving transfer of bacterial DNA from cell to cell using a lytic phage as a vector is called generalized transduction. It occurs when bacterial DNA is accidentally captured into a phage head during the lytic virus life cycle and then transferred to another bacterial cell. If the recipient cell is capable of homologous recombination of the newly donated DNA, then that cell can acquire new genetic traits that will persist stably in its genome. F+ to F- conjugation (choice A) involves the transfer of a plasmid from one cell to another via cell-to-cell contact. The experimental situation described here does not involve two cells exchanging DNA, but rather a virus picking up DNA from one cell and transferring it to another. Hfr to F- conjugation (choice C) involves the transfer of chromosomal DNA from one cell to another via cell-to-cell contact. The experimental situation described here does not involve two cells exchanging DNA. Homologous recombination (choice D) is a process by which linear DNA that has been delivered into a new cell can be successfully recombined into the chromosome and stabilized for the next generation. It is not a mechanism of transfer of bacterial DNA, but rather a mechanism which allows for the protection of DNA transferred into another cell. Although homologous recombination is a necessary final step in all mechanisms of transfer of bacterial DNA with the exception of the F+ to F- cross, it is not the means by which a virus transfers DNA from cell to cell. Site-specific recombination (choice E) is a process by which circles of DNA may become integrated together. It occurs during the lysogenic viral life cycle, when transposons move within bacterial cells, and during the formation of the Hfr chromosome when a conjugative plasmid inserts itself into the bacterial genome. It is not a mechanism of transfer of DNA from cell to another. Specialized transduction (choice F) is the mechanism by which lysogenic (temperate) phages transfer DNA from one bacterium to another as an accident of the lysogenic viral life cycle. Viruses establish lysogeny by inserting their DNA into the bacterial chromosome by site-specific recombination. Later, if an error of excision occurs during induction, bacterial genes adjacent to the insertion site may be transferred. Since the virus that was added to cultures in this question was a lytic virus, it is not capable of performing this type of transduction. Transformation (choice G) is the process by which free bacterial DNA can be picked up by competent bacteria, imported, and integrated into the chromosome with homologous recombination. No viruses are involved in transformation.

question: A 40-year-old man in New Mexico is brought to the emergency department by family because of severe respiratory distress. His sister says that he developed sudden chills, a fever and headache over the past two days. One day later, he develops chest pain, difficulty breathing, and blood-tinged sputum. An x-ray of the chest shows patchy infiltrates and segmental consolidation Which of the following is the most likely causal organism of this illness?
explanation: The correct answer is E. Any previously healthy person in the Southwestern United States who develops septic shock or severe pulmonary disease should be evaluated for plague. Plague is not an extinct disease but is still encountered in sporadic cases in various places in the world, including Asia, Africa, parts of Europe, and the U.S. Southwest. The causative organism is Yersinia pestis which is endemic in many wild-animal populations and can be transmitted to humans either by direct contact or by flea bite. Human plague may take many forms, including pestis minor (mild lymphadenopathy), bubonic plague (prominent hemorrhagic lymphadenopathy), pneumonic plague (as in this patient), and septicemic plague. The primary pneumonic form typically presents as described. Antibiotics are most effective if given within the first 24 hours, which can be problematic if medical staff does not suspect the disease. Since plague is rare in the United States, a high degree of clinical suspicion is required to make a rapid diagnosis and to institute timely treatment. If the diagnosis is missed, the mortality rate is quite high. Brucella abortus (choice A) causes brucellosis characterized by undulating fever, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Brucellosis occurs rarely in the United States, mainly in slaughterhouse workers, veterinarians and farmers. Clostridium perfringens (choice B) causes gangrene and gastroenteritis. Francisella tularensis (choice C) causes tularemia, which is associated with a spectrum of manifestations from an influenza-like syndrome to adenopathy with ulceration at the site of inoculation. In the United States it occurs most commonly in hunters in Arkansas and Missouri. Listeria monocytogenes (choice D) causes listeriosis. Infection during pregnancy may result in sepsis, abortion, or premature delivery. Infection in the neonate may produce meningitis. In immunocompromised adults, either meningitis or sepsis may occur.

question: The exudate from an abscess is Gram stained and cultured on blood agar The Gram stain reveals purple cocci in large clumps Cultures of the exudate grow beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar that are catalase-positive and coagulase-positive. Which of the mechanisms does the causative agent use to protect itself from phagocytosis?
explanation: The correct answer is E. The tests mentioned reveal a gram-positive coccus with the characteristics of Staphylococcus (gram-positive cocci in grapelike clusters). The organism is beta-hemolytic (breaks hemoglobin down to a colorless product) and catalase-positive (produces water and oxygen gas from the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide). Production of a fibrin clot in a tube of animal serum reveals that the organism is coagulase-positive. The only organism that fits all of these criteria is Staphylococcus aureus. Staph. aureus evades phagocytosis by producing protein A, which binds to the Fc component of IgG, thus preventing opsonization. Capsules (choice A) of bacteria and fungi are antiphagocytic but this is not the means used by S. aureus to evade phagocytosis. Key encapsulated organisms include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenza, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Neisseria meningitidis and Cryptococcus neoformans. Diffuse fimbriate layers (choice B) of gram-positive bacteria such as Streptococcus pyogenes cause adherence to eukaryotic cell surfaces. They do not protect against phagocytosis. IgA proteases (choice C) are produced by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, N. gonorrhoeae, and Haemophilus influenzae. They do not protect against phagocytosis, although they do tend to prevent the bacteria that produce them from immediately being shed from the mucosal surfaces. Inactivation of complement (choice D) is a mechanism used by Strep. pneumoniae to protect itself against opsonization.

question: A 55-year-old man develops watery diarrhea after returning from a vacation at the beach He says that he consumed several meals consisting primarily of seafood, including lobster and raw oysters. Which of the following is most likely fo be isolated from the stool of this patient?
options: A. Gram-negative, curved rods isolated on alkaline medium
B. Gram-negative, curved rods that grow at 42°C (107.6°F)
E. Gram-negative rods, non-lactose fermenters, H₂S-positive
explanation: The correct answer is A. Vibrio vulnificus and V. parahaemolyticus which are contracted by consuming raw oysters, are gram-negative comma-shaped rods that are isolated on alkaline media. Gram-negative curved rods that grow at 42°C (107.6°F) (choice B) describes Campylobacter, which is usually acquired from poultry, not seafood. Gram-negative, nonfermenting rods (choice C) describes Pseudomonas aeruginosa which is acquired from exposure to contaminated water, not from eating undercooked seafood. This infection is often associated with wounds, burns, pneumonia in cystic fibrosis patients, and osteomyelitis in diabetic patients. Gram-negative rods, lactose fermenters (choice D), describes Escherichia coli which is usually associated with salads, unwashed fruits, and hamburger, not with eating undercooked seafood. This bacterium uses the human colon as a reservoir. It is often transmitted via the fecal oral route. Gram-negative rods, non-lactose fermenters, H₂S-positive (choice E) describes Salmonella and Proteus. Salmonella is most commonly acquired from poultry products, and Proteus is associated with urinary tract infections.

question: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of burning on urination and increased urinary frequency. Culture of the urine grows 10⁵ colony-forming units of gram-positive cocci/mL. Sensitivity testing using the Kirby-Bauer agar disc diffusion test shows that the isolate is resistant to ciprofloxacin. Which of the following is the most likely location of this drug-resistance gene?
explanation: The correct answer is A. This patient has cystitis caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus. Quinolones inhibit DNA synthesis, recombination, and repair by inhibiting DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II) and topoisomerase IV. The genes encoding resistance to quinolones are primarily chromosomally encoded and involve mutations in the structural genes for DNA gyrase and topoisomerase type IV. It also involves decreased drug uptake caused by mutations in genes that regulate membrane permeability. Another minor mechanism involved in quinolone resistance, which is encoded by plasmids, consists of the overexpression of a pumping mechanism that actively exports the drug. Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone whose main mechanism of resistance is chromosomally mediated. Conjugative plasmids (choice B) are extrachromosomal circles of DNA that are capable of mediating their own transfer from cell to cell via conjugation. Although they are a very common source of drug-resistance genes, they are not involved in the majority of the cases of resistance to quinolones. Episomes (choice C) are plasmids that have been integrated into the chromosome of the bacterial cell. Genes encoding quinolone resistance are not known to exist in episome form. Nonconjugative plasmids (choice D) are extrachromosomal circles of DNA that do not contain the tra operon. They are not involved in quinolone resistance. Prophages (choice E) are temperate bacteriophages that have integrated their DNA into the chromosome of the bacterial cell. Although abnormal excision can cause bacteriophages of this type to transfer drug-resistance genes the prophage DNA, by itself does not include the drug-resistance genes.

question: A 35-year-old woman who recently emigrated from Africa develops thick, erythematous nodules on the ears and nose with significant associated sensory loss. The nodules have grown slowly over the course of many years. Biopsy of the lesions shows dermal granulomas with giant cells and a few acid-fast bacteria. Cultures on blood agar and Lowenstein-Jensen medium show no growth. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The correct answer is F. Mycobacterium leprae is endemic to parts of Africa, Asia, and South America. Tuberculoid leprosy is an indolent disease, typically affecting cooler parts of the body (such as the nose and ears) producing dermal granulomas with rare, acid-fast bacilli and damage to peripheral nerves. This is in marked contrast to lepromatous leprosy, which is progressive, invasive and generally characterized by the presence of numerous acid-fast bacteria in a histiocytic but nongranulomatous tissue response. M. leprae has not been successfully grown on artificial media. Cutaneous leishmaniasis (choice A) is due to Leishmania species that show a worldwide distribution. The infection is transmitted through a sandfly bite, and the skin lesion is typically ulcerated. Histology shows intracellular parasites within the dermis and epidermis. Granulomas are not formed. Lepromatous leprosy (choice B) is the form of disease when the wrong T-helper (TH) cell is activated. Because TH2 cells stimulate antibody production, they have no value against an intracellular pathogen, and the patient develops disfiguring disseminated disease. Onchocerciasis (choice C) or river blindness, is a roundworm infection transmitted by blackflies of Africa and South America. The microfilariae grow at the site of inoculation and cause an inflamed subcutaneous nodule. The organism is seen on tissue sections. Rhinoscleroma (choice D) is a destructive granulomatous infection of the nasopharynx and is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. Gram-negative rods can be cultured from the lesions. Smallpox (choice E), the infection caused by the variola virus (a DNA poxvirus) produces malaise, headaches, and a macular/pustular rash involving the face and distal extremities. Smallpox has been eradicated through worldwide vaccination.

question: A 50-year-old woman develops a fever headache, chills, and fatigue 1 week after returning from a trip to the woods A peripheral blood smear shows small rings in the red blood cells The vector of this disease can also transmit which of the following organisms?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The combination of a 1-week incubation period and the intraerythrocytic parasites strongly suggests Babesia microti as the infecting organism. The clinical disease is called babesiosis. The infecting protozoan is related to Plasmodium and is transmitted by the bite of the Ixodes scapularis tick. Occasional cases have been transmitted by blood transfusions. Most patients are asymptomatic; symptomatic cases in reasonably healthy individuals have the features described in the question stem. Rare severe cases, which may be fatal, may develop in severely debilitated or asplenic individuals and can be accompanied by severe hemolysis (up to 30% of red blood cells may have the parasites) with subsequent hemoglobinuria, hemolysis, and renal failure. Ixodes ticks are potential vectors of Lyme disease (caused by Borrelia burgdorferi) and Anaplasma (formerly Ehrlichia) phagocytophila (the agent of granulocytic ehrlichiosis). Colorado tick fever virus (choice B), Francisella tularensis (choice C) and Rickettsia rickettsii (choice D) are all transmitted by the Dermacentor tick, not the Ixodes tick. West Nile encephalitis virus (choice E) is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes.

question: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive muscular weakness and poor head control. The mother says that she feeds the boy a soy-based formula sweetened with honey. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is ingestion of which of the following?
explanation: The correct answer is E. This baby has infant botulism (floppy-baby syndrome), which is due to germination of Clostridium botulinum spores in the baby's gastrointestinal tract. This disorder is most common in children under the age of 6 months. Older children and adults do not appear to be vulnerable to this form of botulism, but are susceptible to botulism caused by ingestion of preformed toxin. Floppy-baby syndrome is acquired following the ingestion of spores of the organism. A gram-positive vegetative bacillus (choice A) describes C. botulinum, but it is not ingestion of the vegetative bacteria that causes this condition. Endotoxin (choice B), or lipopolysaccharide, is found on all gram-negative bacteria; and C. botulinum is a gram-positive rod. Exotoxin (choice C) could describe any secreted toxin, including neurotoxins, but again this infant's condition was not an intoxication and was not due to ingestion of any kind of toxin directly. A neurotoxin (choice D) describes tetanospasmin or botulinum toxin, which is produced by C. tetani or C. botulinum respectively. Tetanus toxin causes a rigid paralysis due to the inhibition of glycine and GABA at inhibitory synapses. The present case is one of infant botulism, which was not due to ingestion of a preformed toxin or an intoxication as is adult botulism.

question: Public Health authorities are notified of an outbreak of diarrhea with leukocytes, blood and mucus at a day-care center in Minnesota Of the 14 affected children within the ages of 3 to 5 years old, all had fever leukocytosis and pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen What is the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is E. Yersinia enterocolitica is an important cause of 'mini-epidemics' of pediatric diarrhea. Outbreaks are common in colder climates and the organism can be grown well at 4°C (39.2°F). Adults can also be affected, but less commonly than children. Some diarrheal cases are severe (and occasionally fatal) and may be complicated by severe dysentery, appendicitis, or chronic relapsing ileocolitis that may require antibiotics (quinolone, third-generation cephalosporin or trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole) to shorten the course. Helicobacter pylori (choice A) is an important cause of gastritis and ulcers. Salmonella enterica subspecies typhi (choice B) causes typhoid fever. It is not common in the United States, but symptoms of infection include fever, abdominal rash and splenomegaly. Diarrhea is not a consistent feature. Streptococcus pneumoniae (choice C) usually causes respiratory infections rather than diarrhea. Vibrio cholerae (choice D) causes cholera. It is not a common cause of diarrhea in day-care centers in the United States but is normally associated with massive environmental doses of bacteria in contaminated water. Patients with cholera have severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.

question: Several employees at a large company come to employee health services because of a 2-day history of multiple episodes of watery diarrhea. Some have had blood-tinged stools and some have had profound abdominal cramping and fever. All the affected individuals attended a dinner party several days ago. An overnight stool culture at 42°C (107.6°F) grows microaerophilic, oxidase-positive, gram-negative curved rods with polar flagella. Which of the following is the most likely source of this infection?
explanation: The correct answer is F. This case history and culture characteristics describe a typical gastroenteritis due to Campylobacter jejuni, the most common bacterial gastroenteritis in the United States. Contaminated poultry or poultry products are responsible for more than 60% of all infections. Carriers (choice A) are not known to occur with Campylobacter, and are best known with Salmonella typhi. Typhoid fever is an enteric fever that presents with fever, lymphadenopathy and constipation. Custard and potato-salad dishes (choice B) would be the most likely source if the agent was Staphylococcus aureus, but this would have had an onset of 2 hours, and a gram-positive coccus would have been the cause. Milk and cream (choice C) might contain Listeria or Mycobacterium bovis, but Listeria is a gram-positive rod and Mycobacterium is an acid-fast rod. Both may cause a minor gastroenteritis in healthy adults but would be unlikely to present with blood in the stool. Poorly canned green vegetables (choice D) are the usual source of Clostridium botulinum, which would cause a flaccid paralysis. Clostridium is a genus of gram-positive rods. Poorly washed salad greens (choice E) could be sources of infection with multiple agents such as Escherichia coli, Entamoeba histolytica, Salmonella or Shigella. The E. coli strains which cause non-bloody diarrhea are usually associated with travel out of the home country (traveler's diarrhea). E. coli is a gram-negative rod that is oxidase-negative. Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that does not occur commonly in the United States but instead requires travel to a tropical country, and Salmonella and Shigella would be more likely to cause frankly bloody stools. Both are gram-negative rods that are oxidase-negative. Rare red meat dishes (choice G) would be good sources for Escherichia coli or Trichinella spiralis. E. coli is a gram-negative, oxidase-negative rod and Trichinella is a nematode. The serotype of E. coli associated with rare meat dishes in the United States causes bloody diarrhea without leukocytes. Trichinosis causes myalgia, fever, eosinophilia, splinter hemorrhages and periorbital edema. Rice dishes (choice H) are most frequently incriminated in the transmission of Bacillus cereus, which has a 1-to-2-hour onset of vomiting followed by diarrhea. Bacillus is a genus of gram-positive rods. Smoked fish (choice I) is a common source of Clostridium botulinum, a gram-positive spore-forming rod that would produce a flaccid paralysis. Soft cheeses (choice J) are a common source of Listeria monocytogenes, which is a gram-positive rod that causes mild gastroenteritis.

question: A healthy 32-year-old primigravid woman at 8 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal examination. She states that she emigrated from Southeast Asia and that three years ago, she had fatigue, nausea, anorexia, jaundice joint pains, and generalized skin lesions that slowly disappeared. Which of the following laboratory tests should be ordered to investigate the patient's past illness?
options: B. Hepatitis A virus (HAV) IgM antibody
explanation: The correct answer is C. The clinical signs suggest that this woman had hepatitis B three years ago, and the fact that she is now feeling better also suggests that she recovered from this infection. Since she is pregnant, it is necessary to find out if she still has the agent in her liver (chronic hepatitis B infection) by performing a test for HBsAg. This test will be negative if she has completely recovered from the disease, but it will be positive if she is a chronic carrier. Ordering CMV IgG antibody (choice A) would be of no value because the clinical signs of the disease she had 3 years ago do not match those of CMV, and CMV does not produce chronic infections. Quantitation of HAV IgM antibody (choice B) would be useless, since HAV only causes acute infection. Measurement of IgM antibody to HBcAg (choice D) would be of no value at this time. This antibody is positive in acute hepatitis B, but would no longer be positive in this case. Examination of IgM antibody to HBsAg (choice E) would be of no value at this time. This antibody would be formed early during the recovery from acute hepatitis B, and would class-switch to IgG later on in the disease.

question: A 32-year-old man is struck by a car and sustains crush injuries to both legs. Two days later, he develops a severe infection of the legs. Physical examination shows crepitus of the tissue of the legs. An x-ray of the legs shows radiolucent pockets in the soft tissues Which of the following toxins produced by the most likely causal organism is responsible for these findings?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The disease described is gas gangrene, which is caused by the spore-forming anaerobe Clostridium perfringens and other closely related species. These very dangerous bacteria particularly like to grow in necrotic vascular tissue, and they produce a variety of destructive enzymes and toxins. The toxin produced by C. perfringens that is most strongly associated with myonecrosis is the alpha toxin, which is a lecithinase (phospholipase C) that lyses erythrocytes, platelets, leukocytes, and endothelial cells. This toxin mediates massive hemolysis, increased vascular permeability and bleeding, hepatotoxicity, bradycardia, and hypotension. In the laboratory, the action of the lecithinase can be observed in Nagler's reaction, in which strains of C. perfringens will lyse the lecithin in egg-yolk agar. Endotoxin (choice B) is lipopolysaccharide and is not found on gram-positive organisms such as Clostridium. Enterotoxins (choice C) are produced by gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria including C. perfringens but the vignette is clearly specific for myonecrosis and not gastroenteritis. Neurotoxins (choice D) are produced by other members of the genera Clostridium (C. tetanus and C. botulinum), but not by C. perfringens. Superantigen toxin (choice E) is specific for staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome and the pyrogenic exotoxins of Streptococcus pyogenes. These exotoxins cause fever, petechial rash, and disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.

question: A previously healthy 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a rash that appeared 2 days ago Physical examination shows multiple umbilicated, flesh-colored papules on the trunk. Which of the following is a characteristic of the most likely causal organism?
options: A. It captures a nuclear membrane envelope
B. It replicates in the cytoplasm
C. It replicates in the nucleus
D. It utilizes an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase
explanation: The correct answer is B. The lesions are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum, a typically benign and self-limited condition caused by a poxvirus. The disease can be transmitted either sexually or through direct nonsexual contact. Patients with advanced HIV infection may develop a severe, generalized, and persistent eruption, often involving the face and upper body. Molluscum contagiosum virus is a poxvirus that reproduces in the cytoplasm and produces intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies. Capturing a nuclear membrane envelope (choice A) and replication in the nucleus (choice C) are characteristics of Herpesviridae. This family includes herpes simplex 1 and 2, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, varicella zoster, herpes 6 and herpes 8. None of these agents cause umbilicated warts, although rashes may occur. Herpes simplex causes vesicular lesions on the mucosae and varicella causes an asynchronous pruritic rash (chickenpox) or a unilateral vesicular rash that follows a dermatome (shingles). Utilization of an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (choice D) is characteristic of all RNA viruses. Utilization of reverse transcriptase (choice E) is characteristic of human immunodeficiency virus and hepatitis B virus. Reverse transcriptase is an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase.

question: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal itching and discharge. Pelvic examination shows abundant white, lumpy material in the vagina. Examination of the discharge under a microscope shows fungal hyphae and yeast forms Which of the following is most likely io predispose the patient to this condition?
explanation: The correct answer is B. This patient has vulvovaginitis secondary to Candida infection. The condition is characterized by itching and soreness, pain on intercourse, finding of pseudohyphae in vaginal secretions, and absence of a particular odor. Predisposing factors include a high vaginal pH, diabetes, and use of antibiotics. The increased vulnerability in diabetes may reflect increased glucose concentrations in vaginal secretions and relative immunosuppression. Crohn disease (choice A) can predispose for fistulas involving the vagina, rather than vulvovaginitis. Dissemination of Neisseria gonorrhoeae (choice C) can cause septic arthritis. The discharge of gonorrhea is leukorrheic and will contain neutrophils full of gram-negative diplococci. Neither rheumatoid arthritis (choice D) nor systemic lupus erythematosus (choice E) is specifically associated with Candida vulvovaginitis.

question: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of double vision Physical examination shows drooping eyelids, a markedly diminished pupillary light reflex, and difficulty opening his mouth. Which of the following is probable source of the most likely causal agent?
explanation: The correct answer is E. This is a typical presentation of botulism, which is caused by the preformed toxin of Clostridium botulinum. Patients develop a progressive flaccid paralysis that can lead to death if the respiratory system is not adequately supported. Mentation is intact in these patients, and they do not exhibit sensory changes except for those related to failure of extraocular and intraocular muscles (e.g., diplopia, cycloplegia). The most common food sources implicated in botulism are canned alkaline vegetables and preserved fish. Since the genus Clostridium is anaerobic, materials packaged in the absence of oxygen will allow germination of the spores and the production of the toxin. Treatment is supportive. An antitoxin is available from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) via state Health Departments, but may not be obtained early enough to be helpful. Most patients recover from food-borne botulism without any sequelae. Ground beef (choice A) is often implicated in transmission of Escherichia coli but is not involved in adult botulism. Poultry (choice B) is a common source of food poisoning caused by Campylobacter and Salmonella but is not a source of adult botulism. Rice (choice C) is a food often implicated in Bacillus cereus food poisoning, but not in adult botulism. Salad greens (choice D) are a source of foodborne illness in many tropical countries, as well as of Escherichia coli in the U.S., but are not implicated in the transmission of adult botulism.

question: A 36-year-old woman who is schoolteacher comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of swollen, painful hands. She says that the pain and stiffness are worse in the morning Physical examination shows bilateral tenderness and swelling of the wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints. The pain remits and she feels better in seven days. Which of the following illnesses did a student in her classroom most likely have?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum, or Fifth disease. Adults typically do not get the facial rash ('slapped cheek') typical of children, but have arthralgias and arthritis. The symmetrical distribution of involved joints is similar to that in rheumatoid arthritis. The onset in adults is typically 3 to 4 weeks after exposure. Parvovirus infections may persist in immunosuppressed patients, resulting in red blood cell aplasia. B19 virus can cross the placenta and cause hydrops fetalis because it infects erythroid precursors, and has been linked to the aplastic crises of sickle cell anemia. Human herpesvirus type 6 (choice A) is the causative agent of roseola infantum, which is a common childhood illness that causes an extremely high fever; the fever subsides and then the child develops a lacy body rash. Rubella (choice C) is the German measles, which is sometimes called the three-day measles. Although the rash looks similar to that of rubeola (measles) the rubella rash is less intense than that of rubeola. Rubella is best known for its ability to cross the placenta and cause serious congenital defects. Rubeola (choice D) is the measles, which is characterized by the 3 C's (cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis) and photophobia, Koplik spots, and a maculopapular rash that begins below the ears and eventually spreads downward and also covers the face. Varicella zoster virus (choice E) is the causative agent of chickenpox and shingles.

question: A 39-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after experiencing a seizure during which he severely bit his tongue. He appears to be lethargic, is unable to answer simple questions, and has an obvious left-sided hemiparesis. A CT scan of the head is shown. He has a history of fungal esophagitis and cervical lymphadenopathy. In the United States, which of the following is the most common means of transmission of the causal agent responsible for the CT findings?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The lesions shown are ring-enhancing lesions in the brain, and in an AIDS patient, this is extremely suggestive of infection with Toxoplasma gondii. Toxoplasmosis presents with seizures in 15-25% of cases. Because 70-80% of the world's population is seropositive, reactivational disease in the immunocompromised is extremely common. The disease is most commonly spread in the United States by ingestion of cysts from undercooked pork, but it can also be spread transplacentally or from cat feces. Tachyzoites develop intracellularly in phagocytic cells and then spread to the brain, muscle, and other tissues, where they encyst and multiply. Primary central nervous system lymphoma in AIDS patients can present clinically in nearly the same manner as toxoplasmosis, but the course is usually much more indolent. Fecal-oral contamination (choice B) is not the most common means of acquiring toxoplasmosis in the United States. Although cats serve as the necessary definitive host, and contamination with cat feces can cause infection, it is not the most common source in this country. Respiratory droplets (choice C) are not known to be a means of infection with T. gondii. Sexual transmission (choice D) is not known to occur in toxoplasmosis. Transplacental transmission (choice E) occurs with Toxoplasma in 2 to 6 out of every 1,000 live births. Although it is a serious cause of birth defects, this is not the most common route of infection in the United States.

question: A 53-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her sister because of confusion and disorientation She has a 2-day history of fever, chills, severe headache and vomiting. She has no history of major medical illness. Examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows numerous lymphocytes and some erythrocytes and elevated protein. If the patient dies of her infection, which of the following would most likely be seen on microscopic examination of the brain?
options: A. Both distinct nuclear and ill-defined cytoplasmic inclusions
D. Greatly enlarged oligodendrocyte nuclei with glassy amphophilic viral inclusions
E. Microglial nodules containing multinucleated giant cells
explanation: The correct answer is B. This patient most likely has herpes simplex type 1 (HSV-1) encephalitis. HSV-1 is the most common cause of fatal sporadic encephalitis in the United States, accounting for approximately 10% to 20% of the 20,000 viral encephalitis cases that occur annually. Viral encephalitis is characterized by elevated lymphocytes and erythrocytes in the CSF. HSV-1 encephalitis has a propensity for the temporal lobes of the brain. Other types of viral encephalitis typically affect older patients, occur in the summer months (because of mosquito transmission), and have no particular association to regions of the brain. Cowdry type A inclusions are intranuclear viral inclusion bodies that may be found in both neurons and glia and are characteristic of herpes simplex infection. The presence of both distinct nuclear and ill-defined cytoplasmic inclusions (choice A) specifically suggests cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV infection of the brain characteristically occurs in severely immunosuppressed patients, in whom it tends to localize to the paraventricular subependymal regions of the brain. Extracellular spirochetes (choice C) can sometimes be demonstrated in patients with neuroborreliosis, the brain infection seen in Lyme disease, and in neurosyphilis. Neuroborreliosis can cause aseptic meningitis, facial nerve palsies, and encephalopathy. Neurosyphilis can occur in three basic forms: meningovascular syphilis (involving the base of the brain), general paresis (involving the frontal lobe and other areas of the neocortex), and tabes dorsalis (involving the dorsal roots and spinal cord). Greatly enlarged oligodendrocyte nuclei with glassy amorphic viral inclusions (choice D) are a feature of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). This viral encephalitis usually occurs in immunosuppressed patients and is caused by the JC polyomavirus. PML is characterized by demyelination because it preferentially infects oligodendroglia. Microglial nodules containing multinucleated giant cells (choice E) are characteristic of chronic HIV encephalitis, which tends to involve in particular the subcortical white matter, diencephalon, and brainstem.

question: A 23-year-old man with a history of intravenous drug abuse is brought to the emergency department because of a sudden high fever, severe dyspnea, and malaise One hour later he develops progressive respiratory distress and supplemental oxygen is provided His CD4 cell count is 73/uL. Examination of fluid obtained on bronchoalveolar lavage shows a predominant organism when stained with methenamine. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is C. Patients with AIDS are prone to a variety of opportunistic infections, and Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia represents one of the most common initial presentations. This organism is a ubiquitous atypical fungus that may cause a life-threatening acute interstitial pneumonia in immunocompromised patients. P. jiroveci appears as a cystlike organism with a characteristic cup shape that has been likened to a 'crushed tennis ball'. Methenamine silver staining allows its identification in bronchoalveolar lavage. A frothy exudate filling the alveolar cavities is a characteristic finding in patients with Pneumocystis pneumonia. Pneumocystis has been classified as a fungus by ribosomal RNA analysis, but it is an unusual member of the group. A gram-positive, catalase-positive coccus (choice A) describes the genus Staphylococcus. Staphylococcus does not silver-stain and is not a common cause of dyspnea in AIDS patients. An encapsulated monomorphic fungus (choice B) describes the genus Cryptococcus. This genus causes dangerous meningitis in the immunocompromised person, but is not a common cause of pneumonia in AIDS. An intracellular parasitic protozoan (choice D) describes Toxoplasma gondii. Toxoplasma may cause encephalitis in AIDS patients, but it would not be expected to cause pneumonia. An intracellular yeast (choice E) describes Histoplasma capsulatum. This agent causes acute and chronic pulmonary disease in AIDS patients, but would not produce methenamine silver-staining cysts.

question: A B-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a severe sore throat. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F). Physical examination shows an erythematous posterior oropharynx with obvious abscesses on the tonsillar pillars, A rapid antigen test for Streptococcus pyogenes is positive. A beta-lactam antibiotic will have greatest efficacy at which of the following stages shown in the diagram?
explanation: The correct answer is C. In the bacterial growth curve, rapid exponential growth occurs during the log (or logarithmic growth) phase. Within this period, the generation time equals the time it takes for one cell to divide into two. Beta-lactam drugs act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis. In a bacterial culture, cell wall synthesis will occur at a maximal rate during the period of exponential growth, which is marked on the graph by the letter C. The lag phase (choice A) is the initial phase of a bacterial culture during which there is no increase in cell number. Cells in a culture at this stage are activating enzymes necessary for metabolism, but are not undergoing cell wall synthesis. Choice B indicates the initial phase of bacterial multiplication, when cell division has not yet reached a maximum. Although cell wall synthesis would indeed make such cells sensitive to beta-lactam antibiotics, it is not the period of maximum sensitivity. Choice D indicates the phase of the bacterial growth curve when toxic metabolic products begin to accumulate and nutrient levels begin to be insufficient to support continued growth. New cell wall synthesis would begin to fall at this point.
