The stationary phase (choice E) is a period of the bacterial growth curve when the number of bacteria dividing in the culture equals the number of cells dying. This would not be a period of intense cell wall synthesis. The decline (choice F) and death (choice G) phases of the bacterial growth curve are periods when bacteria are dying more rapidly than they are dividing. Cell wall synthesis would be minimal.

question: A 42-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of right upper quadrant pain and a fever. He also has had a 2-month history of chronic diarrhea and bloody stools. Physical examination shows a large, tender liver. Ultrasound shows an ovoid, hypoechoic lesion near the liver capsule. Examination of tissue obtained on biopsy of the liver will most likely show which of the following?
explanation: The correct answer is D. Entamoeba histolytica is an intestinal amebic parasite that either can cause relatively mild diarrhea or can behave more aggressively, causing dysentery (bloody diarrhea with abdominal pain and dehydration), peritonitis, or liver abscess formation (such as this patient has). Treatment is generally administered as soon as the diagnosis is made. Metronidazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of this infection due to its excellent tissue penetration. Metronidazole is effective for both invasive and luminal disease. However, upon successful completion of metronidazole therapy, a 'luminal agent' such as paromomycin or iodoquinol is administered to completely eradicate any remaining gastrointestinal tract infection and prevent an infection relapse. The trophozoite of E. histolytica, which is shown in the image, is identified by the distinctive 'cart-wheel' distribution of chromatin in the nucleus and the evidence of ingested red blood cells. Toxoplasma gondii (choice A) is a cause of encephalitis in the immunocompromised, and birth defects in children infected transplacentally, but is not a common cause of liver abscess or bloody diarrhea. The large tissue cyst shown here would be characteristic of an early active stage of disease or reactivation disease in the immunocompromised. Fasciola hepatica (choice B) is the sheep liver fluke. It can cause bile duct obstruction in infected humans but would not be a likely cause of bloody diarrhea or of liver abscess. It is very rare in the United States. The adult fluke, shown here, is identified by the prominent 'shoulders' on the anterior end. Clonorchis sinensis (choice C) is the Chinese liver fluke. It causes hepatitis and cholangitis in Chinese populations, but not bloody diarrhea or liver abscess. The ovum, which is shown here, is identified by the prominent opercular ridge on the far right of this image. Cryptosporidium parvum (choice E) is a protozoan parasite related to T. gondii. In humans it can cause chronic bloody diarrhea in the immunocompromised, but it is not a cause of liver abscess. The image shows a Giemsa stain of the oocysts that would be found in the stool. Diagnosis of this condition is normally made by acid-fast staining of the stool.

question: A 71-year-old woman with a history of type 1 diabetes comes to the physician because of left-sided hearing loss. She states that she also has pain and discharge from the left ear. Physical examination shows a tender pinna, swelling and erythema of the external auditory canal, as well as a purulent discharge. The tympanic membrane cannot be visualized A CT scan of the head shows temporal bone erosions and new bone formation. Culture of the discharge will most likely show which of the following?
options: A. Gram-negative bacillus requiring factors X and V
B. Gram-negative, oxidase-negative non-lactose fermenting bacillus
C. Gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacillus that produces blue-green pigments
explanation: The correct answer is C. This patient has malignant external otitis, which is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. P. aeruginosa is the most common cause of self-limited external otitis. It may, however, penetrate the epithelium and invade the underlying soft tissue, cartilage and bone, thus leading to osteomyelitis and cranial nerve palsies. The presenting symptoms include ear pain and discharge, hearing loss, and facial nerve paralysis. Abnormalities of the external ear canal are present. A CT scan may reveal bony erosions and soft-tissue swelling. Cultures will isolate the organism. Treatment includes antibiotics and surgical debridement. Malignant external otitis is most common in elderly diabetic patients. Pseudomonas is a genus of gram-negative bacilli that are oxidase-positive, aerobic, and produce blue-green pigments. Other diseases caused by Pseudomonas include septicemia, wound or burn infections, urinary tract infections in catheterized patients, and life-threatening pneumonias in cystic fibrosis patients. A gram-negative bacillus requiring factors X and V (choice A) describes the genus Haemophilus. This genus may cause otitis media; symptoms of otitis media include ear pain, fever and a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane. A gram-negative oxidase-negative, non-lactose fermenting bacillus (choice B) describes some members (Shigella, Yersinia, Proteus, and Salmonella) of the family Enterobacteriaceae. There are no agents of ear infections present in this group. Most of the Enterobacteriaceae are diarrhea-causing agents, or are causes of enteric fevers, neonatal meningitis, or urinary tract infections. A gram-positive, catalase-negative, alpha-hemolytic coccus (choice D) describes Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is the most common cause of otitis media but not of otitis externa, as in this case. A gram-positive catalase-negative beta-hemolytic coccus (choice E) describes Streptococcus pyogenes and S. agalactiae. S. pyogenes is a common cause of otitis media and S. agalactiae is the most common cause of neonatal septicemia and meningitis in the United States.

question: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a near-fatal fire. Over the next several days he develops pneumonia and progressive shortness of breath and is intubated. Gram stain of the sputum shows a gram-negative, encapsulated, oxidase-positive aerobic rod. Which of the following mechanisms allows the most likely causal organism to be resistant to many different antibiotics?
options: A. Mutation of a penicillin-binding protein
B. Mutation of a porin protein
explanation: The correct answer is B. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a very common opportunist in burn patients, in whom it classically causes secondary wound infections and septicemia. It may also cause cystitis in patients with urinary catheters, and pneumonia in patients with cystic fibrosis. The organism is found in water and usually gains access to the body as a contaminant in the water used in respirators or in the water baths used to cleanse wounds. Pseudomonas is resistant to many antibiotics, and mutates to even more resistant strains during therapy. The most important means of resistance is through the mutation of a porin protein that restricts the flow of many antibiotics into the cell. Mutation of a penicillin-binding protein (choice A) is a chromosomally mediated mechanism of resistance exhibited by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Mutation of a topoisomerase (choice C) is a chromosomally mediated mechanism of resistance to ciprofloxacin that is exhibited by Pseudomonas and Escherichia coli. It is not, however considered the major mechanism of drug resistance to a wide variety of drugs. Plasmid-mediated acetyltransferase production (choice D) is a mechanism of drug resistance exhibited by Klebsiella and Enterobacter against gentamicin and by Salmonella against chloramphenicol. Plasmid-mediated beta-lactamase production (choice E) is expressed in Pseudomonas and contributes to resistance to penicillins, cephalosporins, and carbapenems. It does not confer resistance to as many drugs as the alteration of the porin proteins, but is still a significant cause of resistance.

question: A 2-week-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a one-day history of labored breathing. His home birth was uneventful and his immunizations are up-to-date but his mother reports that he developed conjunctivitis on the fourth day of life. He is afebrile and has a respiratory rate of 40/minute. Physical examination shows bilateral inspiratory crackles and a slight wheeze on auscultation of the chest. A chest x-ray is consistent with bilateral pneumonia. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 15,000/mm³ with 40% eosinophils. Which of the following is the most likely causal agent?
explanation: The correct answer is B. This patient presents with symptoms consistent with neonatal atypical pneumonia secondary to Chlamydia trachomatis. This agent is transmitted from the mother's vaginal secretions to the neonate at birth. The conjunctivitis precedes the pneumonitis. Tachypnea, hypoxemia, crackles, wheezing and eosinophilia are evident. Patients with mild to moderate illness with Chlamydia pneumonia may present with the 'staccato cough' (inspiration between each single cough). Chest x-ray may show scattered infiltrates and hyperinflation of the lungs. Ascaris lumbricoides (choice A) produces ascariasis and can cause pneumonia and eosinophilia. This is caused by ingestion of Ascaris eggs from human fecal contamination. Haemophilus influenzae (choice C) is an agent of pharyngitis, pneumonia, meningitis and epiglottitis in unvaccinated children between the ages of 3 months and 2 years. It would not be common in a neonate and would not associate with eosinophilia. Mycoplasma pneumoniae (choice D) is the most common etiologic agent of atypical pneumonia in young people, but not in neonates. Neisseria gonorrhoeae (choice E) can cause ophthalmia neonatorum in this age-group of patient but would not be associated with pneumonia or eosinophilia. Pneumocystis jiroveci (choice F) causes pneumonia in patients with acquired immune deficiency syndrome and other immunocompromised patients. Streptococcus pneumoniae (choice G) is the most common cause of typical pneumonia in adults, but would not be a common agent of pneumonia with eosinophilia following conjunctivitis in a neonate. Varicella (choice H) pneumonia is accompanied by pruritic skin lesions. Eosinophilia is not seen.

question: A male newborn delivered at 30 weeks' gestation develops respiratory distress. Examination of lower respiratory tract secretions obtained on transmural needle biopsy shows roughly spherical bodies with sharply outlined walls when stained with methenamine silver. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is C. The organism described is Pneumocystis jiroveci which is an opportunistic infection in premature infants and in patients with AIDS. It causes an atypical pneumonia due to the over-replication of type 2 pneumocytes and their production of surfactant-rich exudates, which fill the alveolar sacs and eventually cause death by asphyxiation. Bordetella pertussis (choice A) is the causative agent of whooping cough. The incidence of whooping cough has declined with the development of the vaccine. Haemophilus influenzae (choice B) is the causative agent of otitis media, epiglottitis, and meningitis in unvaccinated children. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) (choice D) would be a likely cause of respiratory distress in a premature infant, but the vignette describes the finding of spherical cysts with sharply outlined walls. RSV findings might indicate giant multinucleated cells or syncytia in the sputum. Streptococcus pneumoniae (choice E) is the most common cause of otitis media and pneumonia, but not in premature infants.

question: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painful, tingling lesions on her tongue. Physical examination shows vesicular lesions with associated erythema on the tongue. She says that she is preparing for her wedding in a few days. Which of the following best describes the most likely causal agent?
options: A. A double-stranded DNA virus that has a complex lipid envelope
B. A double-stranded DNA virus that is enveloped and icosahedral
C. A gram-positive, catalase-negative, beta-hemolytic coccus
D. A gram-positive, catalase-positive, beta-hemolytic coccus
E. A positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus that is nonsegmented and naked
explanation: The correct answer is B. The painful vesicular lesions on the tongue are characteristic of herpes simplex virus, and the most common strain that causes these lesions above the waist is herpes simplex type 1. Herpes simplex belongs to the Herpesviridae, which are double-stranded DNA viruses that are enveloped with nuclear membrane and are icosahedral. Stress is frequently an activating stimulus that causes herpes gingivostomatitis to break out from its location of latent infection in the ganglia. A double-stranded DNA virus that has a complex lipid envelope (choice A) describes the Poxviridae, a family that contains smallpox virus and molluscum contagiosum virus. Of these, smallpox virus is extinct and molluscum contagiosum is a common cause of benign, wartlike lesions in young adults. Molluscum does not cause vesicular lesions but rather umbilicated warts, and would not be common on the tongue. A gram-positive, catalase-negative, beta-hemolytic coccus (choice C) describes either Streptococcus pyogenes or Strep. agalactiae. Of these, Strep. pyogenes does cause skin lesions (impetigo) in young children, but these are honey-crusted, not vesicular, and would not be common on the tongue in an adult. A gram-positive catalase-positive beta-hemolytic coccus (choice D) describes Staphylococcus aureus, which is another agent of impetigo in children. Staph. aureus causes bullous impetigo, characterized by vesicular lesions, but would not be common on the tongue. A positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus that is nonsegmented and naked (choice E) describes the family Picornaviridae which includes the agents of herpangina and hand, foot, and mouth disease. These coxsackieviruses cause blister-like lesions in the mouth but would not be common on the tongue. Hand, foot, and mouth disease presents with vesicular lesions in the front of the buccal mucosa, and herpangina manifests with lesions in the rear of the mouth on the palate and fauces.

question: A 17-year-old boy recently immigrated from Tajikistan is brought to the emergency department because of marked swelling of the left testis. He has a one-week history of marked bilateral swelling of the parotid glands. To which of the following families does the most likely causal agent belong?
explanation: The correct answer is D. This patient has mumps, which is caused by a negative-sense RNA virus in the Paramyxovirus family. This virus has been quite rare in the United States since the advent of the live-attenuated MMR vaccine. The mention of recent immigration suggests that the child may not have received adequate pediatric vaccinations or medical care. Bilateral parotitis and inflammation of the pancreas or testes are hallmarks of the infection in this age group. Other members of the Paramyxoviridae are parainfluenza virus, respiratory syncytial virus, and measles. The coronavirus family (choice A) includes corona virus and the SARS agent. The herpesvirus family (choice B) includes herpes simplex 1 and 2, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and varicella zoster virus. The orthomyxovirus family (choice C) includes influenza virus. The reovirus family (choice E) includes rotavirus, reovirus, and Colorado tick fever virus.

question: A 48-year-old woman with a history of diabetes comes to the physician because of a severe prefrontal headache. Physical examination shows swelling of the orbit of the left eye and a black nasal discharge. A silver stain of the patient's nasal discharge is likely to show which of the following?
options: C. Ribbon-like hyphae branching at 90 degrees
D. Septate hyphae branching at 45 degrees
explanation: The correct answer is C. This patient has zygomycosis, caused by fungi of the genera Rhizopus, Absidia, or Mucor. Ketoacidotic diabetics are at risk for developing rhinocerebral infections following inhalation of the sporangiospores of these normally harmless bread molds. The fungi are identified by the nonseptate (ribbon-like) hyphae that branch at 90-degree angles. Arthroconidia and spherules (choices A and E) are the environmental form and diagnostic forms (respectively) of Coccidioides immitis, the causative agent of San Joaquin Valley fever. Monomorphic, encapsulated yeast (choice B) describes Cryptococcus neoformans, which causes meningitis in the immunocompromised. Septate hyphae branching at 45 degrees (choice D) describes Aspergillus, an opportunistic fungus that can cause sinus infections and spread to cause meningitis in the immunocompromised.

question: A 38-year-old man with a history of hemophilia has had multiple infusions of clotting factors in his lifetime. Laboratory studies of ten batches of clotting factors administered to this patient show contamination with the human immunodeficiency virus, yet he has remained HIV-negative. The patient's CD4 count is 900/uL and reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) for the virus is negative. Absence of which of the following cell surface receptors best explains the findings in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is A. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection does not always progress to avert acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). In a few fortunate individuals (called nonprogressors) the infection remains asymptomatic, with a stable CD4 cell count and low or undetectable viremia. It is not entirely clear whether these patients will eventually develop AIDS. Some are resistant to HIV infection because they carry two defective copies of the gene encoding the CCR5 co-receptor. There are 15 known co-receptors, of which CCR5 and CXCR4 are the best characterized. CCR5 is a receptor for chemokines and serves as a co-receptor for HIV internalization into macrophages. CXCR4 is a chemokine receptor that serves as the co-receptor for HIV internalization into T lymphocytes. Approximately 1% of Caucasians in the United States are homozygous for such a protective CCR5 variant, and 20% are heterozygotes. HIV infection follows a slower course in heterozygotes. Homozygotes for this protective CCR5 variant are not present among Black and Asian populations. CD4 (choice B) is an important receptor of T-helper lymphocytes, macrophages, and Langerhans cells. It acts as the primary receptor for HIV binding. Binding to CD4, however, is not sufficient for the entry of HIV into the cells. Individuals without CD4 positive cells are defined as having a severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) and such a condition was not mentioned in the stem. The viral envelope gp120 protein (choice D) first binds CD4. This results in a conformational change in gp120 that allows this protein to bind co-receptors. Such co-receptors are present on lymphocytes and macrophages and normally serve as binding sites for chemokines. Once gp120 binds to CD4 and a co-receptor, a second viral protein gp41 facilitates fusion of the viral envelope with the plasma membrane, allowing 'injection' of the viral core into the cell. Neither CD8 (choice C) nor the receptor for TNF (choice E) plays a role in HIV binding to cells. CD8 is the co-receptor on cytotoxic T lymphocytes that stabilizes the interaction between the T cell receptor and the major histocompatibility molecule. The TNF receptor is a molecule on T lymphocytes that receives stimulatory signals from macrophages or in other cases receives apoptotic signals in various cells.

question: A 7-year-old girl develops behavioral changes, and her performance in school begins to deteriorate. Several months later, she develops a seizure disorder, ataxia, and focal neurologic symptoms. She eventually becomes quadriparetic, spastic, and comatose, and dies within a year. Which of the following diseases did this patient most likely have at 1 year of age?
explanation: The correct answer is E. This child had subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), which is a very rare, late complication of measles (rubeola) infection at an early age. The existence of this complication is part of the rationale for immunizing children against measles at an early age. It is thought that the immune and neurologic systems of very young children may permit the virus to become established in the brain. The exact mechanism of injury is poorly understood, but the brain shows encephalitis involving both gray and white matter. Forty percent of cases die within 1 year, and it is thought that the disease is probably always eventually fatal. Mumps (choice A) causes parotitis and fever in young children, and causes the complications of pancreatitis and orchitis when older individuals acquire the infection. Mumps is not known to cause CNS pathology. Parvovirus B19 (choice B) causes erythema infectiosum, or slapped-cheek fever in school-age children, and hydrops fetalis in fetuses infected in utero. It is also associated with aplastic crises in sickle-cell anemia patients, but is not known to cause CNS pathology. Polio (choice C) spreads from the blood to the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and motor cortex of the brain. It causes an asymmetric flaccid paralysis without sensory loss. Spasticity is not a common finding in polio. Rubella (choice D) or German measles, causes a mild 3-day rash in adults but is known to be teratogenic in the fetus if a mother is infected during gestation. The syndrome in the neonate (congenital rubella syndrome) includes patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, cataracts, microcephaly, and deafness.

question: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of palpable axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymph nodes. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 5 years ago and has been treated with a combination HIV therapy. Physical examination shows anterior cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymphadenopathy, and oral lesions consistent with thrush. The majority of HIV-infected patients with this spectrum of symptoms and signs have CD4 cell counts within which of the following ranges?
explanation: The correct answer is B. This patient has progressed from being asymptomatic to the point that he has a condition attributed to HIV infection, but not an AIDS-defining condition. The most likely CD4 count associated with this stage of disease would be between 200 and 399 cells/mm³. A CD4 cell count of 0-199 (choice A) would be the expected count in a patient who has progressed to full-blown AIDS. Full-blown AIDS is defined by the presence of a variety of infections or conditions that demonstrate a life-threatening collapse of the immune system. Examples of such conditions would include HIV encephalopathy, Pneumocystis pneumonia, Kaposi sarcoma, cryptosporidiosis, or Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare infections. A CD4 cell count of 400-599 (choice C) is a range that would be associated with a finding of generalized lymphadenopathy or asymptomatic infection. The existence of thrush in the present patient indicates that he has progressed to the early symptomatic phase of the disease. A CD4 cell count in the range of 600-799 (choice D) would be expected in an asymptomatic patient without generalized lymphadenopathy or thrush. A CD4 cell count above 800 (choice E) is considered a normal value in an uninfected individual.

question: A 35-year-old woman with AIDS is admitted to the hospital because of disseminated histoplasmosis. The hospital staff is concerned about the possible spread of the organism to other patients. The physician explains that the organism is not communicable from person to person. Which of the following best explains why the causal organism does not infect other patients?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Histoplasmosis is a systemic fungal infection that is acquired through inhalation of soil or dust that contains the organism. Within the body, Histoplasma capsulatum occurs as tiny, 2-to-4-micrometer yeast forms and is found intracellularly, particularly within cells of the reticuloendothelial system and in the lungs. This intracellular location is the principal reason why histoplasmosis is not usually communicable from person to person. H. capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus that forms yeasts (choice E) at body temperature and at lower temperatures, forms hyphal forms (choice A) with macroconidia (choice C) and microconidia (choice D) reproductive structures. Infection is acquired by inhaling the spores.

question: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of painful, palpable masses of the groin. Physical examination shows multiple enlarged, abscessed lymph nodes draining through the skin through indolent sinuses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The correct answer is D. This is lymphogranuloma venereum. The enlarged, abscessed lymph nodes are termed 'buboes' (which can also occur in bubonic plague). The only other commonly discussed sexually transmitted disease in which they can occur is chancroid. Histologically, the buboes of lymphogranuloma venereum are enlarged lymph nodes with stellate abscesses. The primary lesion is usually a self-healing papule or shallow ulcer. The causative organism is Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes L1-L3. Condyloma acuminatum (choice A) is the condition of anogenital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). Granuloma inguinale (choice B) is the condition caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. The disease is characterized by painless genital ulcers that ooze blood and mucus. Herpesvirus infection (choice C) causes tiny vesicles and ulcers and does not cause buboes. Syphilis (choice E) causes a painless nodule and does not cause buboes.

question: A 34-year-old man who recently emigrated from Brazil comes to the physician for a pre-employment physical examination. A chest x-ray shows a patchy, bilateral pneumonia and a lung mass. Examination of tissue obtained on biopsy of the mass shows fungal organisms with a few multiply-budding yeast forms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The correct answer is D. Latin America and multiply-budding ('pilot's wheel') yeasts are clues for paracoccidioidomycosis. This disease is caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. Blastomycosis (choice A) results in large budding yeasts in the sputum. It is found in the great riverbeds of the eastern half of the United States, with North and South Carolina being especially highly endemic. It causes acute and chronic lung infections as well as disseminated disease and is a special problem in the immunocompromised person. Coccidioidomycosis (choice B) is a fungus of the U.S. desert southwest. It also causes acute and chronic pulmonary infections, disseminated infections, and cutaneous lesions, but the tissue form would be spherules with endospores. Histoplasmosis (choice C) is endemic along the Mississippi, Missouri, and Ohio river valleys of the United States. It causes acute and chronic pulmonary infections and disseminated infections in the immunocompromised. The tissue form is an intracellular, unencapsulated yeast. Sporotrichosis (choice E) causes skin lesions in rose gardeners that may be single cutaneous mycetomas or may follow lymphatic drainages. The tissue form is a cigar-shaped yeast.

question: A 28-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician because of pain on swallowing. Physical examination shows white, plague-like material that is easily scraped off from the tongue and on the buccal mucosa. Which of the following laboratory tests is most appropriate to confirm the identity of the causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is C. Candida albicans produces oral thrush, which is common in acute HIV disease and becomes increasingly common as the CD4+ cell count falls. Candida plaques can generally be scraped off easily while those in a similar condition in HIV-infected individuals, hairy leukoplakia, cannot. Diagnosis is by demonstration of pseudohyphae formation in animal serum, the basis of the germ-tube test. The CAMP test (choice A) is used to identify a partial hemolytic agent produced by Streptococcus agalactiae. It is used to distinguish between group A and group B streptococci, along with testing for bacitracin sensitivity. Group B streptococci cause neonatal meningitis and septicemia, not the oral lesions described here. The ELEK test (choice B) is used to identify toxin-producing strains of bacteria in the oropharynx that resemble Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is used to differentiate between the pathogen C. diphtheriae and normal flora diphtheroids. C. diphtheriae causes gray fibrinous exudates to form on the uvula and upper airways. It does not have an association with HIV infection. Heterophile antibody tests (choice D) are common in medicine in cases in which a causal agent is difficult to identify or culture. These tests depend on the detection of accidental cross-reactions between antibodies formed during an infection with an unrelated substance. Key examples of heterophile antibody tests include the Monospot test for Epstein-Barr virus mononucleosis, the Weil-Felix test for rickettsial infections, and the VDRL for syphilis. None of these tests would be used to identify the cause of a white oral exudate in an AIDS patient. The Weil-Felix test (choice E) is a heterophile antibody test used in the diagnosis of several rickettsial diseases. It depends on the accidental cross-reaction between antibodies produced during rickettsial infections and the OX strain of Proteus vulgaris. Rickettsial diseases are arthropod-borne diseases that are all characterized by rashes. None of them would be consistent with the signs in this case.

question: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal itching and a yellow, malodorous discharge that is worse following her menses. She is sexually active with two partners and recently had unprotected sex Pelvic examination shows erythema of the cervix. Microscopic examination of vaginal secretions will most likely show which of the following?
explanation: The correct answer is C. Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan parasite that causes a sexually transmitted disease. The vaginitis it causes is characterized by a frothy yellow discharge. It causes spotty reddening of the mucosa that is referred to as a 'strawberry' mucosa. The organism can be identified in saline mounts of vaginal fluids by its characteristic corkscrew motility. This is caused by the fact that the organism has flagella on one end, and an undulating membrane going down its side that causes it to rotate on its longitudinal axis while it moves in a single direction. Clue cells (choice A) are the diagnostic clue for bacterial vaginosis (BV), usually due to overgrowth of the normal vaginal flora by Gardnerella vaginalis. BV would also have a malodorous discharge, but it would be thin and gray, not frothy and yellow. It is worse following menses, but is not always sexually associated. Gram-negative diplococci (choice B) describes Neisseria gonorrhoeae which would cause a neutrophil-rich discharge and erosions of the vaginal mucosa. A Gram stain of the neutrophilic discharge would show gram-negative diplococci. Obligate intracellular pathogens (choice D) describes Chlamydia trachomatis, serotypes D-K, which would not cause such a discharge. Yeast (choice E) is most likely Candida albicans, a common cause of vaginitis. Candida causes a white, cottage cheese-like discharge.

question: A newborn who is born at 37 weeks' gestation has purple splotches on the skin, hepatosplenomegaly, and jaundice. A CT of the head shows calcifications. Which of the following is also associated with the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is B. The most common agents causing congenital infection in the United States are cytomegalovirus (CMV), herpes simplex virus, and Toxoplasma gondii. Congenital CMV infection, which occurs in 1 to 2% of all live births in the United States, results from transplacental acquisition of a primary or recurrent maternal infection. Most infections are asymptomatic, but about 5% will present with hepatosplenomegaly, periventricular brain calcification, petechial hemorrhages, and hydrops. Sensorineural deafness is a common manifestation in affected infants. Primary infection of the mother is strongly associated with more severe symptoms in affected infants. The mortality rate is 30%, and most of the survivors will have neurologic impairment. CMV infections in children and adults are often asymptomatic; however the virus is responsible for 10% of infectious mononucleosis cases (characterized by an absence of sheep red blood cell agglutinins: heterophile-negative mononucleosis). CMV also causes serious disease in immunosuppressed patients, including bone-marrow recipients and AIDS patients. Ganciclovir is the drug of choice although foscarnet has also been used with some success. Hairy oral leukoplakia (choice A) is a condition caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infections in AIDS patients and is associated with hyperproliferation of the lingual epithelia. EBV although it belongs to the same family as CMV, is not associated with in utero infections. Hodgkin lymphoma (choice C) is associated with EBV. Kaposi sarcoma (choice D) is associated with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and herpesvirus-8 coinfections. It is a sarcoma of endothelial cells. Although HIV can be acquired in utero, it would not be associated with thrombocytopenic purpura. Lymphoproliferative disease (choice E) is associated with EBV infections in AIDS patients.

question: A 37-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of incoordination and unsteadiness. Physical examination shows impaired proprioception and locomotor ataxia. A complete blood count is within normal limits. A diagnosis of degeneration of dorsal columns and dorsal roots of the spinal cord is made. Which of the following is most likely present in this patient's history?
options: A. Ingestion of poorly cooked fish
explanation: The correct answer is C. The findings described are those of tabes dorsalis, a form of tertiary syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum. Tabes dorsalis and other forms of tertiary syphilis are now uncommon in the United States; possibly because the common use of antibiotics may 'treat' many unsuspected cases of syphilis. The hallmark lesion of tertiary syphilis is the gumma, a syphilitic granuloma that forms in the central nervous system and in the vasculature. Tertiary syphilis is preceded by secondary syphilis, in which there is a maculopapular, bronzing rash and condylomata lata (flat, wartlike growths in the perianal or perigenital area). Primary syphilis is characterized by the finding of a painless, ulcerated genital lesion. Neurosyphilis can take many forms, including acute syphilitic meningitis, meningovascular syphilis, tabes dorsalis, general paresis and/or optic atrophy. Tabes dorsalis is a slowly progressive degenerative neurologic disease that affects the dorsal columns with demyelination and the dorsal roots with inflammatory changes accompanied by fibrosis. There is loss of pain sensation and peripheral reflexes, accompanied by impairment of vibration and position senses, with progressive ataxia. Ingestion of poorly cooked fish (choice A) is the means of infection with Diphyllobothrium latum, which is a tapeworm that competes with the host for vitamin B12. As a result, the infection may mimic pernicious anemia, and it may also cause degeneration of the dorsal columns and roots of the spinal cord (subacute combined degeneration) that may closely mimic syphilis. However, the two conditions can be distinguished by the presence of a megaloblastic anemia in vitamin B12 deficiency. Leukorrheic vaginal discharge (choice B) would be observed in a woman with Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, but is not found in any stage of syphilis. Painful genital ulcers (choice D) are caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, but the chancres of syphilis are painless and indurated. Travel to Africa (choice E) would likely be important in the history of a patient with granuloma inguinale (caused by Klebsiella granulomatis) or lymphogranuloma venereum (caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes L1, L2 and L3) but would not be a prerequisite for a diagnosis of syphilis.

question: Examination of tissue obtained on biopsy of the stomach shows markedly atypical glands containing cells with enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei below the muscularis mucosa and two tripolar mitoses. No signet ring cells are seen. Which of the following risk factors has the highest association with this presentation?
options: C. Nitrate content of the diet
explanation: The correct answer is B. This patient has gastric carcinoma, which has been strongly linked to prior gastric infection with Helicobacter pylori with subsequent development of intestinal metaplasia and gastric mucosal atrophy. H. pylori has also been implicated in the etiologies of gastric/peptic ulcer, chronic gastritis, and gastric lymphoma. The disease-causing strains of H. pylori contain a pathogenicity island containing the cytotoxin-associated gene A (CagA) and a type IV secretory system that injects the CagA protein into host cells. The relative risk factor associating H. pylori infection with gastric carcinoma is approximately 6.0. Alcohol consumption (choice A) has been shown in several studies to increase the risk of gastric carcinoma two-fold. High nitrate content of the diet (choice C) has been shown to increase the risk of gastric carcinoma by 1.2-fold. Pernicious anemia (choice D) has been associated with a three-fold increase in incidence of gastric carcinoma. Tobacco use (choice E) has been shown to increase the risk of gastric carcinoma almost five-fold.

question: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge, bleeding, and dyspareunia Examination of tissue obtained on cervical scraping shows cytoplasmic inclusions within epithelial cells The most likely causal organism is unable to synthesize which of the following?
options: E. Protoporphyrin and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide
explanation: The correct answer is A. The disease is chlamydial cervicitis. This sexually transmitted infection is usually suspected after treatment for gonorrhea fails to relieve symptoms. However, a few cases are picked up when cytoplasmic inclusions composed of aggregates of Chlamydia are identified on Pap smears. Confirmation can be made with fluorescent antibodies that pick up both the aggregates and individual bacteria known as 'elementary bodies'. The organisms are obligate intracellular parasites because they have lost the ability to synthesize ATP. They also produce a cell wall that does not contain muramic acid, one of the two normal components of bacterial peptidoglycan. Cell wall (choice B) synthesis is absent in Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma but all other prokaryotes possess a cell wall. Chlamydia have an unusual cell wall made only of N-acetyl-glutamic acid, but it is still a cell wall. Failure to synthesize cholesterol (choice C) is not usually a problem for prokaryotes since they do not have sterols in their cell membranes. Mycoplasmas however, require cholesterol in their diet so that they can include sterols in their unique membranes. Cysteine (choice D) is required by four genera of bacteria (Legionella, Pasteurella, Brucella, and Francisella), but not by Chlamydia. Protoporphyrin and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (choice E) are required by Haemophilus organisms, but not Chlamydia.

question: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of tender lymph nodes in the left side of her neck. She has no history of any major medical illness and takes no medications but received her final pre-school vaccinations two weeks ago. Examination of tissue obtained on biopsy of a lymph node shows benign paracortical expansion and scattered multinucleated giant cells with eosinophilic cytoplasmic and nuclear inclusion bodies Which of the following vaccines is most likely responsible for the findings seen in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is C. The Warthin-Finkeldey (WF) giant cell described here is pathognomonic for measles or the live attenuated measles vaccine. Most giant cells are composed of histiocytes, but the WF giant cell is created by fusion of lymphocytes. Although postvaccinal lymphadenitis may be seen with different vaccines, the usual reaction is immunoblastic proliferation within the paracortical regions of a hyperplastic lymph node. Hepatitis B (choice A), human papillomavirus (choice B), tetanus (choice D), and varicella zoster (choice E) are rarely associated with postvaccinal lymphadenitis.

question: A 33-year-old woman develops a painful. swollen right knee. Culture of the joint fluid aspirate grows organisms on chocolate agar but not on blood agar The most likely causal organism has which of the following properties?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The causal organism is Neisseria gonorrhoeae which is a sexually transmitted gram-negative coccus. It is estimated that N. gonorrhoeae may express over 1 million variants of pili, resulting in the virtual absence of immunity to reinfection with this agent The pili of this organism also are protective against phagocytosis and mediate attachment to the mucosal surfaces. The organism is the most common cause of septic arthritis in otherwise healthy, sexually active adults The treatment is usually with ceftriaxone. The Chlamydiae are intracellular organisms that cannot make ATP (choice C) and do not usually cause septic arthritis. Having both hyphae and spores (choice B) would be true of Candida, which usually causes arthritis as a rare complication of systemic candidiasis in immunocompromised patients. Mycoplasma do not have true cell walls (choice D) and do not usually cause septic arthritis. Syphilis is caused by a spirochete that is visible only with darkfield microscopy (choice E) or direct fluorescent antibody. Secondary syphilis can (uncommonly) cause an acute arthritis, but syphilis is rare in an otherwise healthy adult.

question: A 10-year-old boy develops an abscess on his left knee. Examination of the exudate shows neutrophils containing mixed bacterial flora. Which of the following is the most important virulence factor for bacterial survival within the phagolysosome?
explanation: The correct answer is A. Abscesses are commonly produced by catalase-positive organisms. Catalase is an enzyme that converts hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen. Hydrogen peroxide is one of the toxic oxygen compounds generated by the action of NADPH oxidase in phagocytes and it acts as the substrate for myeloperoxidase. Producing catalase, therefore, allows bacteria to survive longer intracellularly. Catalase-positive organisms include the staphylococci, Pseudomonas, Candida, Aspergillus, and the Enterobacteriaceae. Hemolysins (choice B) refers to a variety of enzymes that act to degrade hemoglobin. These would not have a role inside the phagolysosome. Hyaluronidase (choice C) is a spreading factor produced by Streptococcus pyogenes that degrades hyaluronic acid and promotes the movement of the organism through the extracellular matrix. It would not inactivate any of the intracellular killing mechanisms of phagocytes. Streptokinase (choice D) is a fibrinolytic compound produced by Streptococcus pyogenes. It would not contribute to survival within the phagolysosome. Tetanospasmin (choice E) is a neurotoxin produced by Clostridium tetani. It inhibits the inhibitory mediators glycine and GABA, and promotes the rigid paralysis of tetanus. It would not contribute to survival within the phagolysosome.

question: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of sore throat and a fever. Physical examination shows pharyngeal erythema with a tonsillar abscess. Culture of oropharyngeal secretions on sheep's blood agar grows colonies of gram-positive cocci that are surrounded by a zone of complete hemolysis. Another culture of the secretions on mannitol salt agar grows well and causes the medium to turn yellow. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is C. The description of the agent is consistent with a staphylococcal organism (catalase-positive, gram-positive cocci that grow on mannitol salt agar). The organism is most likely Staphylococcus aureus since it was able to ferment mannitol (as evidenced by the color change in the mannitol salt agar after incubation) and was beta-hemolytic. Other characteristics of this organism are coagulase production and excretion of DNAse from colonies. Staphylococcal organisms are also notorious for formation of abscesses; this patient has an abscess in the tonsillar region. The diphtheria bacilli Corynebacterium diphtheriae (choice A) are gram-positive, pleomorphic rods that are arranged in palisades. They are non-hemolytic and will not grow on mannitol salt agar. These organisms produce a whitish-gray pseudomembrane on the pharynx or the larynx; constitutional symptoms from toxemia are the major features of diphtheria. Epiglottitis is the most common disease of the upper respiratory tract produced by Haemophilus influenzae (choice B) a gram-negative, encapsulated rod. It is also a common cause of otitis media in children and may cause bronchitis, bronchiolitis, and pneumonia in adults. Streptococcus pyogenes (choice D) is a beta-hemolytic gram-positive coccus that grows in chains, as opposed to the random, grapelike clusters of the staphylococci. Streptococcus pyogenes is the most common cause of pharyngitis, which is usually manifested by severe sore throat, fever, a beefy-red pharynx and a tonsillar exudate. Streptococcus salivarius (choice E) is a gram-positive coccus that is usually alpha-hemolytic. It is normal flora of the oral cavity and is sometimes implicated in subacute bacterial endocarditis, but is not associated with tonsillar abscesses.

question: A 58-year-old man with a history of colorectal cancer has had fatigue weight loss, and myalgias for several weeks. He has a temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows punctate hemorrhages under the fingernails and a murmur is heard on auscultation of the chest Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the development of these symptoms in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Streptococcus bovis is a group D Streptococcus. There is a significant association between S. bovis bacteremia and endocarditis with carcinoma of the colon and other colonic diseases. Every patient with S. bovis bacteremia should undergo gastrointestinal and cardiac evaluation. Up to 50% of patients with S. bovis bacteremia are reported to have underlying colonic malignancies. In another study, 25-50% of cases of S. bovis bacteremia were associated with endocarditis, especially in patients with preexisting valvular lesions. The group D Streptococci are distinguished by having a cell wall carbohydrate composed of glycerol teichoic acid. S. agalactiae (choice A) is a group B Streptococcus that is the number-one cause of neonatal meningitis and septicemia in the United States. S. mutans and S. sanguis (choices C and F) are viridans streptococci, which are normal flora of the oral mucosa. While they are associated with bacterial endocarditis, it is usually associated with invasive dental work and a preexisting heart valve defect. S. pneumoniae (choice D) which is a non-groupable Streptococcus (it does not have a C cell wall carbohydrate), is the most common cause of typical pneumonia in the United States. S. pyogenes (choice E) is a group A Streptococcus and is associated with pharyngitis, poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, rheumatic fever, and scarlet fever.

question: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a several month history of chronic fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats. Laboratory studies show that he is HIV-positive by ELISA and Western blot. His CD4 cell count is 525/mm³. He declines anti-retroviral therapy. Which of the following sets of findings is most likely at his next visit?
options: A. Virus, p24, RNA Increasing | CD4+ Decreasing | Anti-p24 Decreasing | Anti-env Increasing slightly
B. Virus, p24, RNA Increasing | CD4+ Decreasing | Anti-p24 Increasing | Anti-env Decreasing slightly
C. Virus, p24, RNA Increasing | CD4+ No change | Anti-p24 Increasing | Anti-env Decreasing slightly
D. Virus, p24, RNA Decreasing | CD4+ Normal | Anti-p24 No change | Anti-env No change
E. Virus, p24, RNA Undetectable | CD4+ Normal | Anti-p24 Decreasing | Anti-env Increasing
explanation: The correct answer is A. Since the patient's CD4 cell count is 525/mm³, he will soon enter the early symptomatic period during which there is generalized decline in immune function, without the presence of an AIDS-defining condition. As the number of CD4-positive cells declines further, his ability to produce any isotype of antibody other than IgM will decline, and thus antibodies to the capsid antigen (p24) will decline. Since these antibodies are the ones that keep virions out of the circulation, there will now be an increase in viral load in the patient, measured by RT-PCR for viral RNA, and virions will be found in the blood. Antibodies against the envelope glycoproteins are generally IgM, which does not require a primary immune response. The IgM anti-env antibody can be made in the absence of TH cells. Increasing p24 virus, and RNA, decreasing CD4 cells, increasing p24 antibodies, and decreasing env antibodies (choice B) is not correct, because as CD4-positive cells decline, there is decreasing ability for isotype switching, and p24 antibodies will decline because they are IgG in isotype. Envelope antibodies will remain stable or increase slightly, not decrease. Increasing p24, virus, and RNA, stable CD4 cells, increasing p24 antibodies, and decreasing env antibodies (choice C) is not correct because in untreated cases CD4 counts will decline consistently until death. Decreasing p24, virus, and RNA, normal CD4 cells, no change in p24 antibodies, and no change in env antibodies (choice D) is not correct because untreated cases do not self-resolve, and decreasing amounts of virus constituents in the blood would indicate that the patient's condition is improving. Undetectable p24, virus, and RNA, normal CD4 cells, decreasing p24 antibodies, and increasing env antibodies (choice E) is not correct, because, again, it suggests that the patient has resolved his infection by removing all the virus constituents from the blood. This does not happen in the absence of anti-retroviral therapy.

question: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of dysmenorrhea and lower abdominal tenderness. A pelvic examination shows adnexal tenderness and a mucopurulent discharge without blood Examination of cervical cells shows intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies when stained with Giemsa stain. Which of the following properties is characteristic of the most likely causal organism?
options: A. It has sterols in its membrane
B. It lacks a cell wall
C. Its cell membrane contains ergosterol
D. Its cell wall contains mycolic acids
E. It uses an elementary body to infect cells
explanation: The correct answer is E. This young woman is infected with Chlamydia trachomatis the most common bacterial sexually transmitted disease in the United States. This genus of organisms is unusual in that they do not make ATP and are thus obligate intracellular parasites, and they possess a cell wall in which muramic acid is missing from the peptidoglycan. Chlamydia species utilize an elementary body to infect host cells and a reticulate body to replicate within host cells. It has sterols in its membrane (choice A) is a statement that describes the mycoplasmas. These are the only prokaryotes that totally lack a cell wall, but instead have sterols in their membranes. It lacks a cell wall (choice B) is also a statement that describes the mycoplasmas. These prokaryotes are devoid of a cell wall but have sterols in their membranes. Its cell membrane contains ergosterol (choice C) is a statement that describes the fungi. The ergosterol molecule is unique to fungi and is the target molecule for nystatin and the imidazoles. A cell wall containing mycolic acids (choice D) describes the genus Mycobacterium. Mycolic acids are long-chain fatty acids that give this group its resistance to environmental stresses and its acid-fast staining characteristics.

question: A 28-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician because of recurrent growth of a whitish film on his tongue and buccal mucosa. There is no evidence of esophageal involvement. A scraping of the lesion is placed in a test tube containing animal serum and the results of this evaluation are shown in the photomicrograph. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug of choice for this patient's illness?
options: A. It blocks ergosterol synthesis by inhibiting squalene epoxidase
B. It inhibits the CYP450—dependent enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase
C. It inhibits the synthesis of beta-glucan
D. It interferes with mitotic spindle function
E. It interferes with thymidylate synthetase and DNA synthesis
explanation: The correct answer is B. This is a case of oral thrush, an overgrowth of the oral cavity with Candida albicans which is a normal flora organism that commonly causes problems in immunosuppressed patients. The image shown is that of the germ-tube test, the formation of pseudohyphae in animal serum, which is considered a definitive diagnostic for the organism. In HIV-infected individuals, oral and/or pharyngeal candidiasis infections are generally treated with clotrimazole troches or fluconazole oral tablets. Fluconazole acts as an inhibitor of the fungal cytochrome P-450 dependent enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase. In a fungus, lanosterol 14-α-demethylase functions to convert lanosterol to ergosterol. This is responsible for the fungistatic effect of the “conazole” antifungals. Terbinafine blocks ergosterol synthesis (choice A). This agent is primarily used to treat dermatophytic infections, particularly tinea unguium. The echinocandins, such as caspofungin, inhibit the synthesis of beta-glucan (choice C). These agents are indicated for invasive candidiasis, not simple oral thrush. Caspofungin can also be used in the treatment of oral/esophageal candidiasis, however this agent would be used only for simple oral candidiasis when therapy with fluconazole alone does not effectively treat the patients oropharyngeal candidiasis. Griseofulvin interferes with mitotic spindle function (choice D). This agent is primarily used orally against dermatophytes, as it concentrates in the stratum corneum. Flucytosine interferes with thymidylate synthetase (choice E). This agent is used in the treatment of cryptococcosis. It is contraindicated in HIV patients, as it may cause bone marrow suppression in those patients.

question: A medical virology laboratory coinfects cells in a tissue culture flask with influenza A (H3N2) and influenza A (H1N1). The flask is incubated for 48 hours and the progeny viruses are analyzed. Four distinct variants of influenza A are isolated: H3N2, H1N1, H3N1, and H1N2 Which of the following viral attributes most likely made the production of H3N1 and H1N2 variants possible?
explanation: The correct answer is D. Influenza A is well known for its ability to undergo genetic shift or reassortment of the pieces of its segmented genome. Because the genome of this RNA virus occurs in eight separate segments, random rearrangements can occur when two related viruses infect a single cell. The packaging of the progeny viruses can then become drastically changed, and pandemics can result in the population due to the sudden appearance of new antigenic types. There have been four major pandemics of influenza since 1933. Genetic shift can occur only in viruses with segmented genomes (separate pieces of RNA that can be exchanged in the progeny). There are four families of viruses with segmented genomes: Reovirus, Orthomyxovirus, Bunyavirus, and Arenavirus. Complementation (choice A) is the process by which two related viruses that have gene defects can “complement” each other when coinfecting a cell, and thereby produce progeny by the sharing of gene products. A variation of this process happens in the case of the delta agent infecting cells coinfected with the hepatitis B virus. The genome of the delta agent is defective in its ability to capture an envelope itself, but when it exists in the same cell as the hepatitis B virus, it can use the hepatitis B envelope-capturing gene to surround itself with an envelope and complete its lifecycle. High mutational rate (choice B) refers to minor antigenic changes based on random mutations, and is a potential cause of genetic drift in virus infections. Although genetic drift due to mutational change can happen in virtually any reproducing organism, it is most common in RNA viruses. It is best described as a mechanism for causing antigenic drift in the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Phenotypic mixing (choice C) is the process by which two related viruses coexisting in a single cell can create a generation of progeny with components of both viruses making up their capsids. The genomes are not altered, but the capsid consists of components of both parental viruses. Syncytia formation (choice E) is the property of forming multinucleated giant cells during viral infection. Fusing one infected cell to the uninfected cell next door allows some viruses to move within the host without being exposed to immunologic products outside the cell. Syncytia formation is a common mechanism of immunologic evasion in the Herpesvirus family, in measles, mumps, and in respiratory syncytial virus infections.

question: A 73-year-old woman with a history of diabetes comes to the physician because of left ear pain and drainage of pus from the ear canal. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness over the left mastoid bone. The most likely causal organism is also responsible for causing which of the following?
explanation: The correct answer is A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa causes malignant otitis externa which is a severe necrotizing infection of the external ear canal. Infection tends to spread to the mastoid bone, temporal bone, sigmoid sinus, base of the skull, meninges, and brain. Patients at increased risk include the elderly, people with diabetes, and the immunocompromised. Pseudomonas is also associated with many other clinical syndromes, including infection following traumatic wounds to the feet in persons wearing sneakers or rubber-soled shoes (since the organism can be cultured from the shoes), burn infections, and pneumonia in cystic fibrosis patients. Ecthyma gangrenosum is the name of the characteristic lesion that occurs during Pseudomonas septicemias. It has a black, necrotic center and a raised hemorrhagic ring outside. Erythema migrans (choice B) is the target-shaped rash that occurs in the early stages of Lyme disease. Food poisoning (choice C) is not commonly caused by Pseudomonas. Nonmycotic mycetoma (choice D) is caused by Actinomyces and Nocardia. Pharyngitis (choice E) is not commonly caused by Pseudomonas.

question: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever, cough, and poor feeding. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F) and respirations are 32/min. A chest x-ray shows bilateral patchy infiltrates and chest auscultation reveals wheezing Which of the following best describes the most likely causal organism responsible for these findings in the patient?
options: A. Double-stranded DNA, naked, icosahedral virus
B. Negative-sense, single-stranded RNA, nonsegmented, helical, enveloped virus
C. Negative-sense, single-stranded RNA with eight segments, helical, enveloped virus
D. Positive-sense, single-stranded RNA, helical, enveloped virus
E. Positive-sense, single-stranded RNA, naked, icosahedral virus
explanation: The correct answer is B. Respiratory syncytial virus is the most common cause of bronchiolitis and pneumonia in children younger than 1 year of age. Outbreaks occur seasonally in winter and early spring. Infection does not result in lasting immunity, and reinfection can occur. The virus belongs to the Paramyxoviridae, a group of negative-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses that are nonsegmented, helical, and enveloped. Double-stranded DNA, naked, icosahedral virus (choice A) describes the Adenoviruses, which are capable of causing conjunctivitis, pharyngitis, upper respiratory disease and gastroenteritis. However, these agents are not common causes of bronchiolitis and pneumonia in infants. Negative-sense single-stranded RNA with eight segments, helical, enveloped virus (choice C) describes the Orthomyxoviruses, which include influenza virus. Influenza is a systemic illness characterized by the sudden onset of fever, headache myalgias, malaise, and prostration, followed by cough, nasal obstruction, and sore throat. The lower respiratory tract may also be involved. Positive-sense, single-stranded RNA, helical, enveloped virus (choice D) describes the Coronaviruses, which cause the common cold (nasal obstruction and discharge, sneezing, mild or no fever, occasional sore throat, and/or cough) and acute pharyngitis (sore throat with or without cervical adenopathy, ulceration, and conjunctivitis). SARS-CoV also belongs to this family and causes a seasonal acute respiratory distress syndrome, which is usually imported into this hemisphere from the Far East. Positive-sense single-stranded RNA naked, icosahedral virus (choice E) describes the Picornaviruses and Caliciviruses. Within the Picornaviridae, rhinoviruses cause the common cold but would not be common agents of bronchiolitis and pneumonia in infants.

question: A diagram of a resistance transfer factor is shown. Which of the following do the rectangular blocks identified by the arrows represent?
options: A. Gene loci for recombinase enzymes
explanation: The correct answer is D. A resistance transfer factor is a bacterial plasmid that encodes one or more drug-resistance genes and has the capability of mediating its own transfer to another bacterium during conjugation (it possesses the F operon). Most of the known resistance transfer factors have been formed by the accumulation of transposons into fertility factor plasmids. Transposons are mobile genetic elements that are capable of movement within bacterial cells. When they carry drug-resistance genes and accumulate in plasmids that already possess the F operon, multiple drug-resistant plasmids (resistance transfer factors) are formed. The flanking sequences in the DNA of a transposon are indirect repeats that are complementary and antiparallel to one another. When transposons insert themselves into a new location, they do so by site-specific recombination, creating direct repeats (identical nucleotide sequences created during the repair of a staggered cut created by the transposon restriction endonuclease). Therefore, in the diagram shown, the rectangular blocks could represent either the direct repeats caused by transposition or the indirect repeats that are the outside edges of the mobile segments of DNA. In either event, they are representations of points at which transposons have inserted their mobile DNA via site-specific recombination. Gene loci for recombinase enzymes (choice A) is not correct. Although each transposon (and there are three that have moved to create the resistance transfer factor shown) carries its own restriction endonuclease and the gene that encodes it, the diagram clearly shows the presence of two rectangles for each of the transposons, and a given transposon would carry only one copy, not two copies, of its endonuclease gene. Introns (choice B) are repetitive, non-transcribed segments of DNA that do not occur in prokaryotes. Points of bacteriophage insertion (choice C) or insertion sequences are palindromic sequences of nucleotides in a bacterial genome that are identical to those found in the genomes of temperate phages. When these sequences are cleaved by a restriction endonuclease the phage genome can be inserted by site-specific recombination into the bacterial chromosome and the state of lysogeny is begun. Bacteriophages are not involved in the formation of resistance transfer factors. Transposons (choice E) are mobile segments of DNA that are responsible for the formation of multiple drug-resistant plasmids such as the one shown here, but they are not represented by the rectangular blocks. In the diagram, the transposons are the sequences between the rectangular blocks, so there are three transposons that accumulated here to create this resistance transfer factor.

question: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain over the past 24 hours. She recently returned from a 4-month trip to Central America. She says that she had bloody diarrhea for the last 4 weeks of her trip. A CT scan of the abdomen shows lesions that appear to be multiple abscesses. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism of this illness?
explanation: The correct answer is B. This patient probably has hepatic amebiasis, which is a life-threatening complication of intestinal infection with Entamoeba histolytica. E. histolytica is transmitted via the fecal-oral route. Intestinal colonization (which may be asymptomatic) always precedes infection of the liver. The abscesses generally contain necrotic debris, with amoebas located along the edges of the abscess. Treatment for liver abscesses of this origin is metronidazole, while iodoquinol is useful to destroy the luminal stages of the parasite. Ascaris lumbricoides (choice A) can cause intestinal obstruction, and may cause abscesses if it invades the common bile duct. It would not cause bloody diarrhea. Enterobius vermicularis (choice C) is the pinworm, which inhabits the rectum. Bloody diarrhea can also be seen with some strains of Salmonella (choice D) and Shigella (choice E), but these organisms do not usually cause hepatic abscesses. Bacterial causes of hepatic abscesses include E. coli, Klebsiella, Streptococcus, Staphylococcus, Bacteroides and Pseudomonas.

question: A 38-year-old man from Missouri comes to the physician because of a low-grade fever and a progressive headache for the past week. He says that sunlight hurts his eyes, and that he has been nauseated and weak History includes Pneumocystis pneumonia and a total CD4 count of 49/mm³. Examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows 4 WBC/mm³, all of which are lymphocytes, protein of 50 mg/dL, and glucose of 30 mg/dL. Which of the following best describes the morphology of the infectious form of the most likely causal organism?
options: B. Budding yeasts resembling a wheel with spokes
explanation: The correct answer is C. This is a classic case of Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis. Clues include the patient population (HIV-positive), and the CSF findings suggesting a fungal etiology. Cryptococcus is the most common fungal meningitis of the immunocompromised in the United States. It is a monomorphic fungus, unlike many of the classic pathogens within the fungal group, so the encapsulated yeast form would be found both in clinical specimens and in the environment as the infectious form. Broad-based, budding yeasts (choice A) would be the forms expected to be found in clinical specimens (not environmental forms) from patients infected with Blastomyces dermatitidis - which is far more likely to present with skin and bone lesions than with meningitis. Budding yeasts in a 'pilot's wheel' arrangement (choice B) would be the form expected to be found in clinical specimens (not environmental forms) from patients infected with Paracoccidioides brasiliensis which is limited in geographic region to Central and South America and typically presents as a primary pulmonary disease. Intracellular yeasts within macrophages (choice D) are the diagnostic form of Histoplasma capsulatum which, despite its name, is not an encapsulated yeast. It is primarily a pulmonary infection acquired by exposure to the droppings of birds or bats. Septate hyphae with 45-degree angles (choice E) are the transmission forms of Aspergillus which is a major opportunistic infection. Aspergillus may cause meningitis in this patient population, but it is not nearly as common as Cryptococcus. Spherules (choice F) would be the yeast forms characteristic of Coccidioides immitis which may be a cause of fungal meningitis in immunologically compromised individuals but is geographically restricted to the Sonoran desert zone of the United States (San Joaquin Valley fever).

question: A 32-year-old schoolteacher in her first trimester of pregnancy is concerned about a student in her class who develops a bright-red rash on her cheeks Two days later, the student's shoulders, upper thorax, and upper arms become red, and develop a lacy, reticulated appearance. The physician should monitor this pregnancy closely for the development of which of the fetal conditions?
explanation: The correct answer is E. There are two parts to this question. The first is realizing that the student's illness is the classic description of Fifth disease, or erythema infectiosum. It is caused by parvovirus B19, which is spread from human to human. Animals do not carry this particular parvovirus. The disease is contagious prior to the onset of the rash. The initial symptoms, during the period of contagion, are nonspecific constitutional symptoms such as fever, myalgia, lethargy, coryza, pharyngitis, and abdominal pain. When the typical 'slapped-cheek' rash begins, the student is no longer contagious. The rash begins with the erythematous cheeks, then the upper part of the body becomes red and then reticulated, i.e., the typical lacy appearance of the rash develops. This fades but can come and go for the next 3 weeks. Parvovirus is a cause of aplastic anemia. It may be responsible for aplastic crises in patients with sickle-cell anemia. In addition, exposure of a pregnant woman in the first trimester may result in a fetus with aplastic anemia, which results in non-immune hydrops fetalis. Because the virus infects immature erythrocytes, causing severe anemia, the fetus dies of cardiac failure. Congenital heart defects (choice A) may occur due to many different reasons. They are, however associated with the congenital rubella syndrome, in which a patent ductus arteriosus and pulmonary artery stenosis are most commonly seen. Cutaneous scarring (choice B) occurs in an infant with congenital varicella syndrome (exposure to varicella during pregnancy). The other major feature is limb defects. Hemolytic anemias (choice C) are usually not associated with prenatal exposure to an infectious agent. They may be produced due to isoimmunization (Rh disease), red cell membrane defects (spherocytosis), or red cell enzyme defects (pyruvate kinase deficiency), as well as many other etiologies. Hydrocephalus (choice D) also has diverse etiologies. There is an association with prenatal exposure to mumps and the fetal development of aqueductal stenosis resulting in obstructive hydrocephalus.

question: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a fever, sore throat, and rash. Physical examination shows an exudative pharyngitis, cervical lymphadenopathy and tenderness, and a diffuse, sandpaper-like erythematous rash. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the expression of the toxin that produces these signs?
explanation: The correct answer is C. The question describes a girl with streptococcal pharyngitis with a characteristic rash. This combination is scarlet fever, and is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes via its erythrogenic exotoxin (Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin, SPE). SPE-A, SPE-B, and SPE-C. The production of this extra virulence is an example of lysogenic conversion. In this case, the DNA of a temperate phage is inserted into the bacterial chromosome and produces a prophage. Besides the repressor protein, the prophage DNA also directs the synthesis of other gene products that make the bacteria more pathogenic. Conjugation (choice A) is one of the three methods whereby DNA is transferred from one cell to another. In this case, it is done by cell-to-cell contact. It is not the means by which the streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins are expressed. Homologous recombination (choice B) is a gene exchange process that stabilizes some genes that have been introduced by conjugation, transformation, or transduction. During the process there is an exchange of pieces of DNA between a linear piece of DNA and a region on the stable circular bacterial chromosome. In site-specific recombination (choice D) a DNA molecule is integrated into a molecule of DNA with which it has no homology, except for a small site on each DNA that is called an insertion site. The end result is the sum of the two original DNA molecules. Transformation (choice E) is another way in which genes are transferred. In this case, naked DNA is taken up by another cell. Cells that can take up naked DNA from the environment need to become competent, and do so under certain environmental conditions. The newly introduced DNA is generally linear, homologous DNA from the same type of cell, but one that may be genetically diverse. Once introduced into the new cell, some genes may become stabilized by homologous recombination.

question: During an investigational study, new combinations of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase molecules are found on the progeny viruses of a prevalent serotype of the swine influenza virus and the prevalent serotype of the human influenza virus. The progeny viruses are genetically stable when purified and are used to infect new tissue cultures. Which of the following mechanisms most likely accounts for the production of the new viral progeny?
explanation: The correct answer is C. Influenza and other viruses with segmented genomes (Reovirus, Orthomyxovirus, Bunyavirus, and Arenavirus) are capable of genetic reassortment. This is an accidental 'shuffling' of the segments of genomic RNA so that new genetic combinations can be produced. Viruses that have segmented genomes have multiple pieces of RNA that must be assembled correctly in the progeny to produce a new generation that is identical to the parental generation. When accidental rearrangements occur, genetic shift results; and in influenza, this is responsible for the production of pandemics of disease. Complementation (choice A) occurs when two viruses infect a single cell. If one is defective in a certain gene product, progeny viruses can be produced as long as that defect can be 'complemented' by the makeup of the other virus. If both viruses have the same defect, no progeny viruses can be produced. In the case given here, two viable viruses were grown in a single cell and new combinations of surface molecules were produced. Genetic drift (choice B) refers to random mutational changes that can occur in any reproducing organism. These changes can change the surface of the organism, which affects the host immune response to the organism. Changes such as these are more gradual than genetic shift, and are best described in viruses such as HIV. Phenotypic masking (choice D) refers to occasions in which two related viruses infect a cell and the capsid produced in the progeny generation is created from the genome of one of the viruses while the genome included in the capsid is from the other virus. Thus, one genome is 'masked' or covered with the antigens of the other virus. In the case described here, combinations of surface molecules were expressed. Phenotypic mixing (choice E) refers to occasions in which two related viruses infect a cell and the capsid produced in the progeny generation is a mixture of the capsid antigens from the two parental viruses. Since the genomic RNA is not actually reassorted in that case, it would not be a stable genetic change but simply a reflection of the antigens of both parental viruses being inserted on the surfaces of a single progeny generation.

question: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of fever of 39°C (102°F), abdominal pain and arthralgias. He had a sore throat and a rash 4 weeks ago. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. A pansystolic blowing murmur is heard on auscultation of the chest and is best appreciated at the apex Laboratory studies show an increased C-reactive protein. An ECG shows a prolonged PR interval. Which of the following is the most likely attribute of the causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is C. This case is classic for rheumatic fever which is diagnosed by a positive Jones criteria (2 major criteria or 1 major and 2 minor criteria) in the presence of a previous history of Streptococcus infection. Major criteria: Migratory polyarthritis, Carditis, Subcutaneous nodules on the back of the wrist, the outside elbow, and the front of the knees, Erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea. Minor criteria: Fever, Arthralgia Joint pain without swelling, Laboratory abnormalities; increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, increased C-reactive protein, leukocytosis, Electrocardiogram abnormalities: a prolonged PR interval, Evidence of Group A Strep infection: elevated Antistreptolysin O titer, or DNAase, Previous rheumatic fever or inactive heart disease. Rheumatic fever is a sequela of untreated infection with group A streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes). Strep. pyogenes is differentiated from the other beta-hemolytic streptococci by its sensitivity to the antibiotic bacitracin. The catalase test (choice A) is used to differentiate staphylococci from streptococci. Staphylococci are catalase-positive; streptococci are catalase-negative. Strep. pyogenes is catalase-negative. The coagulase test (choice B) is used to differentiate Staphylococcus aureus from the other staphylococcus species. Staph. aureus is coagulase-positive; the others are coagulase-negative. Sensitivity to novobiocin (choice D) is used to differentiate Staph. saprophyticus (resistant) from Staph. epidermidis (sensitive). Sensitivity to Optochin (choice E) is used to differentiate Strep. pneumoniae (sensitive) from viridans streptococci (resistant).

question: A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a spiking fever and tachypnea. He has a history of urinary retention secondary to prostatic hyperplasia. Physical examination shows intercostal muscle retractions and bilateral inspiratory crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest A chest x-ray shows bilateral interstitial and alveolar infiltrates. Cultures of the blood will most likely grow which of the following?
explanation: The correct answer is B. Escherichia coli is a common pathogen that is associated with urinary tract infections (UTIs) and that commonly causes cystitis. It is a gram-negative, oxidase-negative rod that reduces nitrates to nitrites. It is important to know that the pili and motility of the bacteria contribute to its pathogenesis. Patients with cystitis can develop bacteremia and subsequent septic shock and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
