The present patient has an obstructive lesion of the urinary tract that predisposes him to the overgrowth of microorganisms such as E. coli. Pulmonary symptoms are consistent with ARDS. Gram-negative diplococci (choice A) might be a Neisseria sp. or Moraxella catarrhalis. N. gonorrhoeae is the cause of gonorrhea, a sexually transmitted disease that presents asymptomatically or with urethritis. Patients are usually younger and sexually active. M. catarrhalis is usually implicated as a cause of otitis media and sinusitis in children. It is also implicated as a cause of purulent tracheobronchitis and pneumonia in a population of patients who are older than 50 years and who have underlying obstructive lung disease. Gram-positive cocci (choice C) such as Staphylococcus aureus and S. epidermidis rarely cause cystitis. S. saprophyticus causes UTIs but the patients are typically young, sexually active women. Enterococcus is a relatively common cause of UTIs in hospitalized patients with indwelling urinary catheters who are receiving broad-spectrum cephalosporin antibiotics. Enterococcal bacteremia can lead to endocarditis, but would not commonly cause ARDS. Gram-positive diplococci (choice D) would be a description of Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. Gram-positive rods (choice E) would include members of the following genera: Clostridium, Bacillus, Listeria, and Corynebacterium. The only significant member of this group to produce UTIs is Corynebacterium urealyticum (C. jeikeium). This organism creates an alkaline urine environment with the potential for stone formation. Patients are usually immunocompromised or have had recurrent UTIs.

question: Thirteen cases of hepatitis are confirmed within a poor African community. The mortality rate is particularly high among pregnant woman. The most likely causal organism belongs to which of the following viral families?
explanation: The correct answer is D. Hepatitis E is an important cause of epidemics of enterically transmitted acute hepatitis. These infections are most common in India, Asia, Africa, and Central America and are associated with a very high mortality among pregnant women. Hepatitis E is caused by a naked capsid RNA virus belonging to the Hepeviridae (formerly Caliciviridae). Adenoviridae (choice A) is a group of naked capsid double-stranded DNA viruses that may cause upper respiratory infections, gastroenteritis, and conjunctivitis, but are not generally associated with hepatitis. Flaviviridae (choice B) is the family to which hepatitis C virus belongs. This is an enveloped RNA virus that is usually transmitted sexually or parenterally, and although it is associated with a high degree of chronicity and carcinogenesis, it is not usually a cause of high mortality among pregnant women. Hepadnaviridae (choice C) is the family to which hepatitis B virus belongs. It is an enveloped double-stranded DNA virus that is sexually or parenterally transmitted. It is associated with the production of chronic infections and hepatocellular carcinoma, but is not known for causing high mortality among pregnant women. Picornaviridae (choice E) is the family of naked capsid RNA viruses to which hepatitis A virus belongs. Although this virus is fecal-orally transmitted and therefore more common in developing countries, it is not associated with a high degree of mortality in pregnant women.

question: An investigator is studying virus life cycles. He creates a continuous culture of kidney fibroblasts that are suitable hosts for a large variety of viral agents. In one experiment, the nuclei of these cells are removed by cytosurgery, and various viral agents are added to the cultures, Following culture of the viruses with the enucleated cells, the yield of cytopathic units of virus is quantified. Which of the following viruses would be capable of replication in these enucleated cells?
explanation: The correct answer is E. Most RNA viruses (e.g., poliovirus) replicate in the cytoplasm and therefore can replicate in enucleated cells. Poliovirus belongs to the family Picornaviridae. These viruses are non-enveloped and have an icosahedral nucleocapsid that contains positive-sense RNA. The exception to the rule regarding RNA viruses is the family Orthomyxoviridae, the influenza viruses (choice C). Orthomyxoviruses undergo transcription and RNA replication in the nucleus of the host cell because they need to cannibalize the capped 5' termini of cellular RNAs for use as primers for viral mRNA transcription. Adenoviruses (choice A) are non-enveloped and have an icosahedral nucleocapsid that contains a double-stranded linear DNA genome. All DNA viruses except the family Poxviridae carry out their replication in the nucleus, and therefore would not be capable of completing their life cycles in enucleated cells. Cytomegalovirus (choice B) is a member of family Herpesviridae. It is an enveloped virus with an icosahedral nucleocapsid that contains a double-stranded linear DNA genome, and thus replicates in the nucleus. JC virus (choice D) belongs to family Polyomaviridae. It is non-enveloped and has an icosahedral nucleocapsid that contains a double-stranded circular DNA genome. It would not be able to complete its life cycle in an enucleated cell.

question: A total of 2 x 10² Streptococcus viridans are inoculated into a flask containing 1 L of enriched broth. If the lag time is 30 minutes and the generation time is 20 minutes, how many bacteria will there be in the culture after 2.5 hours?
explanation: The correct answer is E. During the lag time by definition, bacteria newly introduced into a culture will undergo metabolic changes necessary for use of the medium, but will not increase in number. Therefore, at the end of the first 30 minutes of elapsed time the number of bacteria in the culture will be 2 x 10². Thereafter, the number of bacteria will double every 20 minutes (the definition of 'generation time'). This means that after 2.5 hours (150 minutes) of total elapsed time, 120 minutes (150 min - 30 min lag) will be available for growth. Since generation time is 20 minutes, six generations will have occurred (120 min / 20 min/gen = 6 gen). So the original inoculum will double six times: 2 x 10² * 2⁶ = 2 x 10² * 64 = 128 x 10². Choice A (6 x 10²) is not the correct answer. The student who selects this answer forgot that lag periods occur only once per culture, and also incorrectly multiplied the starting inoculum number by an incorrect number of generations (three). Choice B (12 x 10²) is not the correct answer and reflects the common student error of counting the number of possible generations and multiplying by that number. Remember that every generation time means that every bacterium in that culture has divided into two, so the student must multiply by 2 six times, or 2⁶. Choice C (16 x 10²) is not the correct answer and reflects the common student error of forgetting that the lag time occurs only one time per culture. The student who selects this answer divided the 2.5 hours of culture time between three lag periods and three correctly calculated generations (2³). Choice D (32 x 10²) is not the correct answer and reflects the common student error of including the lag period within the first generation time (overlapping the two, and forgetting that they are distinct and separate periods). The student who did this would therefore count five possible generations and, multiplying correctly thereafter by 2⁵, would arrive at this incorrect answer.

question: A 33-year-old man with AIDS develops multifocal encephalitis. He reports having a unilateral, vesicular rash 1 month ago Treatment with acyclovir is begun, but he dies on the fourth day after admission. Which of the following viruses is most likely responsible for the development of encephalitis in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is D. The specific clue to the cause of the severe encephalitis in this AIDS patient is the history of shingles, due to reactivation of the herpes zoster (varicella zoster) virus. In otherwise healthy adults, the virus (which is usually introduced to the body as a childhood case of chickenpox) remains dormant in a dorsal root ganglion only to reactivate in later life, causing a painful vesicular eruption that characteristically conforms to the distribution of a single dermatome. In AIDS patients, the virus can cause a severe multifocal encephalitis that may be resistant to acyclovir therapy. Cytomegalovirus (choice A) can cause disseminated disease (including brain infection) in AIDS patients but is less likely in the present patient, given his past history of shingles. Herpes simplex type-1 (choice B) and type-2 (choice C) can cause disseminated disease (including brain infection) in AIDS patients but are less likely in this patient, given his past history of shingles and the lack of response to acyclovir. Measles virus (choice E) appears to be related to subacute sclerosing panencephalitis but this condition is not specifically increased in AIDS patients.

question: A 54-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes comes to the physician because of an unresolved skin lesion on his foot. The lesion appeared several weeks ago, but recently has expanded and become painful. Physical examination shows a 5-cm lesion with a black, necrotic center and raised erythematous edges. Which of the following toxins has a mechanism of action most similar to the toxin most likely responsible for this patient's skin lesion?
explanation: The correct answer is E. This patient's wound is infected with Pseudomonas aeruginosa and the characteristic lesion described is called ecthyma gangrenosum. The Pseudomonas exotoxin A, which is responsible for the tissue damage, inhibits protein synthesis by acting on EF-2, with a primary target cell in the liver. The diphtheria toxin has a similar action, although its target cells are heart and nerve. Anthrax toxin (choice A) is a three-component toxin that contains a single binding component (protective antigen) and two active components. The edema factor (EF) is an adenylate cyclase that causes fluid loss from cells, and the lethal factor (LF) is an endoprotease that causes apoptosis. Botulinum toxin (choice B) is a neurotoxin that prevents neurosecretory vesicles from fusing with synaptic membranes and releasing acetylcholine. Cholera toxin (choice C) acts to increase adenylate cyclase activity by ribosylation of GTP-binding protein. Clostridium perfringens alpha toxin (choice D) is a lecithinase. Escherichia coli labile toxin (choice F) works in a fashion similar to the cholera toxin. Pertussis toxin (choice G) causes fluid loss by ribosylating Gi. Shigatoxin (choice H) decreases protein synthesis by inhibiting the 60S ribosomal subunit. Streptococcal erythrogenic toxins (choice I) act as superantigens to increase cytokine production. Tetanus toxin (choice J) is a neurotoxin that inhibits the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and GABA.

question: A 4-year-old girl who recently emigrated from Somalia is brought fo the emergency department by her parents because of a fever and persistent cough. Her temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F). Physical examination shows inspiratory stridor, and a thick, gray film covering the uvula and pharynx that bleeds when displaced with a tongue depressor. Cultures of the oropharyngeal secretions grow gram-positive rods. In the image above, the patient's isolate is strain 1. Which of the following best describes strain 1?
options: B. It contains free plasmid DNA
D. It is not a diphtheroid
E. It is a motile organism
explanation: The correct answer is C. This child has developed diphtheria, which is rare in the United States because of our use of a very effective vaccine, the DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis). Immigrant children from impoverished areas of the globe might not have received adequate pediatric vaccinations or medical care. Diphtheria is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which is a gram-positive rod that is morphologically identical to normal flora organisms in the oropharynx, which are called diphtheroids. The difference between the pathogen and a normal flora diphtheroid is established using the ELEK test, which is shown in the image. This test involves diffusion in gel and a precipitation reaction that will occur when antigen (toxin) produced by the pathogen precipitates in the presence of antitoxin antibodies. In the image, the horizontal lines are the strains of bacteria to be tested for the production of the toxin. The vertical rectangle is a strip of filter paper that has been soaked in antitoxin antibodies. The white lines that form in the right angle where bacteria and filter paper meet are lines of precipitation. In C. diphtheriae, toxin production occurs following infection of the bacterium with a temperate phage that encodes the toxin. This is an example of lysogenic conversion. Episomes (choice A) are plasmids that have integrated into a bacterial chromosome; Diphtheria toxin is produced following stable integration of a phage genome into the chromosome, not due to the integration of plasmid DNA. Containing free plasmid DNA (choice B) is not the distinction between toxin-producing and non-producing strains of C. diphtheriae. The tetanus toxin is produced by virtue of possession of a non-conjugative plasmid by Clostridium tetani, but this is not true of diphtheria. It is not a diphtheroid (choice D). A diphtheroid is a non-toxin producing strain of C. diphtheriae (a normal flora organism). The strains that are streaked in the image as the two central lines are non-toxin producers (diphtheroids). It is a motile organism (choice E) is not the case and motility is not tested by the ELEK test. C. diphtheriae is a nonmotile organism, and the eventual development of peripheral neuropathies and cardiomyopathies during the pathogenesis are a result of the fact that the toxin becomes bloodborne, not that the organism moves from its site of residence in the oropharynx and upper airways.

question: A 43-year-old man who is a farmer develops a pustule on the hand. The pustule ruptures to form a black eschar surrounded by expanding edema. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the development of these symptoms in this patient?
options: C. A gram-negative rod requiring cysteine
D. A gram-negative rod with bipolar staining
explanation: The correct answer is A. The causative organism, Bacillus anthracis is found in many animal species, and humans can acquire the organism either through contact with animals or from locally contaminated soil. The pustule described in the question stem is called a 'malignant pustule' and may be accompanied by lymphadenopathy. Malignant pustules after rupture form a black eschar surrounded by edema. Most cases remain localized but death can occur as the result of complications such as bacteremia, meningitis, and pneumonia. Bacillus is a large, boxcar-shaped, gram-positive rod that forms spores centrally placed inside the bacillus, so that they look like bamboo shoots. A cigar-shaped yeast (choice B) describes the tissue form of Sporothrix schenckii, the agent of rose-gardener's disease. The lesion in such a case would be a mycetoma, draining yellow granular pus through multiple sinus tracts. A gram-negative rod requiring cysteine (choice C) describes Francisella tularensis, which causes tularemia. The organism can persist for weeks to months but does not form spores that could survive for hundreds or thousands of years. Most human cases occur in the endemic areas of the United States, in Arkansas and Missouri. A gram-negative rod with bipolar staining (choice D) describes Yersinia pestis, which causes bubonic plague. This organism does not form stable spores that can survive for extended periods of time. The hallmark of bubonic plague is the formation of buboes which are black, necrotic lymph nodes that form at the site of the vector fleabite. A large spirochete (choice E) describes Borrelia burgdorferi which causes Lyme disease. In the first stage of this disease, there is a localized, expanding, erythematous rash rather than an eschar. Furthermore, Lyme disease occurs in the United States, Europe, and Asia, corresponding to the distribution of Ixodes ticks, which spread the infection.

question: A 24-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician because of a headache, fever, vomiting, and generalized malaise. He has a brief seizure during the physical examination but does not become incontinent Laboratory studies of cerebrospinal fluid show: 150 cells, mostly lymphocytes, protein 60 mg/dL, and glucose 35 mg/dL Which of the following best describes the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is E. Cryptococcus neoformans is a common cause of meningitis in immunocompromised patients. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings in this case are consistent with a fungal infection in the central nervous system (100-1000 cells, mostly lymphocytes, glucose <50 mg/dL, protein >=50 mg/dL). Cryptococcus is a monomorphic encapsulated yeast. Gram-negative diplococci (choice A) describes Neisseria meningitidis. While this patient is in the appropriate age group for meningococcal meningitis, his HIV status and CSF findings indicate Cryptococcus. Gram-negative rods (choice B) would be indicative of any of the enteric organisms, particularly Escherichia coli. E. coli is an agent of neonatal meningitis and septicemia, but the patient's HIV status, age, and CSF findings refute a bacterial etiology. Gram-positive cocci (choice C) would be indicative of Streptococcus pneumoniae, the most common cause of adult meningitis, but the CSF findings in this case refute a bacterial etiology. Gram-positive rods (choice D) would be indicative of Listeria monocytogenes, which also could be a feasible answer but again, the patient's HIV status and CSF findings indicate Cryptococcus. Septate hyphae (choice F) would describe Aspergillus fumigatus, which is another fungal agent of meningitis in the immunocompromised, but it is not the most likely cause.

question: A 34-year-old man develops malaise, fatigue, and anorexia after returning from a trip to Calcutta, India. His symptoms slowly resolve and he does not seek treatment. Three months later laboratory studies of serum show HBsAb Negative, HBeAb Positive, HBcAb Positive, HBeAg Negative, HBsAg Negative. The absence of HBsAg and HBsAb is likely indicative of which of the following?
options: A. The patient has been successfully vaccinated against hepatitis B
B. The patient is anergic to hepatitis B
C. The patient is immune to hepatitis B
D. The patient is in the window period
E. The patient is making an excess of HBsAb
explanation: The correct answer is D. The patient has clearly returned from Calcutta with an active infection of hepatitis B, since his serum is positive for antibody against the core antigen of hepatitis B. This is the standard diagnostic for this infection. The absence of HBsAg and HBsAb from the serum reflects that the patient has entered the 'window period,' a good prognostic indicator because it demonstrates that antibodies to the surface antigen are being made in enough concentration to precipitate the corresponding antigen out of the circulation. Successful vaccination against hepatitis B (choice A) would be reflected by a positive titer of HBsAb only. The presence of antibody against the e core antigen reflects the existence of an active infection. Anergy to hepatitis B (choice B) is not correct because a person who is anergic is selectively unresponsive or tolerant to the antigen in question. Clearly, the presence of antibodies to several of these viral antigens in the serum demonstrates that this patient is not anergic. Although the patient is beginning to mount a protective immune response (antibody to HBsAg, choice C), it has not yet reached a protective level. If the patient were making an excess of HBsAb (choice E), there would be a rising titer of HBsAb. Thus the patient would be positive for HBsAb and negative for HBsAg.

question: An investigator is conducting a study of resistance of enterococcal species against penicillin and tetracycline. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism for the acquisition of this type of multi-drug resistance?
explanation: The correct answer is E. Transposons are mobile segments of DNA that can move themselves or a copy of themselves from one molecule of DNA to another. They are found in eukaryotic cells, bacteria, and viruses. They need at least one gene coding for a transposase, which are the enzymes involved in this movement. The transposase recognizes a specific nucleotide sequence, and the DNA inserts into this position. This insertion creates direct repeats on each side of the transposon. Transposons include some genes for drug resistance and play an important role in building multiple-drug resistance plasmids. These multi-drug resistance plasmids have played a major role in the explosive spread of drug resistances throughout the bacterial world. Bacteriophages (choice A) are viruses that infect the bacterial cell. Temperate phage DNA may be inserted into the bacterial chromosome. Bacteriophages are known to transmit vancomycin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus and imipenem resistance in Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Imported bacterial DNA (i.e., DNA that has been transferred into a cell by conjugation, transformation, or transduction) is on short linear pieces of DNA called exogenotes (choice B). Most linear DNA is not stable in cells because it is broken down by exonucleases. Although technically all transferred DNA involved in emerging drug resistances is of exogenote origin, this is not the best answer because it is not specific enough. A prophage (choice C) is a repressed temperate phage DNA inserted into a bacterial chromosome. The prophage DNA may encode the synthesis of products that make bacteria more pathogenic. This enhanced virulence is called lysogenic conversion. Bacteriophages are known to transmit vancomycin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus and imipenem resistance in Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Restriction endonucleases (choice D) are site-specific endonucleases that recognize specific base sequences and cleave the nucleic acid backbone in the interior of the nucleic acid strand. Although restriction endonucleases are involved in transposon movement, they are not the means by which the drug resistances are acquired.

question: A 58-year-old man with suspected lung cancer undergoes resection of a large cavitary lesion of the lung. Examination of the lesion shows that it contains a freely mobile, matted ball of material. Examination of tissue obtained on biopsy of the wall of the lesion shows granulomatous disease, which confirms tuberculosis infection. Which of the following images best represents the microscopic findings from the material inside the cavitary lesion in this patient?
explanation: The correct answer is C. This patient has a fungus ball, or aspergilloma. These noninvasive or minimally locally invasive lesions are caused by Aspergillus species. They show saprophytic growth in preexisting lung cavities, which may be formed by tuberculosis, tumor, bronchiectasis, or other chronic lung infections. Patients are often asymptomatic but may become allergic to the fungus. Aspergillus fumigatus is a dematiaceous (dark-colored) fungus which forms hyphae that branch at acute angles. Choice A is an image of the arthroconidia of Coccidioides immitis. These are the infectious forms that are found in desert sand. Coccidioides causes San Joaquin Valley fever, which may be an acute or chronic pulmonary condition but is unlikely to invade cavitary lesions of the lung and cause fungus balls. Choice B is an image of the infectious form of Sporothrix schenckii that causes rose-gardener's disease. These are hyphae with sleeves of conidia that would be found in vegetative material in gardens worldwide. Sporothrix causes cutaneous or lymphocutaneous lesions associated with puncture wounds formed while gardening or handling plant material. Choice D is an image of germ tubes (pseudohyphae) formed by Candida albicans when it invades tissues. Candida is an opportunistic pathogen, but it does not cause fungus balls by invading cavitary lesions in the lung. Choice E is an image of the hyphae of the Zygomycophyta (Mucor, Rhizopus or Absidia) which cause rhinocerebral infections in ketoacidotic diabetics and cancer patients.

question: A novel infectious disease has become prevalent and increasingly widespread over the past 2 years. The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) have just isolated the cause of the illness, which is a virus. The virus looks like a brick-shaped complex. It consists of double-stranded, enveloped DNA, which replicates in the cytoplasm via a virion-associated transcriptase. This new virus would be most likely classified in which of the following families?
explanation: The correct answer is F. Examples of viruses in the Poxvirus family are variola, vaccinia and molluscum contagiosum. All DNA viruses are icosahedral, except for Poxviruses, which are described as brick-shaped complexes. Poxvirus DNA is enveloped. All DNA viruses replicate their DNA in the nucleus, except for Poxvirus, which replicates in the cytoplasm via a virion-associated transcriptase. All of the enzymes and factors necessary for viral replication are then made in the cytoplasm. Adenoviruses (choice A) like the other DNA viruses (except Poxvirus), are icosahedral and have double-stranded linear DNA that replicates in the nucleus. The DNA is not enveloped and there is no virion-associated polymerase. The main example of the Hepadnavirus (choice B) family is the hepatitis B virus. It is icosahedral and contains partially double-stranded circular DNA that is enveloped. Viruses carry a DNA polymerase with reverse transcriptase activity to synthesize an RNA intermediate that is then used to make genomic DNA. Herpesviruses (choice C) consist of herpes simplex, varicella zoster, Epstein-Barr and cytomegalovirus. These are icosahedral and contain enveloped double-stranded linear DNA. The DNA replicates in the nucleus and the virus is assembled in the nucleus. Papillomaviruses (choice D) are icosahedral and contain naked double-stranded circular DNA that replicates in the nucleus. The most important of the Parvoviruses (choice E) is parvovirus B19. It is icosahedral and is the only DNA virus that contains single-stranded DNA, which is naked and replicates in the nucleus.

question: A 19-year-old man who is a summer camp counselor in Mississippi is brought to the emergency department because of a headache, vomiting, and confusion He has a temperature of 38.9°C (102°F) and appears disoriented to time and place Physical examination shows gait ataxia when walking and the patient complains of double vision. Over the next several hours, the patient's confusion progresses to stupor Examination of cerebrospinal fluid obtained by lumbar puncture shows 300 lymphocytes, glucose of 50 mg/dL, and total protein of 20 mg/dL. Blood glucose is 78 mg/dL. Which of the following is the means of transmission of the most likely causal agent?
explanation: The correct answer is B. This patient has the signs and symptoms of a viral encephalitis. During the summer months, most types of viral encephalitis are transmitted by mosquitoes. Examples of arthropod-borne viruses include St. Louis virus, West Nile encephalitis virus (Flaviviridae), and Eastern equine, Western equine, and Venezuelan equine encephalitis viruses (Togaviridae). Herpes simplex encephalitis is actually the most common type of encephalitis in the United States, but it is transmitted by direct contact with infected tissues. If this had been a herpes simplex encephalitis, the lumbar puncture would have yielded a high opening pressure and multiple red blood cells would have been found in the cerebrospinal fluid. Aerosol (choice A) is the mechanism of transmission of most of the respiratory viruses. Fecal-oral transmission (choice C) is the most common means of infection with most gastroenteritis viruses. Most of these viruses are naked capsid viruses which are able to withstand passage through the acidity of the stomach. Parenteral transmission (choice D) is common among the enveloped viruses, which require direct transfusion or transplantation to cause disease. Sexual transmission (choice E) is common among the enveloped viruses, which are extremely fragile in the environment.

question: A 32-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician because of a chronic cough and low-grade fever. Examination of sputum shows numerous acid-fast bacteria. The patient's CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 500/uL. A chest x-ray shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is E. Despite the stress placed on the Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare complex in discussions about HIV-infected patients, “ordinary” tuberculosis, caused by M. tuberculosis is the most prevalent form of mycobacterial infection at this point. M. avium-intracellulare complex infections usually do not predominate until the CD4 cell count has fallen well below 100/uL. It is also important to maintain a particularly high index of suspicion in AIDS patients, in whom the chest x-ray may be initially normal, possibly due to an impaired immune response. Some of these cases may clinically (and pathologically) resemble a more conventional bacterial pneumonia, because the body substitutes a comparatively ineffective neutrophil response for the granulomatous response it has trouble mounting. M. avium-intracellulare (choice A) are unusual mycobacterial infections that are noted for causing pulmonary and disseminated infections in AIDS patients, but they are less prevalent than M. tuberculosis except when the CD4+ count is less than 60/uL. M. leprae (choice B) causes leprosy. It is not an infection that is associated with HIV infection in the United States. M. marinum (choice C) can cause fish-tank granuloma (an ulcerating granuloma on the hands of tropical fish enthusiasts) when it enters through cuts in the skin in people who maintain home fish tanks. M. scrofulaceum (choice D) is a scotochromogen (produces carotenoid pigments in the dark) that causes solitary cervical lymphadenopathy in children exposed to contaminated water sources.

question: A photograph of a stomach obtained at autopsy of a 38-year-old man is shown. The patient most likely was infected with which of the following organisms?
explanation: The correct answer is D. The photograph shows a stomach with a perforated peptic ulcer. Perforation of a peptic ulcer is potentially fatal, because of either peritonitis with sepsis or sudden exsanguination (if the perforation damages one of the many arteries of the stomach). Peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, possibly gastric carcinoma, and gastric lymphoma have been strongly associated with Helicobacter pylori colonization of the mucus layer covering the gastric mucosa. The most important pathogenic attribute of H. pylori is its production of urease, which neutralizes the acidic pH of the stomach and allows the organism to invade the mucosal surface. The urease-positive organisms can be remembered with the mnemonic PUNCH: Proteus, Ureaplasma, Nocardia, Cryptococcus, Helicobacter. Helicobacter pylori can be detected with the urease breath test. Campylobacter jejuni (choice A) is also a gram-negative curved rod but is not associated with the formation of gastric ulcers. Clostridium perfringens (choice B) is a gram-positive, anaerobic rod that is associated with gangrene and a mild form of food poisoning. Escherichia coli (choice C) is a gram-negative, lactose-fermenting rod associated with many forms of gastroenteritis but not with gastric ulcer formation. Shigella dysenteriae (choice E) is a gram-negative, lactose-negative rod associated with bloody diarrhea but not with gastric ulcers.

question: A composite virus has been created that has the genome of the molluscum contagiosum virus and the capsid of poliovirus Which of the following genomes would the progeny viruses most likely have?
explanation: The correct answer is A. Composite viruses are viruses that are created in laboratories by artificially combining components of different parental viruses. In this case, the genetic material is DNA because the molluscum contagiosum virus is a double-stranded DNA virus in the poxvirus family. Thus the progeny viruses will have a double-stranded DNA genome. Double-stranded RNA, segmented (choice B) would be the genome of reoviruses, and neither poxviruses nor poliovirus have this form of genome. Negative-stranded RNA viruses (choice C) is the genome of many viruses including rabies and orthomyxoviruses, but neither is present in this composite virus. Positive-stranded RNA viruses (choice D) is the genome of the polioviruses, but because the example uses only the poliovirus capsid, the poliovirus nucleic acid would not be present in target cells. Segmented RNA (choice E) is carried by Reoviridae, Orthomyxoviridae, Bunyaviridae, and Arenaviridae, but none of these genomes were included in this composite virus.

question: A 32-year-old man with AIDS develops a fever, headache, and a stiff neck. Examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows 100 cells, which are mostly lymphocytes, glucose of 35 mg/dL, and protein of 75 mg/dL. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm this patient's diagnosis?
explanation: The correct answer is B. This patient has symptoms and signs of a fungal cerebrospinal infection. The most common cause of meningitis in AIDS patients in the United States is Cryptococcus neoformans, which is an encapsulated, monomorphic yeast acquired from exposure to pigeon droppings. Although the USMLE likes to mention the India ink test of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in vignettes to avoid having to give away the diagnosis, India ink is not the preferred diagnostic test. The more sensitive test that is used in most hospital situations is latex particle agglutination to detect capsular antigens shed into the CSF. India ink (choice A), a test to diagnose cryptococcal infections, depends on the precipitation of a particulate dye around the capsular material of the organism. It misses about 50% of all infections. Molecular probes (choice C) are used in many diagnoses, such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae and a variety of virus infections. It is not used for cryptococcal meningitis. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) (choice D) is used to detect human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infections in infants. This assay detects integrated HIV (provirus). PCRs are available for other virus infections but are not used to diagnose cryptococcosis. Tzanck smear (choice E) is used to diagnose herpesvirus infections. It involves touching a slide or coverslip to a lesion to lift off the multinucleated giant cells caused by the infection.

question: A 32-year-old woman who recently emigrated from Southeast Asia comes to the emergency department because of severe right upper quadrant pain. An ultrasound of the gallbladder shows high echogenicity and she undergoes a cholecystectomy Examination of the gallbladder shows a large number of dark-colored, faceted stones with irregular shapes. Infection with which of the following organisms is most likely associated with this type of stone?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The stones described are pigment stones, composed of relatively pure calcium bilirubinate. These stones are less common than cholesterol stones. Risk factors for pigment stones include hepatic cirrhosis (unclear mechanism), hemolytic anemias, and liver fluke infection, notably by the Oriental liver fluke Clonorchis sinensis. Fasciolopsis buski (choice B) is a large intestinal fluke that can cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, and intestinal mucosal abscesses. Fasciola spp., not Fasciolopsis, are other liver flukes besides Clonorchis. Paragonimus westermani (choice C) is a lung fluke that can cause cough, bronchiectasis, and hemoptysis. Schistosoma haematobium (choice D) is a blood fluke that tends to infect pelvic veins and may cause bladder disease (including cancer). Taenia saginata (choice E) is the beef tapeworm, and may cause intestinal obstruction.

question: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a fever and severe pain in her fingers and toes. Treatment with morphine is begun and the girl's symptoms are partially relieved. Physical examination shows a raised facial rash. A peripheral blood smear shows severe anemia, and a bone-marrow aspirate shows no erythroid precursor cells. Infection with which of the following is most likely responsible for these findings?
explanation: The correct answer is E. Parvoviruses are small, single-stranded DNA viruses, of which only serotype B19 is pathogenic for humans. This virus causes three distinct syndromes: a childhood febrile rash known as erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease), aplastic crisis in individuals with chronic hemolytic diseases (sickle-cell anemia, thalassemia, etc.), and congenital infections that can present as stillbirth, hydrops fetalis (analogous to severe Rh incompatibility), or severe anemia. Coxsackie viruses (choice A) usually cause coldlike illness, but can cause herpangina, myocarditis, and meningitis. Echoviruses (choice B) can infect a variety of organ systems (gastrointestinal, central nervous system, eyes, heart, respiratory, skin), but are not a cause of aplastic crises. Hepadnavirus (choice C) is the causative agent of hepatitis B. Herpesviruses (choice D) cause a variety of acute to chronic infections, including herpes simplex types 1 and 2, chickenpox, chronic herpes zoster, cytomegalovirus infection, and Epstein-Barr virus infections.

question: A stable clone of bacteria that is susceptible to tetracycline is placed in culture with 10 bacteria that are resistant to tetracycline. Within 24 hours, all the bacteria in the culture are tetracycline-resistant. The genetic process by which this occurred is shown Which of the following best describes this process?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The diagram shows the process of conjugation between an F+ donor and an F- recipient bacterium. This process transfers plasmids in their entirety from the donor to the recipient. The traits that will be transferred in this way are those encoded in the plasmid and all recipients will become donors in the process. Generalized transduction (choice B) can be accomplished by both lytic and temperative phage only during the lytic cycle. The process involves the phage mistakenly packaging bacterial DNA into the capsid and transferring the DNA to another bacterial cell. In this type of transduction any gene can be transferred. Homologous recombination (choice C) is not a mechanism of genetic transfer for bacteria but a mechanism by which bacterial nucleic acid is stabilized following transfer. Transformation, transduction, and Hfr conjugation are all followed by homologous recombination requiring recombinase A. Specialized transduction (choice D) can only be accomplished by a temperate phage in which there is an excision error during induction of the phage from the bacterial chromosome. In this case, bacterial nucleic acid is mistakenly excised along with phage DNA. Only certain genes (located next to the phage insertion sites) have an opportunity to be transferred. Transformation (choice E) is the uptake of naked DNA by certain 'competent' bacterial cells.

question: A 27-year-old woman develops a dry cough, fever, headache, and muscular pains. She has been treated unsuccessfully for the past 1 week with aspirin and ampicillin. Three days later, she is brought to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath and worsening cough. An x-ray of the chest shows scattered interstitial opacities. Treatment with erythromycin is begun and her symptoms rapidly improve. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with the causal organism of patient's illness?
options: E. Requirement for factors X and V
explanation: The correct answer is A. This patient's clinical presentation is typical of primary atypical pneumonia. This type of pneumonia is typically caused by intracellular organisms such as viruses, or Chlamydiae, but since Mycoplasma lacks a cell wall, it does not elicit the characteristic neutrophilic infiltrate caused by most other bacteria. Because the patient's infection responded to erythromycin, it cannot have been caused by a virus; so the most likely causative agent is Mycoplasma pneumoniae. A finding in about 65% of Mycoplasma patients is the production of cold agglutinins: IgM isohemagglutinins that will agglutinate autologous erythrocytes at 4°C (39.2°F). The Dieterle silver stain (choice B) is used to identify Legionella pneumophila, which is an agent of atypical pneumonia of the elderly but would be more likely in a smoker or immunosuppressed patient. Legionella would respond to erythromycin, but this patient is not immunocompromised. The Quellung reaction (choice C) is a technique used to identify the capsular serotype of Streptococcus pneumoniae. This bacterium is the most common cause of adult typical pneumonia and would not cause the interstitial presentation described here. Requirement for cysteine (choice D) is a characteristic of four genera of bacteria: Francisella, Legionella, Brucella, and Pasteurella. Although Francisella, Legionella, and Brucella are facultative intracellular pathogens that could cause atypical pneumonia, they would not be expected in this patient. Francisella is acquired from ticks or from handling infected reservoir animals. Brucella is acquired from contaminated dairy products or contact with animals. Legionella is a disease of elderly smokers who are immunosuppressed. Pasteurella is found in the mouths of many animals and is transmitted most commonly from cat bites. Requirement for factors X and V (choice E) is characteristic of Haemophilus. Haemophilus is an extracellular bacterium that causes otitis media, epiglottitis, pharyngitis and meningitis in unvaccinated children who are between 3 months and 2 years of age. It would not be expected in the present patient's age group.

question: A 35-year-old man who lives in the central U.S. develops fever chest pain, and dry cough. Chest x-rays show opacities, consistent with calcified masses. The results of a PPD skin test are negative. A CT-guided biopsy of one of the calcifying masses is most likely to show which of the following?
options: A. 2-to-5-μm yeast with a thin cell wall but no true capsule
B. 4-to-10-μm yeast with a broad, slimy capsule
D. 20-to-50-μm nonbudding spherule filled with endospores
E. Hyphae branching dichotomously at acute angles
explanation: The correct answer is A. A variety of fungi can produce acute or chronic lung disease like that described in this case history. They are distinguished by geographic incidence and examination of the sputum or biopsy. Histoplasma capsulatum which causes histoplasmosis, is observed most frequently in the Ohio, Mississippi, and Missouri river valleys of the United States (Central U.S.). The organism is a small (2-to-5-μm) intracellular yeast which, despite the name, has no true capsule. Calcifying lesions forming in the lungs are very suggestive of fungal infection. Blastomyces dermatitidis could cause similar presentation in this area, but it would be found in the sputum as a broad-based budding yeast, and that option is not available within the choices. Choice B describes Cryptococcus which is the most common cause of fungal meningitis in immunosuppressed patients notably those with AIDS or hematopoietic disorders. Choice C describes Paracoccidioides which can cause pulmonary disease in patients from South and Central America. Choice D describes Coccidioides, which can cause skin lesions or pulmonary disease in the desert southwest and far west of the United States (San Joaquin Valley fever). Choice E describes Aspergillus an opportunistic fungus that can invade cavitary lesions in the lung and cause aspergilloma, or fungus ball.

question: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of fever, joint and muscle pain, photophobia, and malaise. He says that he felt well until 4 days ago, but now has a headache and has been vomiting. His temperature is 40.0°C (104.0°F). Physical examination shows no rash, ulceration, or petechiae Laboratory studies show an absolute leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and increased serum transaminases. A peripheral blood smear shows granulocytes that contain berry-like clusters of intracellular organisms. The vector for the causative agent of his illness is the same as that for which of the following organisms?
explanation: The correct answer is A. This patient has granulocytic ehrlichiosis, caused by Ehrlichia phagocytophila. This intracellular bacterium is transmitted by the Ixodes tick, which also transmits Borrelia burgdorferi and Babesia microti. The disease presents similarly to Rocky Mountain spotted fever but does not have a rash. The pathognomonic feature in this case history is the presence of morulae (berry-like clusters of organisms) inside the patient's granulocytes. Francisella tularensis (choice B) can be transmitted in a number of different ways, but when an arthropod is implicated, it is the Dermacentor tick. This is the same tick that transmits Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Tularemia is an ulceroglandular disease with fever, ulcer at the bite site, and lymph node enlargement. Plasmodium vivax (choice C) is transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito. Mosquitoes are responsible for transmission of most of the encephalitis viruses, all species of malaria parasites, dengue yellow fever, and filariasis. This patient clearly does not have encephalitis, and malaria, dengue, yellow fever, and filariasis would not be expected in a 16-year-old boy in the continental United States. Rickettsia rickettsii (choice D) is the agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever and is transmitted by the Dermacentor tick. Rocky Mountain spotted fever has a characteristic rash that begins on the ankles and wrists progressing toward the trunk. The Weil-Felix test, which is a nonspecific test for antibodies that agglutinate Proteus organisms, would be positive. This tick also transmits Francisella tularensis but the symptoms of this patient are not consistent with either tularemia (an ulceroglandular disease) or Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Rickettsia tsutsugamushi (choice E) is the agent of scrub typhus. It is transmitted by mites in the genus Leptotrombidium. Rickettsialpox (Rickettsia akari) is also transmitted in this fashion, but both of these diseases are rare in the United States and would be characterized by rash and Weil-Felix test positivity.

question: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a seizure. His mother says that he developed a fever, a severe prefrontal headache, and an altered sense of smell ten days after swimming in a lake near his camp. Physical examination shows a profuse green discharge from the nose. Examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows 100 neutrophils, 50 lymphocytes, 30 mg/dL glucose, and 60 mg/dL protein. He dies two days after admission despite aggressive therapy Which of the following is most likely to be found on microscopic examination of the central nervous system at autopsy?
options: D. Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusion bodies
E. Ribbon-like hyphae branching at 90-degree angles
explanation: The correct answer is C. This child has acquired primary amebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri. This organism is a free-living ameba that is found in warm freshwater lakes. During the act of diving into such lakes, changes in pressure can force the organism through the cribriform plate and result in the production of necrotic lesions spreading from the olfactory lobes. The form of the organism that is found in human tissue is a flagellated trophozoite. Gram-negative, encapsulated diplococci (choice A) describes Neisseria meningitidis. This is a common cause of meningitis in young adults, but the case history would have to describe the presence of petechial hemorrhages from endotoxin toxicity. N. meningitidis overproduces outer membrane fragments and thus produces very early signs of endotoxin shock compared to other gram-negative organisms. Gram-positive catalase-negative diplococci (choice B) describes Streptococcus pneumoniae. Although this is the most common cause of typical pneumonia, meningitis and sinusitis in the United States, it is not associated with swimming or diving, and the CSF would have shown extremely high numbers of neutrophils, low glucose, and high protein. Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusion bodies (choice D) describes cells infected with herpes simplex virus. This is the most common cause of viral encephalitis in the United States. It is not associated with swimming or diving. Although the CSF cell, protein, and glucose values could have indicated a viral etiology, herpes simplex encephalitis is also associated with a high opening pressure and the presence of many red blood cells. Encephalitis is also generally associated with confusion or change in mental status. Ribbon-like hyphae branching at 90-degree angles (choice E) describes the zygomycophyta: bread mold fungi in the genera Rhizopus, Absidia, and Mucor. These agents can cause fatal rhinocerebral infections in ketoacidotic diabetics and adults with cancer. The symptoms would be quite similar to those described in this case history, but these are opportunistic pathogens that do not cause disease in otherwise healthy individuals. Urease-positive, encapsulated yeasts (choice F) describes Cryptococcus neoformans. This monomorphic fungus is the principal cause of meningitis in patients with Hodgkin disease or AIDS.

question: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a sudden high fever, severe dyspnea, and malaise. One hour later, he develops progressive respiratory distress and supplemental oxygen is provided. He has a history of intravenous drug abuse, His CD4 cell count is 73/uL. Which of the following tests will be most helpful in confirming the identity of the most likely causal agent of his fever and respiratory symptoms?
explanation: The correct answer is B. The most common atypical pneumonia in AIDS is caused by the atypical fungus Pneumocystis jiroveci (formerly carinii). Patients with Pneumocystis pneumonia have great difficulty producing sputum, so bronchial lavage or transmural biopsy are generally required. The sample is then submitted to the direct fluorescent antibody test or stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain to visualize the organisms. The direct fluorescent antibody test is a technique to demonstrate the presence of antigen from a pathogen in a patient. Antigen-detecting tests will remain useful throughout the life of an AIDS patient because they do not depend on detection of the patient's immune response to the pathogen (which may be absent at the end of AIDS). When stained with methenamine silver, Pneumocystis cysts have a characteristic cup or boat shape; the individual cells are difficult to demonstrate without electron microscopy. CD4 cell count (choice A) is used to measure the progression of infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Since the virus infects and destroys these cells, the number remaining in the circulation becomes a good predictor of the progression of disease. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (choice C) is used as the screening test to diagnose HIV infection. It is a serologic test (i.e., identifies antibodies against the virus) and once the patient progresses into full-blown AIDS, antibody levels other than IgM will decline, so in general, serologic tests in late HIV infection tend to be less useful than tests that detect antigens from a pathogen. Polymerase chain reaction (choice D) is used to detect the viral load of the HIV virus in infected patients and infants. Western blot (choice E) is the confirmatory serologic test that is used in the diagnosis of HIV infection.

question: A 28-year-old woman from Mexico develops an indurated, erythematous nodule that is 12 mm in diameter after receiving a PPD tuberculin test. Which of the following is the bacterial feature most important in stimulating this response?
explanation: The correct answer is D. This woman has developed a positive tuberculin skin test indicating exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The molecule injected into the skin of the forearm to elicit this response is a purified protein derivative (PPD), which is composed of tuberculin (an outer surface protein) and mycolic acids of the organism. This is an example of a type IV hypersensitivity reaction requiring sensitized TH1 cells. Only proteins can evoke such responses, since T cells are only capable of recognizing peptides presented to them in the context of an MHC molecule. The cell wall (choice A) of mycobacteria contains a thinner-than-normal layer of peptidoglycan and mycolic acids, which are long-chain fatty acids. However, this material is not proteinaceous and therefore does not stimulate the TH1 cells necessary for the formation of the delayed-type hypersensitivity response. The cytoplasmic membrane (choice B) of mycobacteria is a phospholipid bilayer that is similar to the inner membranes of all other prokaryotes and does not contribute to the specific skin test for tuberculosis. Flagella (choice C) are not present on M. tuberculosis because the organism is not motile. M. tuberculosis does not possess a periplasmic space (choice E) because it is an organism that is taxonomically related to the gram-positives. Only gram-negative bacteria possess a periplasmic space.

question: A 35-year-old man develops hemiparesis, homonymous hemianopia, and cognitive deterioration. An MRI of the brain shows widespread areas of abnormal T2 signal in the white matter. An electroencephalogram shows diffuse slowing over both cerebral hemispheres. Examination of tissue obtained on biopsy of the brain shows demyelination with abnormal giant oligodendrocytes, some of which contain eosinophilic inclusions. This patient's condition occurs most commonly in association with which of the following diseases?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The condition is progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is a rapidly progressive demyelinating disorder in which the JC virus (a polyomavirus) infects oligodendroglial cells in the brain. The eosinophilic inclusions represent accumulations of JC virus. PML occurs in about 1% of AIDS patients, and is the AIDS-defining illness in half of the patients who develop the condition. Symptoms include aphasia, hemiparesis, cortical blindness, ataxia, and conjugate gaze abnormalities. The condition can progress to quadriparesis and coma. There is no effective treatment for this disorder. Shingles and postinfectious encephalitis can follow chickenpox (choice B) but varicella is not specifically associated with demyelination. Measles (choice C) can cause an encephalitis and, in some cases, subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) may follow previous measles infection. These disorders would affect not only white matter but gray matter as well. Also, SSPE usually occurs before the age of 18. Multiple sclerosis (choice D) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease characterized by demyelination. The immunologic basis of the pathology appears to be that TH1 lymphocytes reactive against myelin stimulate macrophages to destroy the myelin. It is an example of a type IV hypersensitivity response. Women are affected twice as often as men. The disease tends to have a relapsing and remitting course and may involve visual impairment, cranial nerve signs, ataxia, nystagmus, and internuclear ophthalmoplegia. Spinal cord lesions give rise to motor and sensory difficulties of the trunk and limbs, and spasticity and loss of control of bladder function. Rabies (choice E) produces eosinophilic inclusions (Negri bodies) in the brain but these are found in the gray matter. Signs of rabies would include excessive salivation, hallucinations, and hydrophobia. Syphilis (choice F) can cause meningitis, encephalitis, and spinal cord damage, but the disease process would not be limited to the white matter. Tuberculosis (choice G) can cause a granulomatous meningitis, typically affecting the base of the brain.

question: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of redness and a yellowish discharge from her left eye over the past 2 days. She has had minimal crusting upon awakening in the morning but has not had eye pain or previous trauma. Physical examination shows diffuse conjunctival hyperemia and a mucoid discharge. The pupils are reactive to light, but there is mild photophobia of the affected eye. Gram stain of the exudate shows pleomorphic, gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following is necessary to culture the most likely causal organism on a blood agar plate?
options: A. Antibiotics to inhibit normal flora
E. Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar
explanation: The correct answer is E. The patient is suffering from conjunctivitis caused by Haemophilus, a fastidious organism requiring factors V (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) and X (hematin), which must be released from whole-blood preparations to be accessible to the organism. This can be done by gentle heating, which lyses the red blood cells, or by co-culture with Staphylococcus aureus, which is beta-hemolytic and lyses the red blood cells to provide the factors Haemophilus needs for growth. This is called the satellite phenomenon. Antibiotics (choice A) would not be necessary since, with proper culture techniques, no normal flora should be available to confuse the diagnosis of conjunctivitis. Antibiotics and antifungals are added to chocolate agar to create Thayer-Martin medium to prevent the growth of normal flora when culturing from the genital tract. Cold temperature (choice B) would not be necessary because Haemophilus grows at normal body temperature. Listeria is the genus commonly mentioned for which a cold temperature is necessary. Cholesterol (choice C) is necessary for the growth of Mycoplasma but not Haemophilus. Low oxygen tension (choice D) is necessary for the growth of the microaerophiles (such as Campylobacter, Helicobacter, and Borrelia), but is not a condition for growth of Haemophilus.

question: A 67-year-old woman in a skilled nursing facility develops flulike symptoms. Several days later, she develops a high fever dyspnea, a productive cough, and mental status changes. An x-ray of the chest shows a cavitary lesion in her left lung Examination of a sputum sample will most likely show which of the following?
options: B. A gram-positive, catalase-negative, alpha-hemolytic diplococcus
C. A gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive coccus
E. A yeast that forms pseudohyphae
explanation: The correct answer is C. This woman has developed a pulmonary abscess, as evidenced by the chest radiograph. Of the organisms listed, Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely cause of bacterial pneumonia complicated by abscess formation. Bacteria that commonly produce pneumonia that develops in the context of influenza include Staph. aureus, Haemophilus influenzae and Streptococcus pneumoniae. Of these, Staph. aureus is most destructive to lung tissue and likely to cause cavitary lesions. Staph. aureus is a gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive coccus. A gram-negative, oxidase-negative bacillus (choice A) describes Klebsiella pneumoniae. This bacterium would be a cause of pneumonia in alcoholic or diabetic patients, or in those suffering from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. A gram-positive catalase-negative alpha-hemolytic diplococcus (choice B) describes Strep. pneumoniae. This agent causes a necrotizing abscessing pneumonia with appearance similar to that of Staph. aureus, but it rarely causes cavitary lesions. A silver-staining cyst (choice D) describes Pneumocystis jiroveci. This agent is associated with atypical pneumonia in the immunocompromised or in premature infants. A yeast that forms pseudohyphae (choice E) describes Candida albicans. Candida is an opportunistic pathogen in the immunocompromised, but would not be expected to be associated with postviral pneumonia.

question: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of an itchy, vesicular rash on his face and trunk Physical examination demonstrates a mixture of lesions, with macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions. The mother says that the lesions seem to be occurring in crops. The virus that causes this boy's condition also causes which of the following disorders?
explanation: The correct answer is D. This is varicella (chickenpox), which is the primary form of infection by the herpes zoster (varicella-zoster) virus. Recurrence due to virus harbored in neurons tends to be dermatomal in distribution and is called shingles. Fever, malaise, headache, and myalgia may also be present, particularly in the prodromal phase. Tzanck smear of the base of a vesicle may demonstrate multinucleated giant cells. Immunocompromised patients can be treated with acyclovir to prevent dissemination. Chickenpox may be complicated by secondary bacterial infection, pneumonia, systemic spread (immunosuppressed patients), neurologic involvement (rare), Reye syndrome (rare), and/or hemolytic anemia (rare). Genital vesicles and ulcers (choice A) are associated with herpes simplex type 2. Infectious mononucleosis (choice B) is usually caused by Epstein-Barr virus. Orchitis (choice C) can complicate mumps infection. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (choice E) is a rare complication of measles infection.

question: An 18-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fever, chills, and sore throat. Physical examination shows marked pharyngeal hyperemia, tonsillar exudates, cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. Treatment with ampicillin is begun. Two weeks later, he returns to the physician because of a generalized maculopapular rash. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
options: D. Lateral x-ray of the neck
explanation: The correct answer is C. This patient most likely has infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The clinical features include sore throat, headache, fever, malaise, lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis and tonsillitis, hepatosplenomegaly, periorbital edema, rash, and a palatal enanthem. The diagnosis is made by heterophile antibody testing (monospot), EBV antibody titers, and the finding of lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. Treatment includes rest, fluids, and analgesics. Treatment with penicillin derivatives (ampicillin) leads to a maculopapular rash. Chest x-ray (choice A) is useful for a respiratory or cardiac process. Infectious mononucleosis cannot be diagnosed by any radiographic study. ELISA (choice B) would be a useful screening test for a variety of infections, including human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). A lateral x-ray of the neck (choice D) is useful in acute epiglottitis; it would show epiglottic swelling. The symptoms of epiglottitis include extreme sore throat, drooling, and difficulty swallowing. A rapid antigen test (choice E) is used to diagnose streptococcal pharyngitis. Streptococcal pharyngitis is characterized by fever, sore throat, tonsillar exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy. A scarlatiniform rash may follow the pharyngitis. The rash, a diffuse erythema that later desquamates, is caused by an erythrotoxin. Antibodies to the varicella virus (choice F) can be detected by immunofluorescence. The symptoms of varicella include a vesicular rash (in various stages of evolution), fever, and malaise. The treatment is bathing soaks and antipruritic topical medication. Treatment with aspirin has been associated with Reye syndrome and should therefore be avoided.

question: A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a fever, nausea, diarrhea, and a rash. Her last menstrual period began 3 days ago. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 90/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a diffuse erythematous rash with areas of desquamation over the hands and feet. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
options: A. Gram-negative, oxidase-negative, nonfermenting, nonmotile, non-H₂S-producing bacillus
explanation: The correct answer is C. This patient has toxic shock syndrome (TSS), a multisystem syndrome caused by a toxin (TSST-1) formed by certain strains of Staphylococcus aureus. TSS usually affects several organ systems (gastrointestinal, renal, hepatic, hematopoietic, musculoskeletal, pulmonary) and can result in death. TSS has historically been associated with the use of tampons in young women, but can also occur in other patient populations. Fever, hypotension, diarrhea, and diffuse rash with desquamation of the hands and feet are common symptoms. Management of shock, renal failure, and adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) are a priority if these conditions are present, in addition to appropriate antibacterial treatment. S. aureus is a gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive coccus. A gram-negative, oxidase-negative non-lactose fermenting, nonmotile, non-H₂S-producing bacillus (choice A) describes the genus Shigella, which causes dysentery, characterized by fever, abdominal cramps, and bloody diarrhea. A gram-positive anaerobic rod (choice B) describes Clostridium perfringens, which causes gas gangrene with necrosis of soft tissues, usually after a traumatic wound. It is also a cause of food poisoning. Gram-positive, catalase-positive, novobiocin-sensitive coccus (choice D) describes Staph. epidermidis, which is part of the normal skin flora but is notorious for causing infections of intravenous lines and prosthetic heart valves. A single-stranded diploid RNA virus (choice E) describes the retroviruses. Although HIV-1 can cause many diverse findings and should never be immediately ruled out, the findings in the present patient are most specific for TSS.

question: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of fever, myalgias, and cough He owns an automobile repair shop and recently cleaned his garage, which was infested with mice. He is tachypneic and must use accessory respiratory muscles to breathe. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The correct answer is C. Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome, first reported in 1993, consists of fever, myalgia, and rapid development of respiratory failure leading to death. The initial cases were mostly among Navajo Indians, however, cases have been documented in many U.S. states and in Canada. It is most common in the U.S. Four Corners states: New Mexico, Arizona, Colorado, and Utah. The causative agent is a hantavirus belonging to the family Bunyaviridae. The virus has also been called the Sin Nombre (Spanish for 'without a name') virus. Infection is thought to be through inhalation of aerosolized secretions from the common deer mouse. The disease typically begins with a nonspecific prodrome (fever, generalized myalgia, and gastrointestinal disturbances) followed 4 to 5 days later by respiratory symptoms (cough, dyspnea, and tachypnea). This progresses rapidly to an adult respiratory distress syndrome and, in many cases, death. California encephalitis (choice A) is caused by an arbovirus transmitted by infected mosquitoes. Most cases are in children younger than 10 years of age. Signs and symptoms include fever, headache, photophobia, nausea, and vomiting. Myalgias and arthralgias are typically present. Seizure activity is most frequently observed in infants and young children. Most cases are in the midwestern United States. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (choice B) is a Herpesvirus that produces a variety of infections. Primary CMV infection is usually asymptomatic in immunocompetent patients, but can cause a heterophile-negative mononucleosis syndrome. Perinatal infections can occur in utero, intrapartum, or postpartum, and can produce congenital malformations. CMV can be transmitted by leukocytes in blood transfusions. In patients with AIDS or other immunosuppressive states, CMV can produce severe disease, including retinitis, pneumonia, encephalitis, adrenalitis, and gastrointestinal tract ulcerations. Plague (choice D) is caused by Yersinia pestis. It is endemic in the desert southwest of the United States, but plague normally begins with an extremely high fever, conjunctivitis, and septicemia. If it is acquired by fleabite, then buboes (hemorrhagic lymph nodes) will be found; if it is acquired in the pneumonic form, then cough will be observed. Poliovirus (choice E) is a member of the Picornavirus family. It remains epidemic in parts of Asia and Africa even though the wild type has been eliminated from the western hemisphere. The virus affects cranial nerve nuclei and anterior horn motor neurons of the spinal cord, producing a flaccid paralysis that is usually asymmetric. Vaccine-related polio can occur with the live virus vaccine. Rabies (choice F) is a Rhabdovirus that produces encephalitis and/or myelitis. It should be considered in persons who have recently traveled outside of the United States. The most common sources of exposure are dogs, cats, skunks, foxes, raccoons (in Florida and Connecticut), wolves, and bats. The infection is acquired from the bite of a rabid animal or by inhalation. Rabies also has been reported to occur in patients after corneal transplantation. The virus spreads along peripheral nerves to the central nervous system. Symptoms include hallucinations, hydrophobia and copious salivation. Tularemia (choice G) is caused by Francisella tularensis, a gram-negative, cysteine-requiring facultative intracellular bacillus. The disease is most common in Arkansas and Missouri, and is acquired by handling, ingesting, or inhaling material from infected reservoir animals such as deer, rabbits and small rodents. It may also be transmitted by ticks from one of the reservoir animals to humans. Tularemia is generally characterized by disseminated granulomatous lesions, and would not be expected to cause acute respiratory distress syndrome.

question: A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of a headache and a high fever. He recently returned from a 2-week trip to Europe where he went diving in several natural pools. A diagnosis of meningoencephalitis localized to the base of his brain is made. A photomicrograph of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is shown. Through which of the following structures did the causal organism most likely gain access to the brain?
explanation: The correct answer is B. The rare but life-threatening meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri apparently ensues when the organism enters the body through the nasal mucosa and crosses the cribriform plate to enter the brain via the olfactory nerves. It has been speculated that changes in pressure created during diving predispose to this infection. The cavernous sinus (choice A) is the site of entry of the zygomycophyta (Rhizopus, Mucor or Absidia) into the brain in diabetic ketoacidotic patients or adults with cancer. The lacrimal bone (choice C) of the medial aspect of the orbit does not appear to be involved in amebic infection. The mouth and its associated bones, including the mandible (choice D), do not appear to be routes of infection for this organism. The nasal bones (choice E) located on the superior surface of the nose, do not appear to be a route of infection for this organism. The zygomatic bone (choice F) which forms the cheekbone, does not appear to be a route of infection for this organism.

question: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of malaise, loss of appetite. nausea. and jaundice. Laboratory studies show a serum alanine transaminase (ALT) of 3,200 U/L. Serology for hepatitis viruses is performed and shows the presence of HBsAg and HBc IgM antibody Antibody tests for HBsAb and HAV are negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these results?
options: B. A dual infection of HBV and HAV
D. Immunity to hepatitis B virus
explanation: The correct answer is A. The presence of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) along with hepatitis B core IgM antibody (HBc IgM Ab), and the absence of hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb), indicate the early stages of an acute infection with hepatitis B virus (HBV). A dual infection of HBV and hepatitis A virus (HAV) (choice B) is not plausible since the IgM anti-HAV serology is negative. Chronic HBV infection (choice C) is unlikely because the patient has HBc IgM Ab, which is characteristic of an acute infection rather than a chronic infection. Immunity to HBV (choice D) is not plausible due to the presence of HBsAg and HBc IgM Ab and the lack of HBsAb. Past hepatitis A infection (choice E) would be manifested by the presence of IgG antibodies against HAV.

question: A 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a fever of 40°C (104°F) Physical examination shows conjunctival petechiae, bruising in the right antecubital fossa, and a murmur is heard on auscultation of the chest along the left fourth intercostal space. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple patchy infiltrates in both lung fields An echocardiogram shows damage to the tricuspid valve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The correct answer is A. This patient has acute infective endocarditis. The most common cause of acute bacterial endocarditis is Staphylococcus aureus. This type of endocarditis is typically acquired by illicit intravenous drug use, which can introduce skin organisms into the venous system that then attack the tricuspid valve. Staph. aureus accounts for between 60 and 90% of cases of endocarditis in intravenous drug users. Damage to the tricuspid valve is common. The endocarditis associated with congenital heart disease (choice B) typically involves either damaged valves or atrial or ventricular septal defects. The tricuspid valve is not particularly vulnerable. Rheumatic fever (choice C) most commonly damages the mitral and aortic valves, and tricuspid damage is usually less severe and seen only when the mitral and aortic valves are heavily involved. Rheumatoid arthritis (choice D) is not associated with bacterial endocarditis. Systemic lupus erythematosus (choice E) can produce small, aseptic vegetations on the ventricular and atrial surfaces of the mitral valve (Libman-Sacks endocarditis).

question: A previously healthy 18-month-old girl is brought fo the physician because of left ear pain. She has no history of major medical illness and her vaccinations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.6°F). Physical examination shows an erythematous dull, and bulging left tympanic membrane. Which of the following virulence factors is most important for the most likely causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is A. The most common causes of otitis media in children are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae and Moraxella catarrhalis. In a vignette that gives no Gram stain or culture characteristics, the answer should refer to the number one cause, in this case Streptococcus pneumoniae. The most important virulence factor in Strep. pneumoniae is the capsule, which protects against phagocytosis. Lipopolysaccharide (choice B) is present in all gram-negative bacteria and would not be found in Strep. pneumoniae which is gram-positive. Non-pilus adhesins (choice C) exist in many organisms, and mediate adherence to the epithelial surfaces. For example, hemagglutinin molecules of bacteria and viruses fit this definition, and some toxins like the pertussis toxin have adhesive abilities. Pili (choice D) are glycoprotein “hairs” which mediate attachment to the epithelium. In gram-positives such as this one they are referred to as fimbriae and in gram-negatives they are extremely important virulence factors in allowing colonization of the uroepithelium by Escherichia coli, for example. Pneumolysin (choice E) is a cytotoxin produced by Strep. pneumoniae which destroys ciliated epithelial cells.

question: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of shortness of breath and palpitations. He recently moved with his family from Brazil to the United States. A chest x-ray shows pulmonary congestion and ECG shows right bundle branch block Echocardiography reveals biventricular dilatation with massive cardiac enlargement. Which of the following is the most likely vector for the causal organism?
explanation: The correct answer is D. The patient has myocarditis due to Trypanosoma cruzi. This infectious condition, known as Chagas disease, is endemic in vast areas of South America and is transmitted from person to person by the reduviid bug, also known as the 'kissing bug'. Experts assess the number of persons with Chagas disease at about 7 million, with about 35 million at risk in South America. T. cruzi is an intracellular protozoan that localizes mainly in the heart and nerve cells of the myenteric plexus, leading to myocarditis and dysmotility of hollow organs, such as the esophagus, colon, and ureter. Cardiac involvement manifests with ventricular dilatation and congestive heart failure secondary to myocyte necrosis and fibrosis. Intracellular parasites can be visualized in tissue sections. Chagas disease is a cause of acquired achalasia, in which the distal third of the esophagus dilates because of loss of its intrinsic innervation. A similar pathologic mechanism accounts for megacolon and megaureter in Chagas disease. The flea (choice A) is the vector for Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of bubonic plague. The louse (choice B) is the vector for Rickettsia prowazekii, the causative agent of epidemic typhus. The mosquito (choice C) is the vector for many of the Arboviruses that cause encephalitis. West Nile virus and St. Louis encephalitis are examples. Ticks (choice E) are the vectors for Borrelia burgdorferi, Babesia, Rickettsia rickettsii, for example.

question: A strain of Escherichia coli is resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, sulfonamides, ampicillin, kanamycin, and neomycin Another strain of the same bacteria is not resistant to any of these drugs. When 100 bacteria from the resistant strain are added to a flask of bacteria of the sensitive strain and incubated overnight, all the bacteria in the flask develop resistance to the full complement of antibiotics Which of the following best explains these findings?
options: A. Transfer of drug resistance from the Hfr chromosome during conjugation
B. Transfer of drug resistance via generalized transduction
C. Transfer of drug resistance via specialized transduction
D. Transfer of drug resistance via transformation
E. Transfer of multiple drug-resistance plasmids via conjugation
explanation: The correct answer is E. Gram-negative bacilli such as Escherichia coli are well known for their ability to transfer multiple-drug resistances during a single conjugative event. When these resistance genes become accumulated on a plasmid capable of mediating conjugation (a fertility factor), all drug-resistance genes are transferred efficiently and swiftly to the other partner of conjugation.
